He did not then put the ship into Court at once, or ask the aid of the civil authorities in the matter, but continued on board with armed men until the 11th August, when this Court first heard of the seizure. The proceedings of this young officer, he (the learned Counsel) hoped, would be seriously dealt with by his official superiors when they were laid before them. He asked the Court, therefore, to dismiss the suit with damages and costs. Here follows the evidence given on behalf of the vessel, and after which"}, {'id': 3323, 'article_title': 'A Vessel Plundered by Africans', 'full_section_title': 'A Vessel Plundered by Africans', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_03_1877#article-25', 'issue_date': '01_03_1877', 'content': "Information has just been received in Liverpool (26th Feb.) of an unusual adventure of a ship's crew on the coast of Liberia. In December the American schooner Joseph Nickerson went ashore on Shark's Point. The crew did all in their power to get her off, but almost as soon as she struck large numbers of armed natives surrounded the vessel in canoes, cutting the cable which had been put out to warp off the ship, and left her in a very awkward position. The mate and four of the crew took a boat, with some difficulty managed to get clear of the savages, and went to Banana for assistance; but they reached there too late to do anything that night. The next day a pilot connected with a Dutch factory there manned seven boats with a number of whites—agents, clerks, and others—all well armed, and they pulled to the scene of the wreck. The natives, however, being alarmed by such a formidable display of strength, did not wait for them to come up, but made for the shore and disappeared. It was found that the ship had been thoroughly ransacked and plundered. She had 250 bags of coffee on board, and the natives had carried off 120 bags, but being unable to take all, they had knocked the heads out of some tar barrels and emptied them over the remainder, which were thus completely spoiled. They also took away the cabin fittings, doors, and boards, and chopped off the wheel level with the deck. The sails they cut down and distributed among themselves. After the mate and crew left for Banana the natives boarded the schooner, and insisted on taking off the captain and steward, who remained, and on the way to the beach they made several attempts to drown them by overturning the boat. Fortunately, they were not successful, and next morning, when the boats arrived from Banana, the two men were seen standing on the beach with nothing on them but their singlets and drawers, all their other clothes having been stolen. The captain and crew of the wrecked schooner returned to Banana, from which place they were taken in the steamer Ethiopia to Loanda, where they laid their case before the American Consul. A consultation afterwards took place between the British and American Consuls, the result of which was that a strict investigation was commenced, with a view to discover and punish the offending natives."}, {'id': 4662, 'article_title': 'Gambia—Bathurst, River Gambia—Liberia—West African Gold Fields—Affairs in Ashanti—Wreck and Plunder of a Ship at Grand Popo', 'full_section_title': 'Gambia—Bathurst, River Gambia—Liberia—West African Gold Fields—Affairs in Ashanti—Wreck and Plunder of a Ship at Grand Popo', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1883#article-1', 'issue_date': '01_08_1883', 'content': "Dear Sir,—When will some natives of this country be persuaded to see their folly in plundering vessels? The rain and wind raged mightily; the Captain blew the fog horn, which alarmed the natives that something was wrong. Immediately it was known to them that a vessel had come on shore, they thronged along the beach and began plundering the gin and palm kernels that were on board. The vessel became wrecked at five o'clock a.m., when the cases of gin and palm kernels were all afloat upon the surface of the water. How long will it be before these things have an end?—I am, dear Sir, yours truly,"}, {'id': 5561, 'article_title': 'The Inquiry into the Loss of the Steamer Senegal', 'full_section_title': 'The Inquiry into the Loss of the Steamer Senegal', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1887#article-5', 'issue_date': '01_08_1887', 'content': "An inquiry instituted by the Board of Trade into the circumstances attending the stranding, on the West Coast of Africa, on June 2, of the mail steamship Senegal, was commenced at St. George's Hall, Liverpool, on July 13, before Mr. Raffles, stipendiary magistrate, with Captains Castle and Hore as nautical assessors. Mr. Fell conducted the inquiry on behalf of the Board of Trade; Mr. Bateson represented the African Steamship Company; Mr. Dickinson appeared for Captain Charles Brown, the master, and Mr. Thornely for Charles Maxwell Jacob, the second officer, who was in charge of the steamer when she struck.

Mr. Fell said the Senegal was built in Glasgow in 1872, and was of about 1,100 tons register, with engines of 275 horsepower. She left Grand Bareby on June 1st, bound for the usual ports along the coast, and about one o'clock on the following morning she struck upon a rock near Tabon Point. She had a crew of thirty-six, and was carrying twelve saloon and eight deck passengers. She had a cargo of about 1,000 tons, consisting principally of palm oil. She seemed to have been well found, and two of her six boats were life-boats. At ten p.m. on the 1st, the wind was blowing moderately and the sea was calm. According to some of the witnesses the atmosphere was clear, and according to others it was hazy. At all events, land could be seen a mile and a half off, and was visible at 12.45. The captain went to his room at ten o'clock, leaving the third officer in charge, and the latter was afterwards relieved by the second officer, whose orders were to keep the land in sight and to haul off if he got too near, and to keep sounding every fifteen minutes. This was done, and the last cast of the lead showed fifteen fathoms. Shortly afterwards the vessel struck, and towards morning she broke loose from the rock and drifted on to the beach, where nothing could be done for her. Eventually the natives came on board and plundered her of everything they could."}, {'id': 5561, 'article_title': 'The Inquiry into the Loss of the Steamer Senegal', 'full_section_title': 'The Inquiry into the Loss of the Steamer Senegal', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1887#article-5', 'issue_date': '01_08_1887', 'content': "The Court, in giving judgment, found that a safe and proper course was set and steered after leaving Devil's Rock, but it was not made good. Proper measures were not taken to ascertain and verify the position of the vessel at ten p.m. on the 1st June. The Court was of opinion that as cross bearings could not be taken, and as the currents in the locality are strong and variable, the engines should have been stopped and correct soundings taken, which would have shown the master that the vessel was much nearer the land than the position given by dead reckoning, and, in consequence, that the alteration made in the course was not a safe and proper one. The master allowed one knot per hour for currents, which at the time he thought sufficient, but the result showed that he had not made sufficient allowance. A sufficiently satisfactory cast might have been obtained with a 28lb. lead to have warned the officer in charge that he was running into danger, supposing the lead to have been properly used. The second officer, when he took charge, assumed, as he might fairly do, that the ship was in a proper position, but at 12.30 a.m., finding that the course the ship was then steering would take him too close to the land, he altered it a point to the southward, which was so far good, but not sufficient, and it was undoubtedly then his duty to have reported the alteration to the master. The Court thought that the master might certainly have visited the bridge more frequently than he appeared to have done during the night. A look-out was properly placed on the forecastle, and the officer was on the bridge. The look-out man saw the trees and the surf, but did not report them. In his evidence the second officer said he did not see them. The stranding of this vessel was caused by the courses set not having been made good by the lead not having been properly used. The Court was of opinion that the master and the second officer were both to blame in respect to the navigation—the master for not having ascertained his exact position at 10.30 p.m., when he altered the course, and the second officer for not having called the master at 12.30 a.m., when he altered the course again—but the Court, taking into consideration the antecedents of both officers for a long time in the same employ, contented themselves on this occasion with a reprimand."}]

[{'document_title': 'A British Man-of-War Ordered to Tabou', 'section_title': '', 'content': "The British and African Steam Navigation Company's royal mail steamer Lagos (captain, J. Clancy) recently arrived in the Mersey from the West Coast of Africa, with mails and passengers. Her Majesty's ship Royalist was lying at Lagos when she left, and had received orders to proceed to Tabou, on the Kroo coast, for the purpose of inquiring into the conduct of the natives when the mail steamer Senegal was wrecked there last month. The instructions were sent to the Royalist by cable, so that no time would be lost in chastising the natives for their hostile conduct to the crew and passengers of the wrecked vessel. There is but one factory at Tabou, and it is stated that the plundering of the cargo and passengers' effects, as well as the threatening of the lives of those on board the Senegal, was done by the natives living in the bush. The occupants of the trading factory, which is owned by Mr. Julio, a European, gave the shipwrecked people refuge on their premises, and their conduct was in strong contrast to that of the bush people. The latest report from the Senegal was that she was breaking up. It was felt that the visit of the Royalist would have a salutary effect, particularly as the British war vessels are said to have been somewhat apathetic in interfering where it was thought British interests were menaced; whilst, on the other hand, the French and Germans have been very energetic in respect of the concerns of their own countrymen. The Acorn, a smaller gunboat, received the first instruction to visit Tabou. She was then lying at Bathurst. These were, however, countermanded, and given to the larger vessel—the Royalist—which is looked upon as an indication that the authorities are determined to deal smartly and decisively with the natives for their hostility.", 'last_edit_date': '1887-08-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1887#article-6', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.672, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The West Coast of Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The steamer Roquelle, of the British and African Company, lately arrived at Liverpool from West Africa with mails and passengers. She brings news from Brass, where it is feared the absence of the British Consul may lead to some serious conflicts. The steamer left on the 6th September; a few days previous to which, the natives came down the river in great force, and compelled the traders to sign an agreement not to take any of their steam launches up the Brass river. Limits were marked beyond which the launches were not to go. The British Consuls have been absent from the coast for some time, and the traders themselves sent for a gunboat to be despatched to the Brass river, in order that the difference might be adjusted, and, if possible, a serious disturbance avoided. One of the traders, who the natives alleged had gone beyond the limits, was fined by the natives. The barque Benedicta was lost on Akassa Bar on the 4th September. The crew escaped to the shore, where they were held by a native chief, and not released until a ransom had been paid for them. News from Whydah announces the annexation of that place by the Portuguese. A man-of-war went specially to Whydah, and afterwards took away, it is reported, 1,200 slaves belonging to the King of Dahomey. The slaves, it is stated, go under an agreement to work in the plantation at St. Thomé, an island on the south-west coast, belonging to the Portuguese. It was not stated that the men were slaves to the Portuguese authorities, but merely that they had previously been slaves belonging to the King of Dahomey, with whom the Portuguese authorities entered into an agreement for the removal of the men from Dahomey to St. Thomé.

Our readers will find upon another page some further particulars in reference to the part which is being taken by the Portuguese authorities in support of the slave trade. A recent despatch has it that the whole kingdom of Dahomey has been placed under the "protection" of Portugal!', 'last_edit_date': '1885-11-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_11_1885#article-12', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.66, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'A Visit to an African King', 'section_title': '', 'content': "The British and African Steam Navigation Company's Royal mail steamer Opobo arrived on Aug. 25 from the West Coast with mails and passengers. The Opobo left Tabou on the 4th ult., and reports that Her Majesty's gunboat Icarus had visited the scene of the wreck of the mail steamer Senegal to inquire into the conduct of the natives who plundered the vessel and molested the passengers and crew. It appears that there is only one trading factory at Tabou, which is owned by a white man named Fitzwilliam Julio. This gentleman was absent when the Senegal was wrecked, but soon afterwards returned to the coast and called together the chiefs of the bush people, who had plundered the cargo and passengers. Mr. Julio held a palaver of a week's duration, and informed the natives of the serious nature of their conduct, and also that a British war vessel had been ordered to make inquiries, if not to burn down their villages. Mr. Julio managed to collect from the natives a number of documents belonging to the Senegal, and also a portion of the mails, but many had been destroyed by the natives, who were not aware of their value. The Icarus subsequently arrived, and, aided by Mr. Julio, the captain at once set about an investigation of the matter, a report of which will be submitted to the home authorities in due course. The captain evidently had no instructions to punish the natives; at all events, nothing was done by the Icarus to them. Tabou is an independent country, contiguous to the Liberian territory. The territory, however, is claimed by the Liberians, although the chiefs state they have documents which prove its independence. Reports had been made by the Liberian authorities to the captain of the Icarus that dynamite and other dangerous explosives had been imported into Tabou by Mr. Julio and his agents in order to incite the people of Tabou and Cavally against the neighbouring territory of Liberia. This matter was also investigated by the captain of the Icarus, and was found to be groundless, so far as the importation of dynamite was concerned, and the inciting of the natives to war. Cargo of so dangerous a nature as dynamite is not carried by the English steamers, and consequently could not be imported. It was also shown that the natives were desirous of living peaceably, so long as no designs were made upon their territory, or any attempt made by the Liberians to assume authority over it and impose duties. The wreck of the Senegal had entirely disappeared, owing to the action of the current where she stranded, and nothing can now be seen of her. It was three miles from Tabou where the Senegal was lost, and it was the natives who live in the bush that came down to the wreck to plunder the cargo.", 'last_edit_date': '1887-09-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1887#article-4', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.667, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African Times.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'At the present time, from all parts of the West African coast, we have reports of troubles and disturbances, which must hamper trade and retard the commercial and civilising development of that part of the Dark Continent. For some months now the trade of Lagos has been blocked by the closing of the roads which, running through the district inhabited by the Jebu and Egba tribes, connect that port with the interior; but we are pleased to learn, from the latest telegrams received, that the careful and earnest steps that are being taken by the authorities to secure the opening of these trade routes, have not been without their moral effect upon the tribes implicated, for they are already making overtures of peace and reconciliation. It is much to be hoped that this is the case, for at the present time trade needs fostering on the West Coast more than perhaps ever before, and this object can only be attained by the cheerful co-operation of all interested in its maintenance. The British administration in West Africa has been by no means free from faults in the past; and these faults have born their natural fruit. The secret of good Colonial government would seem to consist in interfering as little as possible with Native customs and prejudices, but at the same time making it thoroughly understood that laws and ordinances must be respected. Now that the dispute with the Jebus and Egbas would seem to be in a fair way of settlement, it affords an opportunity to the Governor of Lagos to insure that, though these tribes are to be treated fairly and with patience, they must quite understand that any infraction of the engagements now or subsequently undertaken by them, will be visited most severely upon the offenders.

But the troubles in this part of the world are by no means confined to the British. It appears that the French have been forced into a war with Dahomey, the only...

[MAY 2, 1892.', 'last_edit_date': '1892-05-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_05_1892#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.683, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'BRITISH WEST AFRICA AND THE TRADE OF THE INTERIOR.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The trading operations of Europeans in West Africa are carried on after the following manner: The trader selects a site suitable—generally by the side of a river or creek, or along the seashore—and comes to terms with the owner of the soil or the native chief of the district for the leasing of the land, the natives retaining a dislike to alienating any part of their country. All these trading establishments are constructed mainly of corrugated iron, with iron framework, though the interior may be lined with timber. The houses are well built, well ventilated, and comfortably furnished, and have all the appearance of a bright, pleasant home. With every trading colony of any size—that is to say, where there are more than three or four trading houses—there is a medical officer, jointly paid by the various firms.

Perhaps in no body of Englishmen abroad has such an improvement taken place as in the class of men who now conduct the trade with the natives in West Africa. In former times we had the unscrupulous scoundrels and pirates who carried on the slave trade between West Africa and America. To them succeeded the scarcely more polished "palm oil ruffians"—the masters and crews of the sailing vessels which would anchor for about a year in some one of the Oil Rivers, fill up their ships with native produce, and then sail away again. The conduct of the masters and seamen of these trading vessels was often outrageous. The way in which those earlier traders treated the natives was simply regulated by the power of the natives to avenge ill-treatment. With the missionaries it can be imagined how these ruffians came in conflict; and so angry were they at the prospect of the missionaries protecting their victims, or interfering with them, that they bribed and frightened the native chiefs, and used every effort to prevent the missionaries obtaining any hold on the country. The increase of steam navigation, and consequent supplanting of these sailing-vessel voyages; the more permanent settlement of European merchants on shore, where they began to build houses; the establishment and growing influence of various forms of administrative Government; and, it may also be said, the spread of civilisation, refinement, and sobriety among the seafaring class generally, brought about a better state of affairs in the trading colonies of West Africa. Yearly the improvement continues; more and more the great trading companies of Liverpool and Bristol have realised that their interests are better served by men of good manners and refinement.', 'last_edit_date': '1889-02-04', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_02_1889#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.665, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'WEST COAST OF AFRICA', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Intestine wars had broken out amongst the natives in the Mellicourie country, near Sierra Leone, and several European factories had been destroyed and plundered. The authorities at Sierra Leone were adopting measures to punish the marauders and obtain reparation for the losses sustained by British subjects during the disturbance. Trade was very inactive, and in consequence of heavy rains sickness was rather prevalent amongst Europeans. The ships Advance, Day Spring, and Ellerslie were in port.

At Bathurst the health was very good, but the trade was dull. The barque Le Grace, of Marseilles, was in port.', 'last_edit_date': '1865-07-22', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/22_07_1865#article-0', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.705, 'probability_score': 0.069, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE AFRICAN "MIDDLEMAN" AND OTHER HINDRANCES TO TRADE.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The populations seen in the towns on the river banks must not be taken as a proof that the parts not visited are equally populous; and we must remember that the negro, when first he becomes acquainted with the fabrics of the looms of Europe, does immediately array himself in fathom upon fathom of calico. We must also take into consideration that the merchants of other nations are seeking for new markets with as much avidity as we are, and that the manufacturers of Mulhausen and other foreign towns will meet the products of our looms on a footing of equality. Another question which has to be overcome in the Upper Congo is the difficulty and cost of transport between Vivi and Stanley Pool. The American officers sent to report on the advantages to the trade of the United States to be expected from the opening up of the Congo, say that on this section there was famine and disease, and that even the employés of the International Association were suffering from these causes, and that transport was both scarce and costly.

Until some better route is opened up, the trade of the Upper Congo can only be tentatively opened, as it is doubtful if ivory even will be able to stand the great cost of carriage. The trade on the Lower Congo is rapidly increasing in value and importance; but some disastrous ventures have been made, and investors have been deterred from joining in enterprises for its development on account of some businesses which have not realized the prospects held out by their promoters. The Dutch are the largest traders in the Lower Congo, and the slave trade continued longer there than in any other place on the West Coast; and even after it was put a stop to, many of those who had been engaged in it remained, and brought into more legitimate trade the lawless habits they had acquired in their previous avocation; and the native inhabitants of the creeks and shores of the stream were lawless and fierce, and not unfrequently indulged in piracy. The expedition under Sir William Hewett, in 1875, put a great check on their practices, and since then both English and Portuguese men-of-war have chastised breaches of law and order, but some of the worst offenders amongst the Europeans managed to escape the punishment they merited.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1885#article-10', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.661, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'TRADE IN BRITISH WEST AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Now that the Germans have followed the English and French for purposes of trade into the waterways of Guinea, British merchants will be sure to pay greater attention to these river basins as providing outlets for the disposal of their goods in increased quantities. In this they will be assisted by the English-speaking negro traders, who, travelling from Sierra Leone, Bathurst, and Lagos, have had so much to do in introducing English goods into the interior. While land carriage remains difficult and expensive, on account of the want of proper vehicles, roads, and beasts of burden, the rivers and lagoons will continue to be used wherever practicable by the canoes and small schooners which, with a few steamers on the Niger, have up to the present time conveyed European goods from the coast. With the spread of Christianity and civilization will come better means of transit.

For many years a continually increasing trade has been secured by the merchants and African trading companies, whose palm oil, ground nut, and other stations extend along the coast into the delta of the Niger, and thence into the Nupe country. But little difficulty usually marks the voyage of the British vessel, and in most cases the landing of the goods is safely accomplished. It is the negro trader who receives, as a sort of middleman, the European merchandise which he has to sell on the spot, or transfer into the interior, who has to encounter a host of difficulties arising from the barbarous character of the country and the tribal jealousies which prevail. Hence, rather than encounter the danger of loss through the absurd country customs characteristic of many parts, the exacting demands made by petty chieftains in others, and the physical difficulties on land and water, the English-speaking negro confines his commercial operations to those rivers where he is tolerably sure of securing protection, because of treaties made between the English colonial governors and the native chieftains. If he goes beyond treaty ground, as he sometimes does, he may encounter loss, as the colonial authority is powerless to secure compensation without the exhibition of force. The colonial trader living beyond the English territorial boundaries connects the British merchant with the inland caravan traffic. These caravans bring various articles of African produce to exchange for European commodities from the coast.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-08-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1885#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.676, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Voyage of the Raleigh', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'There is a lesson to be learnt from this case, and what has lately happened to the German East African Company in Zanzibar. In both cases the Arab traders were the instigators, though in the latter case they seem to have had matters simplified for them by the action of the German East African and Imperial authorities. If it be true that the German ships have occasionally been guilty of promiscuously shelling the coast, "simply to overawe the natives," we can hardly wonder at the influence obtained by these Arab traders. In the ordinary way there is not much reason for this alliance between the natives and the Arabs—as the intercourse of the latter is generally confined to kidnapping and enslaving the former. But the presence of a common enemy is sure to drive them into alliance together. And let us remember the native mind does not grasp the difference between one European power and another. It is not in the interests of the Arab to enlighten them—on the contrary, it is clearly to his advantage to persuade them that all Europeans are bent upon their destruction. The Arab influence in East Africa is already immense. The chief obstacle to its further development lies in the hostility of the native tribes, who have trusted Europeans in preference, because they found that these have been just and considerate; but according to latest accounts, the Germans seem bent upon changing all this, and forcing the natives to make common cause with the Arabs. Their efforts at peaceful colonisation will surely fail in exact proportion to their success in this enterprise.', 'last_edit_date': '1889-03-04', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_03_1889#article-10', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.672, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Some Minor Trading Stations on the West Coast of Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We may now take up the consideration of another portion of Africa, one which till lately was considered as being peculiarly under British influence, and as places where British trade need fear no competition—the Oil Rivers. Unfortunately, the traders and merchants considered that the independence of the chiefs was more for their benefit than the establishment of British rule; that the influence of the British Consul, backed up by an occasional gunboat, was sufficient to prevent any serious difficulties; and that the treaties with the chiefs secured trade on profitable and equitable terms.

Under the old régime large fortunes were made, but competition has now much reduced the profits, while German and French annexations have closed some districts to Englishmen and seriously injured their interests in others. In the days that were gone, the courts of equity, formed of the principal merchants, used, with the assistance of the British Consul or the captain of a man-of-war, to smooth all local disputes, settle prices, and generally make regulations for the conduct of trade. Whilst all the merchants were English this system acted very well, although no doubt at times considerable difficulties arose.

Foreign competition has sprung up now to a very considerable extent, most of it being in the hands of Germans, and the way that the trade has passed into their hands is not creditable to the foresight or patriotism of English merchants. Even when trade was conducted at more remunerative rates than at present, the scale of pay to clerks and subordinates was not sufficiently high to induce men of education and standing to face the risks of the African climate, and separate themselves from their families and the comforts of civilization for lengthened periods; and in consequence, among those who went to the coast, there were some men whose ideas of commercial morality were at a very low ebb.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-11-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_11_1885#article-19', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.663, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'MR. JOSEPH THOMSON ON EUROPEAN INTERCOURSE WITH AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Having glanced at African exploration during the past 400 years, the lecturer proceeded to inquire what had been the net outcome of direct and indirect efforts and sacrifices and intercourse between the European and the African. He knew that the impression they had acquired from various sources was that the beneficent results were enormous; but he had been enabled to see for himself the nature of those results and to draw his own conclusions, and he appeared before them to put a pin into the beautiful iridescent bubble which they had blown for themselves with the materials supplied by the ignorant, the interested, the colour-blind, and the hopelessly biassed. Taking a bird's-eye view of the whole situation in time and space, so that each factor might assume its proper relative position and proportion, he unhesitatingly affirmed in the plainest language that so far their intercourse with African races, instead of being a blessing, had been little better than an unmitigated curse to them. These were strong statements, they would say, and required confirmation. If true, what could possibly have caused this frightful miscarriage of the noblest aspirations of a Christian people? The answer was simply the nature of their commerce with Africa in the past and present. To the slave and gin trades, and that in gunpowder and guns, must he ascribed the frightful evils they had brought upon the negro race, beside which the good they had tried to achieve was hardly discernible.", 'last_edit_date': '1890-01-11', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1890#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.663, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE WEST COAST OF AFRICA', 'section_title': '', 'content': "The West African steam ship Athenian arrived at Liverpool on Saturday, Sept. 10; from Benin, July 26; Fernando Po, July 31; Cameroons, August 3; Old Calabar, August 2; Brass River, August 4; Bonny, August 7; Lagos, August 10; Cape Coast Castle, August 14; Sierra Leone, August 22; Bathurst, August 25; Teneriffe, August 31; and Madeira, September 2. She brought 676 ounces of gold dust.

Very little trade was doing at Benin; the river was healthy. The Commodore of the English fleet on the West Coast was expected daily to blockade the river, to enforce payment of the fine imposed upon the natives some time ago for the outrage upon Dr. Henry's establishment.

Trade very dull at Fernando Po, and the small-pox prevalent amongst the natives; Europeans healthy.

At Cameroons trade was still stopped, but there was a prospect of its being shortly reopened.

The Brass River was healthy and trade pretty brisk.

At Bonny trade was lively, the price of palm-oil moderate, and the river healthy.

In the interior, at Lagos, the war amongst the natives was still raging and likely to continue. The colony was tolerably healthy, but trade very dull.", 'last_edit_date': '1864-09-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1864#article-0', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.661, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'SOUTH-WEST AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The British and African Steam Navigation Company's royal mail steamer Senegal, Captain Keene, with mails and passengers from South-west Africa, has arrived in the Mersey.

The Senegal touched at all of the ports affected by the Congo Treaty, and brings important news concerning it. The proposal to hand the territory over to the Portuguese was becoming known along the coast when the steamer left, and, although the feeling was only beginning to manifest itself then, it was seen that opposition to the Treaty would expand as the matter became more known. At Kinsembo and Ambrizette the feeling was very strong, and it was stated that here at least any attempt to carry the provisions of the Treaty into operation would be forcibly resisted. The natives could not understand the reason for such a proceeding, and could scarcely believe it until the news was confirmed by subsequent mail advices. On other parts of the coast affected, where the natives are of a quieter spirit, they stated their intention to leave their homes and go to other places rather than submit to Portuguese jurisdiction. Their experience of Portuguese jurisdiction on other parts of the coast cause them to take the step. They say the Portuguese are cruel, and punish the natives without first knowing who is in fault. If a complaint is made against them, the natives allege that the Portuguese immediately burn down their villages without a "palaver," and they say if Portugal got holding their country, they would continue this practice.

The Senegal left Gaboon on March 26. De Brazza was then up the Oqowe River. The steamer brought no news confirmatory of the alleged annexation of territory from Brazzaville to the Equator line by De Brazza. On the other hand, however, it was reported at Gaboon, which is a French settlement, that De Brazza was hemmed in up the river, and that his mission had practically failed. It was further stated that he had no goods or money with him, and that his followers had nearly all left him. The new French government of Gaboon is said to be giving much satisfaction in the administration of the colony.

As the Senegal lay at Old Calabar, a large alligator attacked a party of natives who were washing themselves in the river. The monster bit the hand off one of the natives, as well as a piece out of his side. His screams brought assistance from the Senegal, but the poor fellow was so severely injured that he died in an hour afterwards, notwithstanding that the doctor of the steamer and the resident doctor on the river did all they could for him. The alligator, which was about 20 feet long, was passed by the Senegal, but they failed to kill it.

It seems that both at Bonny and New Calabar the arrival of the English Consul was looked for with great anxiety, and it was feared that unless he soon made his appearance war might again break out. Trade in the rivers was almost at a standstill.', 'last_edit_date': '1884-05-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1884#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.67, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'LE STANLEY. A STERN-WHEEL STEAMBOAT FOR THE CONGO EXPEDITION.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The accompanying engraving illustrates "Le Stanley," a stern-wheel steamboat specially built by Messrs. Yarrow & Co., of Poplar, London, E., for the International Association, of which His Majesty the King of the Belgians is the head. Although it is some seven or eight months since this new departure in river craft was completed and dispatched for use on the great African water-way, the events of the last few weeks have brought all matters affecting the colonization of the Congo into such special prominence, that no excuse is needed for giving full particulars of the vessel in our present issue. The problem placed before Messrs. Yarrow by the Belgian authorities to construct a steamer of exceptionally shallow draught was which should be able to navigate waters where there was not sufficient depth for vessels built in the ordinary way, and one, moreover, which could be easily transported over land, so as to avoid the numerous rapids and cataracts which render continuous navigation impossible.', 'last_edit_date': '1884-11-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1884#article-11', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.662, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'LE STANLEY. A STERN-WHEEL STEAMBOAT FOR THE CONGO EXPEDITION.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The solution of this problem is to be found in Le Stanley, which consists of six oblong pontoons of galvanized steel, 18 ft. long by 8 ft. 6 in. wide, and 4 ft. deep. These pontoons, which form sections of the vessel, and each of which is water-tight and therefore floatable in itself, are placed side by side and fastened together, and to them is added a bow-piece and a stern-piece. The whole forms a hull 70 ft. long by 18 ft. beam. The sections are so bolted together that they can be readily disunited and as readily put together again. On the bow division are placed two steam boilers of the locomotive type, and capable of working up to 150 lb. per square inch. The boilers have very capacious fire grates for burning wood, which will, of course, be the only fuel procurable. On the stern division are the engines, which are designed for a working pressure of 140 lb. per square inch. There are two cylinders, one on either side of the vessel, each 10½ in. diameter and 2 ft. 6 in. stroke. The piston rod of each cylinder is connected with a crank shaft, carrying a stern paddle-wheel 10 ft. diameter and 12 ft. breast, and placed well aft of the vessel. The strains on the boat which arise from these weights being placed at either end, are taken by a system of light steel tie-rods, by means of which the whole of the vessel is well braced. The ship is fitted with a pair of balanced rudders, and is steered from a bridge placed well forward and about 12 ft. above the water, giving the steersman a good view all round. Above the main deck, and completely covering it, will be found a wooden awning deck, which in an African climate will be necessary to protect the passengers and crew from the sun. On the main deck is a small, well-ventilated saloon. On the occasion of the preliminary trial recently a number of engineers and scientific gentlemen were present. The vessel was put through several interesting manoeuvres, the most striking of which was rapid turning, for which Le Stanley showed remarkable aptitude, indicating great steering capabilities which render her admirably suited for tortuous and winding rivers. Her mean draught was 14 in. in working trim, and, with a steam pressure of 100 lb. per square inch, a speed of from nine and a half to ten miles per hour was obtained.

The hindrances hitherto experienced in the development of trade with Africa have been due in a great measure to the practical difficulties met with in placing vessels of light draught on the rivers. These difficulties would now appear to have been overcome, and the question of continuous transport to be practically solved.', 'last_edit_date': '1884-11-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1884#article-11', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.675, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}]

hh: Commodore Wilmot's visit to Dahomey was a strategic diplomatic mission aimed at showcasing British naval power and influence, potentially preventing immediate military action and fostering favorable relations with the King.
result: The claim that Commodore Wilmot's visit to Dahomey was a strategic diplomatic mission aimed at showcasing British naval power and influence is supported by observations from both the "General History of Africa" textbook and The African Times news articles, albeit with varying degrees of specificity. The textbook does not specifically mention Wilmot's visit but provides a broader context of British diplomatic and military strategies in West Africa, highlighting the use of naval power to negotiate favorable conditions for trade and political influence, as seen in British actions in Lagos and Porto Novo. This aligns with the general idea of using naval power as a diplomatic tool, including tactics like 'divide and conquer' and gunboat diplomacy. The African Times articles, on the other hand, offer direct support for the claim by detailing how Commodore Wilmot's visit was received with great interest by the King of Dahomey, particularly when shown the ship's engines and an Armstrong gun, indicating a display of British naval power. The articles also note Wilmot's diplomatic mission to persuade the King to abandon the slave trade and consider peaceful relations, further suggesting an attempt to foster favorable relations. However, they also highlight challenges, such as the King's reluctance to make a treaty and his ongoing military expeditions, complicating the narrative of preventing immediate military action. Together, these sources provide a nuanced understanding of Wilmot's visit, emphasizing both the diplomatic and influential aspects while acknowledging the complexities involved.

[{'document_title': 'Dahomey, Yorubaland, Borgu and Benin in the nineteenth century', 'section_title': 'The growth of European interest', 'content': 'The events that marked the real turning point, however, were the formal annexation of Lagos to the British Crown in 1861 and a British naval action against Porto Novo later the same year.$^{34}$ These two British actions naturally sensitized the French, who had considerable commercial interests in Whydah and Porto Novo. Further west, suspicion of British political intentions grew in 1851 when Lagos was bombarded by the anti-slave trade squadron.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.655, 'probability_score': 0.052, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Niger delta and the Cameroon region', 'section_title': 'The Niger delta > The eastern delta', 'content': "The decision to abolish the slave trade by Britain in 1807 was an important factor for change. Efforts to effect stoppage of the trade led to new activities by British traders, consuls, and naval officers, resulting in new relationships with the delta states. First, it led to an increased British presence in the Bight of Bonny. For the delta states, these developments meant the demonstration of British power in their waters, bringing the era of gunboat diplomacy in which the British consuls used naval power to negotiate favourable conditions for British traders, missionaries, and explorers. These courts were, naturally, under the control of the British, and not of the local rulers.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.602, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The abolition of the slave trade', 'section_title': 'Protecting new trade', 'content': "Unlike the Roman Catholic ones, the Protestant missions sought tem› poral influence. They spread arithmetic and spoken and written English among people who had long been self-taught. Specialists came from Sierra Leone to teach architecture, printing and medicine.
