The indunas returned with royal greetings but no repudiation. Rhodes obtained his monopolist royal charter to colonize the area. In early 1890 his pioneers marched from South Africa, through Matabeleland into Mashonaland and hoisted the Union Jack at Salisbury on 12 September 1890.
From September 1890 to October 1893 the Ndebele nation and settler colony of Mashonaland kept a wary eye on each other. As had happened between the settlers and the Xhosa in the Cape as well as the settlers and the Zulu in Natal, it was a matter of time before the inevitable military showdown occurred.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.63, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The British, Boers and Africans in South Africa, 1850-80', 'section_title': 'British withdrawal from the interior', 'content': "With the Transvaal out of the way, the commissioners turned their attention to the Orange River Sovereignty. However, Cathcart, the new High Commissioner, wanted to patch up British military prestige, which lay in tatters in the eyes of the Africans, by striking a telling blow to Moshoeshoe's kingdom. With a large force of infantry and cavalry, he met Moshoeshoe at Platberg on 15 December 1852 and delivered an ultimatum that was impossible to fulfil. Moshoeshoe was ordered to produce within three days 1000 horses and 10 000 cattle, which would be used as com› pensation for the Boer property lost during the Warden war and also to finance Cathcart's own current expensive expedition. When Moshoeshoe failed to meet the deadline and pleaded for more time, Cathcart ignored the King's excuses and ordered an invasion of what is today Lesotho. But he met with such stiff resistance from the Lesotho infantry and cavalry that he was only too willing and relieved to withdraw when Moshoeshoe displayed a diplomatically submissive posture in a letter dated 20 December 1852. Moshoeshoe beseeched the High Commissioner to be content with the loot of over 5000 cattle which the Governor's troops had managed to capture. The King confessed himself sufficiently punished and indeed well impressed by the power of the British and therefore begged for peace. He would also in future try to prevent his people from causing disorder. On receipt of the letter the following day, the Governor with his mauled army (thirty-eight dead and fifteen wounded) quickly pulled out of the dangerous kingdom. 5
Cathcart's experience of the Sovereignty quagmire added to the British conviction that the region could only be retained at a high cost. Sir George Clerk was therefore sent out to go and complete the British withdrawal from north of the Orange river. Getting wind of the impending British departure, Moshoeshoe prepared for the certain long struggle ahead with the Boers by destroying their potential allies, the Tlokwa, Griqua, and Kora in the north-west of his kingdom. All the southern Sotho around his kingdom now fell under his rule, except Moroka's chiefdom, whose population had been whittled down anyway to only 1000 people during the previous war.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.63, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The British, Boers and Africans in South Africa, 1850-80', 'section_title': 'British expansion in South Africa 1870-80', 'content': "It was quite clear to the British government, which was also impressed by the arguments of the Anglican Bishop, John William Colenso, the only stout defender of the Hlubi chief, that injustices done to the Hlubi were the result of the excessive dread of the blacks held by the whites. Actual contacts made by Langalibalele with the Sotho, Ndebele, and Zulu before the rising, or rumours of them, further raised the spectre of a general African uprising against the balkanized whites in South Africa. Advised by Shepstone and others, Lord Carnarvon saw federation as the only answer to the 'terrible labyrinth' of South Africa. 33 As a first step, Lord Carnarvon secured the appointment of Sir Garnet Wolseley, recently returned from Kumasi where he had defeated the Asante, to deal with the Natal difficulties. Wolseley was instructed to gain control of African affairs for the Crown and to delay responsible government for the whites in preparation for a South African federation.$^{34}$ Since peaceful approaches would be pursued, Carnarvon became conciliatory to the Boers by dangling a settlement of the diamond fields disputes. In 1875 he proposed a conference of the colonies and republics where minor issues such as a common African policy and territorial misunderstandings would be discussed as a prelude to the main issue of confederation. The mistake Carnarvon made was to suggest the names of the delegates and, in fact, he blundered gravely when he appeared to support the division of the Cape Colony by inviting the secessionist and leader of the opposition, John Paterson, as representative of the easterners and the Prime Minister, John Charles Molteno, as representative of the westerners. The result was that the Cape Colony and the republics, which were still aggrieved at the loss of the diamond fields, refused to participate, leaving Natal and Griqualand West as the only willing ones.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.632, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Mfecane and the rise of new African states', 'section_title': 'The Sotho', 'content': "The 1830s saw the intensification of Boer encroachment on Sothooccupied territory. This reached its peak after 1836, the year of the Boer exodus commonly referred to as 'The Great Trek'. Numerous clashes ensued between the encroaching Boer and dispossessed Basotho farmers. While some of the conflicts were the result of disputes over land, others were the result of counter-claims to cattle ownership, and differences over labour questions. The frequency and the growing intensity of these conflicts drew forth the reluctant intervention of the British government which, after attempting two abortive solutions,$^{82}$ threw in the sponge by recognizing an independent Boer republic in the heart of Moshoeshoe's country. To add insult to injury, the Bloemfontein Convention, by which Great Britain legitimized Boer expropriation of Sotho territory, included as one of its provisions an article that banned the sale of arms and ammunition to the Basotho and other black states while the Boers themselves could freely purchase such requirements.
It is therefore hardly surprising that the Orange Free State republic embarked upon an aggressive expansionist foreign policy that threatened to undo all the work of Moshoeshoe and, in its desperate bid to reach the sea at Port St Johns,$^{83}$ annihilate the very kingdom of Lesotho. The Basotho had to fight two wars in 1858 and 1865 against the Orange Free State before their country was taken over on behalf of Her Majesty's Government by Governor Wodehouse.
Moshoeshoe's plea for the annexation of his country by the Queen's government was a defensive move in the preservation of the nation that he had worked so hard to build. It was done to prevent the incorporation of his kingdom into the Boer republic of the Orange Free State. By the time Moshoeshoe died in March 1870 he had not only saved his kingdom from disintegration, he had also created the basis for an independent state that has survived to the present.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.646, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Africa and the colonial challenge', 'section_title': 'The state of African preparedness', 'content': 'And as will be seen in many of the following chapters, religion was indeed one of the weapons used against colonialism. Moreover, many African rulers had been able to build empires of varying size only a couple of decades back, and some were still in the process of expanding or reviving their kingdoms. Many of them had been able to defend their sovereignties with the support of their people using traditional weapons and tactics. Some of them, like Samori Ture of the Mandinka empire in West Africa, and Menelik of Ethiopia, had even been able to modernize their armies. Because of this, the African rulers saw no reason why they could not maintain their sovereignty at that time. Furthermore, some thought they could stave off the invaders through diplomacy. As we shall see below, in 1889, while Cecil Rhodes was preparing to occupy the land of the Ndebele, their king, Lobengula, dispatched a delegation to London to see Queen Victoria; and while the British invading army was marching towards Kumasi in 1896 to seize Prempeh five years after he had turned down the British offer of protection, he dispatched a powerful diplomatic mission to Queen Victoria. As seen above, Menelik addressed a similar appeal to the same monarch as well as to other European heads of state.
It is also obvious from some of the quotations above that many African rulers did in fact welcome the new changes that were steadily being intro› duced from the third decade of the nineteenth century since these changes had hitherto posed no threat to their sovereignty and independence. In West Africa, for instance, thanks to the activities of the missionaries, Fourah Bay College had been founded as early as 1827 in Sierra Leone, while elementary schools and a secondary school each in the Gold Coast and Nigeria had been established by the 1870s. Indeed, a call for the establish› ment of a university in West Africa by the Caribbean-born pan-Africanist, Edward Wilmot Blyden had already gone out. As early as 1887 some of the wealthy Africans had even begun to send their children to Europe for further education and professional training and some of them had returned to the Gold Coast as fully qualified barristers and doctors.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.641, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The British, Boers and Africans in South Africa, 1850-80', 'section_title': 'British expansion in South Africa 1870-80', 'content': 'To the Sotho, guns had considerable social, political and economic significance. The guns were bought with wages earned at the diamond mines, and as such represented an enormous investment in labour. The Sotho also valued their guns because they might be used in future to defend their kingdom, as the long history of their struggle with the Orange Free State had only too clearly taught them. The possession of a gun by a man further signified the passage from childhood to adulthood among the Sotho. The Sotho also suspected that the Cape government did not fully trust them. Besides, the chiefs suspected that the Cape government wanted to weaken them so as to turn them into slaves. There were further measures that drove the Sotho into armed resistance. In 1879 the Cape Colony proposed to alienate the Qluthing district to white farmers as a punishment for its Sotho chief, Moorosi, who had recently rebelled. Such action was in complete violation of the British promises to Moshoeshoe that no part of his country would be alienated. Moreover, the Cape government also announced that the hut tax would be increased to £1. This was utterly unacceptable to the Sotho in view of the recent Cape move to appropriate £12000 from the Lesotho account to the Cape Colony.
The Sotho tried to come to an understanding with the Cape Colony by peaceful means. They protested to Sprigg when he twice came over to their country to discuss most of these issues with them; they sent petitions to the governor and the Queen of England; they sent delegates to Cape Town to go and lobby the parliamentarians, but all these efforts came to nothing.
Meanwhile power in Lesotho shifted from the king, now called Para› mount Chief, Litsie, to the chiefs. The king was getting too old and, though opposed to the disarmament and other Cape colonial measures, was extremely fearful of the adverse effects of an armed resistance that might drive out the British and expose the kingdom to the Orange Free State.
He therefore moved out of step with the popular clamour for armed struggle and called for peaceful protests. The result was that the majority supported chiefs Lerotholi, Masopha and Joel, who all vowed to oppose the Cape government measures by violence and encouraged their people to punish the supporters of the colonial administration by destroying and confiscating their property and disobeying the magistrates.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.633, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}]

[{'id': 148, 'article_title': 'GOLD COAST', 'full_section_title': 'GOLD COAST', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1863#article-3', 'issue_date': '23_05_1863', 'content': "It is not unlikely that ere this time you have received information about the pending danger which threatens this coast. We have for the last three months been anticipating what, to all intents and purposes, will prove a reality—viz., a war with the King of Ashantee. In November last, one of the captains of the King being ordered up to Comasie, on a charge of robbing what is regarded as the King's quota of gold, and being apprehensive that the issue would cost his head, escaped with eighty adherents from the kingdom of Ashantee to the coast, and claimed protection from the English Government. The King immediately sent one of his principal chieftains, with a number of sword-bearers, to request that the captain and his men should be given up. On his arrival at Cape Coast Castle a grand palaver was held, in which were present the Governor and Council, the principal merchants at Cape Coast and its vicinity, the chiefs and head men of Cape Coast, the runaway chief, as well as the King's messengers. After a long palaver, the last were unable to substantiate the charges against the man, who swore that he would rather have his head cut off before the fort gate than that he should be sent up to Comasie. After long deliberation it was unanimously agreed that the captain and his followers were not to be delivered up until the King should send down witnesses to corroborate the charges alleged against him. The King demanded that the men should be delivered up unconditionally; or, if not, the Governor must stand the consequence. During this time it was noticed that Ashantees, who came down as peaceful traders, bought almost wholly guns, powder, and lead bar, articles which are decidedly munitions of war. The chiefs in the interior got alarmed at this, and seized the articles as the men passed along their territory. Intelligence of this reached Comasie, and from that time the King gave orders to his captains to make preparations for an invasion. In the meantime the King sent to inform the Governor that he had broken the treaty with his Government, and that he (the King) was going to send down one of his captains, who was then in the interior, to show the Governor the treaty. The Governor promised, whenever that should be done, to deliver the captain up, and even escort him to the frontiers of the King of Ashantee with British soldiers. The next information that reached the coast was that a large Ashantee army had crossed the river Prah (the boundary line between the protectorate territory and the kingdom of his Majesty King Quaku Duah) towards the eastern district, and that the King of Akim had fallen back before them to get the support of the tribes on the seashore. A few days afterwards another army crossed the Prah at Assin, in a direct road to Anamaboe and Cape Coast. Most of the men on the seacoast who are able to bear arms have left for the Fantee camp, at the neighbourhood of Assin, where at least about 14,000 men are at present, waiting the movements of the Ashantees. Scouts have been sent out, and some Ashantee heads have been sent down, to corroborate the report that the Ashantees have invaded the Fantee territory. The report is just now current that pickets of the army of Ajeman, King of Western Akim, met an Ashantee pillaging band, fired at them, and wounded their leader, who was brought before the King as a prisoner. He begged hard for his life, and promised to reveal everything about the war. He was made to swear by his King's stool that all that he was about to say were facts. The information he gave was the following: The King, on hearing that the Governor refused to deliver up the men, turned out all the available force, numbering about 60,000 men. Of these, 20,000 were to form a corps of observation on the eastern district, by descending on Akim, and thus preventing the Accras, Aquamhus, and Akims from joining the Fantees, and the remaining 40,000 were to descend upon the Fantees through Assin, sweeping everything before them, until they arrive at Cape Coast and Anamaboe, both of which places they intend to sack; the victorious were then to march against the Accras. So that, perhaps before you receive this account, we might all have been massacred by these brutal Ashantees; but we are determined to give them a most hearty reception."}, {'id': 6635, 'article_title': 'The Execution of an Englishman in the Congo State', 'full_section_title': 'The Execution of an Englishman in the Congo State', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1895#article-10', 'issue_date': '01_10_1895', 'content': "In our last number, we briefly alluded to the fact that an Englishman named Stokes had been summarily hanged by the Belgian authorities early in the year, the plea being that, in spite of international arrangements and treaties, he was in the habit of supplying the Arabs with firearms and ammunition. We pointed out at the time that the British Government did not seem at all satisfied with the explanation, and insisted upon further details of the case being submitted. Accordingly, early in September, all the official documents bearing upon the execution of Mr. Stokes were forwarded by the Congo State authorities to the British Minister in Brussels, none of the papers having passed through the hands of the Belgian Government. It seems that the sentence of death was passed on Mr. Stokes on Jan. 14 at Lindi, so that the execution probably took place on the following day.

In the House of Commons, on Sept. 3, the Under-Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, in reply to Sir E. Ashmead-Bartlett, said that the official documents, which were of a voluminous nature, were only just received, and until they had been thoroughly examined it would be impossible to give a detailed answer to the hon. member's questions. They would take some time to examine and put into print. Probably they must go to the Secretary of State, who is abroad, before any announcement can be made upon them.

Pending the examination, it would be premature to pronounce judgment on the circumstances of Mr. Stokes's death. Those circumstances must remain imperfectly known until the investigation has been completed, and perhaps until it has been supplemented by further testimony. The account which has reached us from unofficial sources is certainly imperfect and perhaps misleading, but it is such as to render imperative prompt inquiry. Neither the Government nor the nation have any desire to screen their fellow-subjects from the just punishment of their crimes in any part of the world; it is, however, their duty when a British subject has been punished, and particularly punished with death, to satisfy themselves that he had a fair trial, and that his sentence did not exceed the competence of the Court. These are the points upon which information is required. It may be forthcoming, and it may be satisfactory. If it is satisfactory we may regret the stringency of the laws of the Congo State, but if it should be shown that the trial of Mr. Stokes was unfair or irregular we shall be bound to demand adequate retribution on the heads of those who wronged him."}, {'id': 6635, 'article_title': 'The Execution of an Englishman in the Congo State', 'full_section_title': 'The Execution of an Englishman in the Congo State', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1895#article-10', 'issue_date': '01_10_1895', 'content': 'Now, if these accounts are true, they seem to show that Captain Lothaire's conduct will require a good deal of explanation. In the first place, it is clear that he tried Mr. Stokes and sentenced him to death by Court-martial. The law of the Congo State, however, expressly provides that its officers shall not pass the capital sentence on any civilian without a previous trial at Boma. If this be so it seems to have been directly broken by Captain Lothaire, for Mr. Stokes could not forfeit his status as a civilian by selling rifles and ammunition to Kibonge and promising to help him against the expedition. Next, if it was competent to try Mr. Stokes by Court-martial at all, it has to be proved that the Court-martial was regularly constituted. We know, on the authority of the Belgian accounts, that Dr. Michaux protested against the execution, and, presumably, against the trial, and that two officers refused to sit upon the Court. Apparently they were the only two officers with the expedition, for, as they would not serve, Captain Lothaire called upon two non-commissioned officers to sit in their stead. The tribunal, therefore, would seem to have consisted of the commander of the expedition and two non-commissioned officers. Is that a proper tribunal to try issues of life and death? Both from a sense of discipline and from consciousness of their own unfitness to act as Judges such men would naturally defer to the opinions of the president of the tribunal. The president in this case seems to have left them in no doubt as to what those opinions were. He declared that the acts of Mr. Stokes amounted to "trahison" and to "a flagrant participation in the war against the Free State." He was equally clear as to the penalty. He pronounced these crimes worthy of death. Apparently the non-commissioned officers assented to their commandant's views upon both points, for Mr. Stokes was a dead man a few hours later. There may be a perfect justification of all that Captain Lothaire has done. It certainly looks as if the circumstances in which Mr. Stokes was arrested were highly suspicious. Kibonge was a notorious villain, and the letters, if authentic, would be a terrible evidence of complicity. But three points have to be made out to clear Captain Lothaire. He has to show, first, that he had a right to try Mr. Stokes on a capital charge at all; secondly, that the accused was guilty; and, thirdly, that he was tried by a properly-constituted Court and with due regard for regular procedure. The attempt being made in certain quarters to exempt the Congo State from liability for the acts of its officers cannot be successful in this country. That State is dependent upon the good will of the Powers, and it would commit a grave error of judgment if it sought to shirk responsibility for any blunders committed by its representatives.'}]

[{'document_title': 'BEFORE THE LAW COURTS.', 'section_title': '', 'content': '**SIERRA LEONE PROTECTORATE ORDINANCE.**—An Ordinance came into force on Jan. 1, intended for the regulation, not of Sierra Leone proper, but of the adjacent territory over which H.M. Government exercises a protectorate. The African Committee of the Manchester Chamber of Commerce call attention to certain provisions which, in their judgment, are harassing and vexatious, particularly those with regard to the £2 annual license to be required from all traders, and the clauses forbidding the gifts of spirits to Natives by Europeans.

**PREMPEH REMOVED TO SIERRA LEONE.**—Prempeh, the ex-King of Kumasi, the Queen-mother, his father, and brother, together with the war chiefs Kinos, Manpong, Offisu, and Ogean, and their followers, have been removed from Elmina Castle, where they had been confined since their arrival at the coast after the Ashanti expedition, and taken, on board the steamship Bakana, in charge of an escort of Hamsa, to Sierra Leone. Prempeh, who, at first, seemed to be somewhat alarmed at his sudden removal, soon got to be reconciled to his fate when once he was on board. The chiefs Boatin and Fuku, who were among the Ashanti Envoys in England prior to the British Expedition, left Accra by the same steamer.

**THE CONGO STATE AND THE STOKES INCIDENT.**—We learn that the Congo Government claims 150,000 francs as duty payable on ivory belonging to the murdered Mr. Stokes. As that is exactly the sum paid by the State as compensation for the assassination, Major Lothaire's villainies would not cost it a single farthing. To put a man to death without trial, and then to levy heavy duties on his property, savours more of brigandage than of the processes of civilisation. We are not surprised to learn, therefore, that "relations continue to be strained between Lord Salisbury and the Congo Administration." The Congo authorities had better beware how they trade upon the assumption that England can be affronted with impunity. They have got it into their heads that we attach very high value to the co-operation of the Dhansis expedition with our forces at Uganda. Of course, it is the interest of both Powers to stand together against the Dervishes on the Upper Nile; but that interest is not so paramount in the case of England as to necessitate submission to insult. Even if it were so there can never be real friendship between Great Britain and the Congo State until the murder of Mr. Stokes is compensated for, so far as compensation can go. To award his relations a certain sum, none too liberal, and forthwith to take it back is a mockery of justice which does not comport with British notions.', 'last_edit_date': '1897-01-04', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_01_1897#article-4', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.754, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE CONGO STATE AND THE STOKES AFFAIR', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'A despatch was received in Brussels, on Dec. 15, by the Free State Administration announcing a decisive victory by the Native troops, under Major Lothaire, over the insurgents who are responsible for the recent disturbances in the district of Luluaburg. The action took place on Oct. 18 on the right bank of the Lomami, and resulted in the complete defeat of the rebel forces, who, according to the version received by the Administration, were practically cut to pieces. As the result of Major Lothaire's victory, the mutiny may be considered as definitely stamped out. The rebels suffered enormous loss, and Major Lothaire took a very large number of prisoners. The few who escaped took refuge in the country of the chief Dibue, who assisted the insurgents. Prior to this engagement two detachments of troops, commanded respectively by Major Michaux and another Congo State officer named Swenson, had encounters with the rebels. Major Michaux was defeated, but M. Swenson routed his opponents.

Major Lothaire's victory over the rebels on the Upper Congo will doubtless prove a fortunate circumstance for him in connexion with his trial for complicity in the death of Mr. Stokes. An old colleague of Major Lothaire, who has had exceptional opportunities of studying his methods in Africa, affirms that he is one of the most capable officers in the service of the Free State, and "one of the best of the lot," apart from his ability as an officer. He is a very strong-willed man, apt at times to act before due thought, and to this defect in Lothaire's character is to be attributed his unjustifiable conduct in reference to Mr. Stokes. When the news of the murder of Mr. Stokes first became known the officials of the Free State in Brussels were anxious as far as possible to shield Major Lothaire, but subsequently, when King Leopold and his advisers found into what a serious difficulty Major Lothaire's action had landed them, a feeling of considerable irritation against him gained ground. Now, however, that he has again rendered such signal service by crushing what promised to be a most formidable rebellion in the neighbourhood of Luluabourg, he may fairly count on a revival of the old feeling that everything will be done to minimise the punishment for what, from the Free State point of view, was an error of judgment joined to an excess of zeal. In any case, it is understood that the formal charge against Major Lothaire will not be that of murder, but one of a much less serious character.', 'last_edit_date': '1896-01-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_01_1896#article-11', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.747, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Execution of an Englishman in the Congo State', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'It may be gathered from a question put by Mr. H. M. Stanley in the House of Commons that Mr. Stokes was a Protestant Irishman from Ulster, that he went out to Africa as a missionary, and that since 1879 he had acted as a trader in East Africa, and had gained great influence over the Natives. He is said also to have "established" Mwanga, a circumstance which seems to indicate that he occasionally meddled in Native politics. According to the statements of a Belgian newspaper, Mr. Stokes was in the neighbourhood of Kilunga, a village on a tributary of the Aruwimi, about the end of last year; and at the close of December Capt. Lothaire, who had left Stanley Falls with a strong party in order to attack the Arab chief Kibonge, reached the same place. On his arrival Capt. Lothaire found Kibonge already a prisoner. At the same time Capt. Lothaire received letters from a British merchant, who claimed protection for his ivory and goods, which he desired to carry towards the East Coast. This merchant was Mr. Stokes. Capt. Lothaire found amongst Kibonge's property letters from Mr. Stokes, and other letters from Mr. Stokes were also handed to him by different chiefs. In these letters Mr. Stokes informed Kibonge that he would join him against the forces of the Congo State, and made suggestions as to how the attack of the expedition should be withstood. These letters, it is stated, corroborated other information given to Captain Lothaire by several chiefs to the effect that Mr. Stokes had sold large quantities of arms and ammunition to Kibonge for use in the war against the Congo State. Captain Lothaire thereupon sent forward two of his lieutenants with orders to arrest Mr. Stokes and to confiscate his stores and ivory as prize of war. When Mr. Stokes was brought in to Kilunga he was taken before a court-martial, and it is alleged that he acknowledged the authenticity of the letters and admitted the sale of the munitions of war, and that such sale had been made for the purpose of making war upon the Congo State. The "commandant," according to this report, declared that the acts admitted by Mr. Stokes constituted "a flagrant participation in the war against the Free State which merited death." He was sentenced to be hanged and was executed on the spot. Another account holds that at the worst Captain Lothaire can only be deemed guilty of "having acted irregularly through excess of zeal." It affirms that two officers who accompanied Captain Lothaire refused to take part in the Court-martial upon Mr. Stokes; and from a third Belgian paper we learn that Dr. Michaux, who was attached to the expedition, protested against the execution; that early in the morning, after the trial, he got up and begged Captain Lothaire to tell him where the prisoner was as he desired to speak to him, and that thereupon Captain Lothaire showed him the dead body of Mr. Stokes hanging from a bamboo. It is added that Dr. Michaux repeated his protest and insisted on returning to Stanley Falls, and that Captain Lothaire gave him an escort for the journey.', 'last_edit_date': '1895-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1895#article-10', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.768, 'probability_score': 0.069, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Internal Condition of the Congo Free State', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'According to a statement made to a representative of Reuter's Agency by a missionary who has lately returned from the Congo, things must be in a very parlous state there. The substance of the statement is appended, but our readers need hardly be reminded that as the name of the missionary is not made public the account must be accepted with much caution. The whole truth, he says, regarding the situation on the Congo can never be made public by anyone who has to return there. The State officers are so far from any central control that if they heard that the missionaries, for instance, had said anything, they would retaliate by attacking the Natives round the stations, even if the white men were not themselves hurt. As to the Stokes affair. I know nothing personally of that incident. I do know Captain Lothaire, however, and therefore was not surprised. He, in common with a few other State officers who could be named, is held in special awe by the Natives. The people on the Lulanga River called him "Lofembe," meaning mist, by reason of his mysterious movements. Lothaire is by no means the worst of the Congo officers, as there are many in the State service who have a still worse reputation among the Natives. The following is a specimen of Captain Lothaire's actions. Some four years ago he arrived with some black troops at a point opposite the mission station of Eulongo. Finding the Natives had fled on hearing of his approach, he pitched his camp on an island facing the station, and sent over to the missionary asking him to use his influence to get the Natives back, and promising a three days' truce in order to hold a palaver. The missionary, supposing he was dealing with an officer and a gentleman, induced the Natives to come into the station. As soon as they did so, Lothaire and his men opened fire on them and killed a number. Naturally, the Natives attributed this treachery to the missionaries, and later, when Lothaire sent word to another mission station that he was about to visit it, the missionary warned the Natives around the station not to return if they were sent for. One important thing connected with the Stokes affair seems to have been overlooked. It is that Stokes had been robbed of a caravan worth £4,000, and it is quite likely that many of the arms found by the State officers on the Natives formed part of the booty. This being so, it is scarcely probable that the people would admit having stolen them, but would be much more likely to declare that they had got them from the British trader. This might happen in the case of any trading or mission station being looted by the Natives, as materials for purposes of shooting game, as well as for defence, are always kept in readiness, including perhaps a thousand cartridges. If these were found on the Natives the State officials might as readily declare that they had got them from the British. This does not affect the action of Captain Lothaire one way or the other, but it throws an important side light on the affair.', 'last_edit_date': '1895-11-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1895#article-16', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.777, 'probability_score': 0.07, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Internal Condition of the Congo Free State', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'An Englishman lately returned to England after some years' residence on the Congo, said with regard to the above interview: While all the cases referred have not come under my personal observation, I regret I am unable to deny the general charges of inefficiency and brutality made against the State officials. The chief object of the officers is to get rubber and ivory at any price rather than to civilise, and they make no scruples in setting one tribe against another, using the stronger as a catspaw to obtain the ivory from the weaker. Great loss of life is the result, and it is no wonder we hear at intervals of officers being massacred. In addition to the ivory in the Native villages, the river is closely watched. A canoe laden with ivory is seen coming down the river in the evening, and signals are made for the Natives to stop and bring in their goods on the usual terms—that is to say, at a much lower price than could be obtained from any independent trader. Of course, the Natives paddle away as fast as possible, whereupon they are at once fired on and either killed or compelled to bring in their ivory. Another serious matter—one which is attracting the attention of the British Government—is the wholesale recruiting by Belgian agents of British subjects in Sierra Leone, the Gold Coast, and Barbadoes. Although, as the result of representations made to the Colonial Governments concerned this is being gradually suppressed, at one time almost every ship brought a number of men who had entered into contracts with the State to act as labourers. Once in the Congo the word "travailleur" was erased, and "soldat" substituted. Comparatively few of these people ever return to the coast. They die in the interior, usually of starvation. The result of all this is that hundreds of miles of the country are desolate, and that the Natives are leaving for the French sphere.

It is only fair to say that the high officials on the coast are not wholly responsible for this, and that some slight attempt is made at Boma, for instance, to educate the children, and so forth. The interior is in a constant state of siege, and legitimate trade is stagnated. There can be no doubt that had the Congo people the power of cohesion, the Belgians would have long since been swept out of the country, and that the British and other foreigners, who are all classed as whites, would have shared a similar fate. The suspicion entertained by one tribe of another is the Belgians' only safety.', 'last_edit_date': '1895-11-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1895#article-16', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.729, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Leader', 'section_title': '', 'content': "might arise which would render communication with the Governor, stationed so far away, difficult or practically impossible, and in these cases much must be left to the discretion of the commander of the expedition. The whole detail of the circumstances is not very clear; but it would seem that Inspector Dalrymple felt himself compelled to resort to force, with the result that the natives turned against him, and treacherously shot him down—we use the word advisedly, because Mr. Dalrymple's death was not the result of warfare or even of a riot, but he was shot at from an ambuscade. So far the case is clear, and there can be few who will deny that swift punishment should be meted out to those who were concerned in the murder—if only from the necessity of showing that the person of a British officer in the execution of his duty, and that mainly in the cause of peace and civilisation, must be respected. But the punishment in this case, all must admit, was terribly excessive, and calculated to do vast injury to the British cause. When these terrible events were known, orders were given at Accra to Assistant-Inspector Akers, with a colleague, to proceed with a force of sixty-three Houssa soldiers, who pursued the people about the bush, the number slain being between 500 and 600! And the modified disapproval of this action afforded in Lord Knutsford's despatch upon the subject is not at all what we should have liked to see. No doubt there are many difficulties to be considered and allowed for, in a country and among a people who have only the merest rudiments of civilisation. But our Colonial Empire was never built up on such a policy, and something more than a milk-and-water reprimand should have been sent from Downing Street to make the officials show some decent respect for human life. Mr. Picton's motion was ultimately defeated in the House of Commons by a large majority—probably because it was felt that the discussion which arose out of it was sure to do good, perhaps even more so than a distinct vote against the Government. As to the three people who were acquitted on the charge of procuring the murder of Mr. Dalrymple, it is quite conceivable that the Governor is acting for the best in detaining them in custody, for the present at least; but we hope to hear before long that the pacification of the district is so far advanced as to permit of their discharge.", 'last_edit_date': '1889-06-03', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/03_06_1889#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.707, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Condition of the Congo State', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The heads of expeditions and the District Commissioners must specially watch that their subordinates, to whatever category they belong, employ in their dealings with Natives the tact necessary to avert the conflicts which might arise from misunderstandings or practices conflicting too roughly with the customs and usages of the Natives. They will recommend their agents to aim at raising the level of the Natives only by degrees, and will draw their serious attention to the danger of wishing to attain results too rapidly. Before coming into conflict with the Natives, they will endeavour to enter into negotiations with them, and should be animated by the conviction that it is more advantageous to obtain reparation of damage done to the State pacifically than by force of arms.

The Government does not conceal from itself that energetic repression is occasionally necessary, but it is of opinion that such repression should only be resorted to exceptionally, and only when all means of conciliation have been exhausted.

In many circumstances, pourparlers adroitly conducted and wisely prolonged will avert open hostilities. It is advisable, for instance, to have recourse to the intervention of chiefs loyal to the State and at the same time having friendly relations with the people in conflict with the authorities, in order to prevent bloodshed.

It will thus be rendered impossible for the Natives—especially those not having continuous relations with Europeans—to distrust the intentions and sentiments of the State in their regard, a distrust which must inevitably be provoked by over-hastiness in resorting to extreme measures. In any event, when recourse to force becomes unavoidable the Government should be completely and accurately informed of the motives prompting such action, and the operations should be conducted in such a way that, as far as possible, only the really guilty may be punished.', 'last_edit_date': '1896-09-18', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1896#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.703, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Critical Condition of the Congo Free State', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Mr. Murphy next proceeded to give incidents of the barbarities alleged to have been perpetrated by the State for the purpose of obtaining rubber; and observes that some radical change in government must take place before there can be any hope of prosperity. It may well be supposed that the country is in a disturbed state. The people of the district of Lake Mantumba, of Irebu, and Lokolala and all the Mobangi towns have crossed over to the French side. Going over to the French side meant that they would become homeless and hungry wanderers. Even then the State could not leave them in peace; they heard that they came over at night to their old homes to get food, and they stationed canoes and lay in wait for them, with orders to shoot all they caught, and to my knowledge they shot seven people in one night. The State is strong enough to-day to do these things because the people lack unity. They have no leaders, no common cause, and no weapons to fight. Their condition is deplorable, and needs our sympathy, as well as all that European public opinion can do to secure for them the blessings of a righteous government under which they can live in peace.

Regarding the State officers and their manner of administration, Mr. Murphy said: "The white officers do not know the language of the people they govern, and trust too much to their Native soldiers, who are, as a rule, men belonging to a hostile tribe, whose chief aim in life is to plunder. These men are sent out to fight very often without any responsible officer being with them, with the result that many cruelties are perpetrated which might have been avoided. It is impossible for the Governor at Boma—four weeks' journey from Stanley Pool, which ought to be the real seat of Government—to manage his vast and unwieldy territory, so that the commissaires and petty governors of the interior districts have almost unlimited power. The officers of the State are young and inexperienced; they do not come out as colonists to develop the country, but in order that they may receive quick promotion, the Congo decoration, and, above all, to get money.', 'last_edit_date': '1895-12-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_12_1895#article-4', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.71, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Mr. Jacob Bright, M.P., on the Congo Question', 'section_title': '', 'content': '(Hear, hear.) Whether they spoke to merchants, to travellers, to scientific men, to explorers, or anybody who had ever had relations with the Congo, they would not find one who regarded with anything but aversion the possibility of Portugal being planted in that most important region. Finally, as he had said, the Portuguese Government urged in this dispatch that there should be some civilized jurisdiction on the banks of the Congo. Well, he would not say that a civilized jurisdiction, in which the natives could have confidence, in which the merchants could have confidence, and which would produce a better state of things than now existed—he would not say that such a jurisdiction might not be desirable. It ought to be within the capacity of England and the other powers of Europe to establish such a jurisdiction if it was necessary. But the jurisdiction of Portugal would not be such a jurisdiction as he had described. In the very case he had spoken of in which the British Consul asked the Portuguese Governor to punish the murderers of the thirty negroes, after an inquiry had been held, the Consul had a belief that it was altogether unsatisfactory, and that it was not a real inquiry. And it would be easy to show that in the Portuguese Colonies of Africa deeds probably as horrible—certainly many very dreadful deeds—were perpetrated which did not meet with any adequate punishment. Some newspapers, the Times for instance—and he thought also the Manchester Guardian, the other day—leaned somewhat to the view that on some terms or other Portugal might perhaps be allowed to go to this region. What did the merchants say? They said, We would not have Portugal on any terms; we do not trust her; no kind of bargain which she might make with us would give us any kind of security. In the despatch he had spoken of, Portugal said, Of course if we go to the Congo it will be an exception; we won’t establish the tariffs, and we won’t do there as in other colonies. That was very much like an admission that her other colonies were not in a very satisfactory state. She said that if she went to the Congo her tariff should not exceed the lowest tariff that existed in any part of the world. He scarcely knew where the lowest tariff existed, but he supposed it was in Turkey. If Portugal said, We will never have a higher tariff than five per cent., or seven or eight per cent., that would give no kind of security to the merchants of these various countries. They might bind Portugal to that agreement, but what were they to do with regard to her internal government, her internal taxation, with regard to the wonderful capacity she had of obstructing and delaying every kind of commercial proceeding, however small? (Hear, hear.) The Portuguese Government said not only that they would have very low duties, but that the navigation of the river should be absolutely free. But unless the banks of a river were free, how could the river be said to be free? (Hear, hear.) Although there was considerable commerce on the Congo, it was not so great as to induce ocean steamers to go from the sea up the 115 miles of river on which they could ply without difficulty if they chose to do so. Goods were unloaded and put upon smaller vessels to go up the stream. If Portugal was planted on the Congo, with all her machinery of custom houses, and all her genius for delay, what would become of the trade represented by the goods that would have to be unloaded and reloaded in Portuguese possessions? Men who talked glibly about putting Portugal on the banks of the Congo and abolishing the sway of the native chiefs, should remember the important fact of the difference betwixt the two provinces of Zanzibar and Mozambique. Mozambique was a great province on the eastern coast of Africa, and alongside of it was Zanzibar. Zanzibar, which was under native rule, had a trade eight or ten times as large as Mozambique, which was a province of Portugal. (Hear, hear.) The British Government for half a century had exercised an influence which had kept the Congo region free, and made it impossible for Portugal to go there. He contended that the influence which had done this in the past might do it in the future; and he should have very little faith in, or admiration for, the statesmanship of England or the statesmanship of Europe, if it allowed a region so important now and so promising for the future to be blighted by passing into the possession of such a power as Portugal. (Cheers.)', 'last_edit_date': '1883-11-10', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1883#article-6', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.703, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Condition of the Congo State', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The following is the text of the decree lately issued by King Leopold constituting a commission for the protection of Natives in the Congo State:—

Leopold II., King of the Belgians, Sovereign of the Independent Congo State. On the proposal of our Secretary of State, we have decreed and do decree as follows:—

A permanent Commission is instituted charged with the protection of the Natives throughout the territory of the State. The members of this Commission will be nominated by the King-Sovereign for a term of two years, from among the representatives of philanthropic and religious associations. The following are the first nominations: Mgr. Van Ronste, Bishop of Thymbrium, Vicar Apostolic of the Vicariate of the Congo State, president; Father Van Hencxthoven, superior of the Jesuit Mission at Leopoldville; Father de Cleene, of the congregation of Scheut; William Holman Bentley, of the Baptist Missionary Society Corporation; Dr. A. Sims, of the American Baptist Missionary Union; George Grenfell, of the Baptist Missionary Society Corporation, secretary.

The members of the Commission will inform the judicial authorities of any acts of violence of which Natives may have been victims. Each member, individually, will exercise the right of protection, and will communicate directly with the Governor-General. The Commission will also advise the Government of the measures to be adopted to prevent slave-trading, to render more effective the prohibition or restriction of the sale of spirituous liquors, and to bring about gradually the disappearance of barbarous customs, such as cannibalism, human sacrifices, trial by poison, &c.

Our Secretary of State is charged with the execution of the present decree.

Given at Brussels, Sept. 18, 1896.  
LEOPOLD.

M. Michel (V. Z.) has been appointed State Inspector, charged with a mission of inspection on the Upper Congo. He will have to see that the instructions of the Government, especially those which have to do with our relations with the Natives, are carried out. He will submit a report to the King every three months on the facts and results of his inspection. He is invested with the disciplinary powers provided for in Clause 1, paragraphs a, b, c, of the decree of April 16, 1887, including the right of suspending from office any agent infringing the instructions of the superior authority. It will be his duty to apprise the judiciary of any offences brought to his knowledge.

CO-ORDINATED TEXT OF VARIOUS INSTRUCTIONS REGARDING THE RELATIONS OF THE STATE AGENTS WITH THE NATIVES.', 'last_edit_date': '1896-09-18', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1896#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.712, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Alleged Threat to Kill the Governor of Sierra Leone', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'A cablegram has been received in Liverpool on April 19th, from which it appears that a further complication has arisen between the French and the English in the neighbourhood of Sierra Leone, and the life of the English Governor is threatened. The cablegram says the Governor was stopped by the French and Konnohs at Coongeah, or Loongeah, and that they threatened to kill him. The Governor in question is Colonel F. Cardew, who sailed from Liverpool on February 28 last to take up the administration of the Sierra Leone colony in succession to Sir Francis Fleming. Colonel Cardew appears to have lost no time in going into the interior. The Konnohs are the tribe that attempted to stop the advance of the West India Regiment under the command of the late Colonel Ellis, just prior to the deplorable French and English collision. The West Indians at that time drove the Konnohs before them from place to place, and it was then thought that they had received a lesson that would have lasted them for years. It is therefore feared that they have taken courage at some action of the French, although it is scarcely believed that the French would incite them to oppose the English Governor. It is also not credited here that the threat to kill the Governor was made by the French, but must have been on the part of the Konnohs. Loongeah or Coongeah cannot be located, but there is an important town called Lungay, between Tagreer and Scarciss on the Bullon Shore in the Kaffwee-Bullon district. It is believed that Governor Cardew had not taken troops up with him on this mission, beyond his official staff and carriers, but all of the West India men have returned from Bathurst, and are at present in Sierra Leone, and would be ready for any immediate orders.

It should be added that up to the time of our going to press, the Foreign Office has received no information in support of the statement made above, that the life of Governor Cardew has been threatened, and it is maintained that if such were really the case the Home authorities would have secured some official confirmation of the report.', 'last_edit_date': '1894-04-19', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1894#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.703, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Defiance of British Authorities in the Gambia', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Sir,—I have to bring under your notice the state of things in the Gambia and the sufferings of the inhabitants therein from the natives of different lands—to wit, the Séréréas, Mandingoes, &c., and other tribes of the interior now settled here.

A brutal murder was committed on the 29th ult., on the body of one Samuel Cole, deceased, by the Séréréas. This poor Cole was a fisherman by trade; he went as usual to his work with his own canoe, and these Séréréas also, with their own, fishing together. Immediately some dispute arose between them, and this poor Cole was in the right; notwithstanding this, the Séréréas (who are so careless of the British laws) went alongside of the deceased's canoe, and killed him on the spot by sticking him with knives and spears and with large sticks. This and other like atrocities have occurred through the destitute condition of the colony; no arms or protection provided, excepting the small police force. If this continues, there will be a great mutiny here in a very short time, and the inhabitants will surely take revenge for the cause which they are suffering from, for this is not the first murder that has happened here.

I wish also to put before you, Mr. Editor, the conduct of your own countrymen here (the Europeans) who are merchants of this place. They also have set at naught the British rules, for the regulations of the Gambia are framed by them to suit their business; I except our worthy chief magistrate, Thomas Witter Jackson, Esq., who is doing nothing but justice, and with whom there is no partiality. The Europeans of this place are the members of the Legislative Councils, and the Hon. Thomas Brown alone is nominally for the colony. To show you the state of things here, there are capable men of the inhabitants of this place who are well qualified for the Council; but they were excluded from it; and the fore-named gentleman alone, even if his personal interest was not too often opposed to ours, is not sufficient for this colony, for two are far better than one in counsel or for fight.", 'last_edit_date': '1872-09-16', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_10_1872#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.705, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Anticipated Trouble in Ashanti', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Just as we are going to press, we learn through Reuter's Agency that, in consequence of the hostile action of the King of Coomassie (the old Ashanti confederation having been broken up), the Government has instructed the Governor of the Gold Coast to send Colonel Sir Francis Scott home for the purpose of consulting with the authorities as to the force required to deal with the troubles, and whether it will be necessary to despatch additional troops from England. Of course, an Ashanti war would not be anything like as large an undertaking as the expedition of twenty years ago: many who then fought against the British are now living quietly under their protection.

It appears that the King of Coomassie is alleged to have violated treaty engagements with Great Britain by the continuation of the practice of human sacrifices, as well as by hampering trade and attacking neighbouring tribes which are under British protection. There are other causes of complaint, one of which is the difficulty he has placed in the way of the appointment of a British Resident at Coomassie. Communications on these subjects have for some time been taking place between the King of Coomassie and the Governor of the Gold Coast. The former has been temporising, but there is still hope that the differences now existing may be arranged without a resort to war. It is nevertheless felt necessary to be prepared for a less favourable contingency, and with this view, as mentioned above, Sir Francis Scott, Inspector of Constabulary of the Gold Coast, has been summoned home for the purpose of conferring with the War Office about the preparations for the military expedition to Ashanti, should war prove inevitable.

Several Native envoys from Ashanti recently arrived in London with a commission from their king to negotiate with the British Government on some of the questions now at issue. These envoys were not, however, officially received or recognised by the Government; and as Ashanti is within the British sphere of influence, they were advised to make their communications through the Governor of the Gold Coast, the authorised representative of the British Government in the district to which they belong.", 'last_edit_date': '1895-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1895#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.711, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}]

hh: Governor Freeman's inability to respect local customs and his postponed visit to Abeokuta underscore the diplomatic challenges and tensions between British colonial authorities and African leaders.
result: The claim that Governor Freeman's inability to respect local customs and his postponed visit to Abeokuta underscore the diplomatic challenges and tensions between British colonial authorities and African leaders is supported by observations from both the "General History of Africa" textbook and The African Times news articles, albeit in different ways. The textbook does not specifically mention Governor Freeman or his interactions with Abeokuta, nor does it directly address any postponed visits or disrespect for local customs by him. However, it highlights broader themes of diplomatic challenges and tensions between British colonial authorities and African leaders, such as the general strategy of colonial administrators to manage relationships between traditional and new African elites, often leading to dissatisfaction and conflict. It also describes instances where African leaders, like Prempeh I of Asante and Jaja of Opobo, resisted colonial impositions, indicating a pattern of tension and resistance to colonial authority. These examples align with the claim's theme of diplomatic challenges but do not provide specific details about Freeman or Abeokuta. In contrast, The African Times articles provide specific details supporting the claim, noting that Governor Freeman's visit to Abeokuta was postponed due to the absence of key Egba leaders, reflecting a lack of coordination and respect for local customs. The articles also highlight Freeman's unsuccessful attempts to secure an interview with the chiefs of Abeokuta, suggesting strained relations and communication breakdowns. Additionally, Freeman's imposition of Calabar mats, which led to unrest, is criticized as a disregard for local conditions and customs. These details align with the claim that Freeman's actions contributed to diplomatic challenges and tensions. However, the articles also mention efforts by other British officials, like Acting Governor Glover, to improve relations, indicating that the challenges were not solely due to Freeman's actions but part of broader colonial administrative issues.
