[{'document_title': 'THE ASHANTI WAR.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'No one believed throughout the protectorate, not even the gentleman who pretends to be omnipotent with the King of Ashanti, that his Majesty ever intended delivering up his German prisoners just now; and if the 1,000l. he asked for them had been sent up—and we believe that it would have been if this same gentleman could have had his way—his Majesty would have coolly pocketed the money, retained the white prisoners, and still have come to war. Everyone knows the Ashantis to be a treacherous lot of people; that they do not rashly pledge themselves to anything, and when they do, they have ulterior designs; and how the Government could have been induced to place any confidence in his Majesty of Ashanti, so as to compel our people from time to time to give up their prisoners, and fine and disgrace our kings and chiefs, on representations coming from such a source, is more than any sane man out here can understand. For him, and to suit him, and to oblige and to calm him, our border kings and chiefs were almost invariably maltreated. One can hardly find fault with the Government for this, as there was someone who was perpetually pouring into their ears stories of outrages committed on peaceable Ashanti traders, insults offered to his Majesty, and anything that would lead the Government to believe that we are and were always the provoking and aggressing party in all disturbances with the Ashantis. We hope that for the future the Government will not accept all such stories as truth without making inquiries of their own; and not appoint people who are related to this same person, or who can be induced by him or anybody else to distort or conceal facts; and that in future communications or negotiations with his Majesty of Ashanti, other native gentlemen, and Europeans of some experience here will be invited to the Councils of the Government. There are many gentlemen who are as well acquainted with the Ashantis as the one who is desirous of making people believe that he has but to say to him of Ashanti, "Come, and he cometh; Go, and he goeth;" and who informs the Ashantis that he is paramount here, and the authorities listen but to obey when he speaks.', 'last_edit_date': '1873-02-28', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/29_03_1873#article-1', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.716, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Native Letters from the Gold Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Some of your contemporaries have undoubtedly got hold of the bull by the wrong horn—have as undoubtedly read the history of the Gold Coast and of Ashanti, such as is known, with prejudiced and perverted minds, and have consequently treated the public with résumés, précis, and such like articles, from their point of view; and their correspondents, as a rule, have dealt in like manner with the history of these regions, and the position held here by you.

We will not discuss how you came to assume, nor by what means you assumed, the protectorate of the tribes inhabiting the Gold Coast; it suffices that you have assumed and exercised such a protectorate, and accepted the responsibilities consequent thereon. You have levied taxes, imposed duties, and governed us in every sense as you do your Crown colonies and other dependencies. You make and unmake kings and chiefs; you treat with Ashanti without consulting the kings and chiefs over whom you have assumed such a protectorate; you have divested them of all power and authority over their subjects, and over even their own domestics; you fine and imprison them as you think fit; you legislate for them, make laws, pass ordinances, bills, &c., without consulting them; and by your fiat, can make them vassals to a foreign power, without their being taken into your deliberations. All this, and more, you do; and when, through your thirst for extension of territory and lust for empire—when, through the blundering of your officials, and their crass ignorance and mismanagement, you find yourself launched into a war, you begin execrating us poor fellows, who had no hand in bringing this war about, and talk of giving over a portion of our territory to appease his Majesty of Ashanti, just as though the Gold Coast were British territory, and not merely British protectorate territory, and could be given out in plots, "regardless of what might be thought of it by the Fantees, who seem to be of no use to us or to themselves."

The writer of these words shows throughout his article a pitiable ignorance of the question he is discussing. He speaks of the Fantees as "a hostile tribe, over whom we have assumed a protectorate, and who have, in the confidence of that protection, given offence to the Ashantees;" and that we "shut out the Ashantees from the Coast at our pleasure;" talks of our "speculating on your assistance to bar the Ashantees from the sea;" of our shielding an Ashantee chief, and thus enabling him to flaunt successful rebellion in the face of the king; and about the treaty of 1831, which he says the Fantees have violated, together with observations of a like nature,—in a strain which exhibits imperfect knowledge of his subject-matter. But he is not alone, as there are others who have written on the Chamah and Tacorady disasters as though the recently-ceded Dutch tribes, and those who inhabit Fanti proper, and those formerly under the English, are one and the same people.*', 'last_edit_date': '1873-10-09', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/29_11_1873#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.695, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE ASHANTI ENVOYS IN ENGLAND.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sir,—The Ashanti Ambassador has consulted me in reference to the various articles appearing in the Press touching on this subject, and he has requested me in fairness to ask that you will permit me to make some comment thereon inasmuch as the English version of the matter has alone been presented to the public. There appears to be some foundation for believing that a military expedition has been sent to Coomassie, or is about to be, for the purposes of compelling the King of Ashanti to accept a British Resident at his capital, whether the same be just, expedient, or otherwise. It is but fair (and Englishmen always boast of their fairness) that our Government and the King of Ashanti should have the like opportunities of putting their case before the British public, although I am aware that the public Press is not exactly the constitutional medium generally appealed to. The Ambassadors, however, are in London, and having appealed to the Government for a hearing (which has been refused), they can but now appeal to the Press for the ventilation of their alleged grievances—the more especially as I understand that the British Government are not slow on occasions to recognise that as a correct medium. According to my instructions, it would appear that Prempeh was not elected to the stool of Ashanti by us, so much so that we refused to interfere with the Ashantees' selection at all, but fully recognised their action by having present our official representative at the coronation, and acknowledged him as King of Ashanti. There cannot be any manner of doubt about this, as it is borne out by the Blue records from 1888 to 1894. I am also told that when the British Government submitted the proposal that a British Resident should be received, the King was correctly designated by us as "King of Ashanti," although at that time we were aware of the fact now alleged that "the old Ashanti Confederation" has been broken up"—a confederation which, I am instructed, had never existed. My clients emphatically deny that the King has ever broken or violated any of his treaty engagements. They deny, too, that he has countenanced human sacrifice, a fact which I am told is negatived by our own records; nor has he, it is urged, hampered trade and attacked tribes under British protection. It is also denied that he has raided for slaves. On the contrary, my clients inform me that the King has cause to complain of want of frankness towards him, and that our representative in the Gold Coast, while professing friendship towards the King, has, as a fact, been acting contrary to his pledges. The King is prepared to open his country to British skill, and does not seek to hamper trade as is suggested. The Ambassadors submit that the fact of Ashanti being "within the sphere of British influence" does not carry away the King's independence as a sovereign, nor justify the hostile attitude our Government are assuming. That the King is an independent sovereign, there cannot be any question in the face of the reply of the Under-Secretary of State for the Colonies, given in February last, and if England claims the right to send a mission to the King whenever she feels inclined, my clients urge that the same privilege should be extended to their King when he is acting with bona fides and in the honest belief that he is acting within his rights. The mission have travelled some thousands of miles to discuss the position and treat with her Majesty's advisers, and if only on the grounds of fair play, and apart from any precedent, the Government could receive them, there certainly would not be any particle of reason why one ounce of blood should be shed. Of course, in expressing the foregoing views I am carrying out my instructions, not, however, with any doubts as to the justice of the King's claim, but with a keen sense of the Ambassador's sincerity.—I am, sir, yours, &c.,', 'last_edit_date': '1895-10-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1895#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.692, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE ASHANTI WAR.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The King of Abrah, who sent down the first reliable information, requested Mr. Wm. Cleaver, Mr. James F. Amissah, and myself to convey it to Colonel Harley; this Mr. Cleaver and Mr. Amissah did in my absence, and on my return, we all sought the Administrator. We had no cause to complain of our reception by Colonel Harley. He very kindly listened to what we had to say, but, somehow or other, he would not believe that the Ashantis were in very large force, and appeared, therefore, somewhat reluctant to give assistance in arms and ammunition proportionate to the emergency. During our discussion, however, Mr. Amissah stated to the Administrator that our peoples were determined, since they had not provoked this war, if they were successful in driving off the enemy, to follow him up to Coomassie, and make a final blow at the Ashanti power, provided we were assisted by the Government. This Colonel Harley construed into treasonable language, refused to listen to an explanation, and Mr. Amissah was therefore politely requested to make his exit. I need not say how much I was taken aback at this, and I believe that Mr. Cleaver could not have been less so; for Mr. Amissah is the last person from whom one would be likely to hear treasonable language, and if he cared about talking treason, it is not to be expected that he would do so in the presence of so august a personage. I have stated this incident, as a wrong impression appears to have got abroad as to what transpired at the interview, and I will at once tender the amende honorable to all concerned if they consider I have made an unwarrantable use of their names, or have made public what should have gone no further. I trust, however, that by this time, it has become evident that Mr. Amissah is a man of some consequence, and that he was actuated by the best of motives when he thus spoke.

This incident, trivial as it is, had very nigh led to consequences that could not have been calculated upon beforehand; and it has even had the effect of deterring others from giving such information as they may have, and from communicating with the authorities here in the frank and open manner that they sought by their proclamation.', 'last_edit_date': '1873-02-28', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/29_03_1873#article-1', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.693, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Affairs of the Interior', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sir,—I informed you of a compliment of the Gyawoman King to Ossay Bonzo. That King appears to be of his word. This day week his Excellency was greeted with the news of two large towns belonging to Ashanti being attacked by armies of Gyawomans and Bannah; the inhabitants have been partly butchered, and the rest fled. The successor of the General who invaded the Protectorate has been sent with Ashantee forces to hinder their progress. As usual in messages on such occasions, "King Bonzo, not wishing that he should be misrepresented to the Governor" (do not laugh) "as going to war," Kankum, a sword-bearer, must come to report to his Excellency that "he has sent Awoo-ah to stop them." Now, I suppose, Mr. Editor, you begin to see the Ashantee schemes, as I before wrote to you! This message and the subsequent by Nunochwee have their meaning, and only to be understood by those who know them as they know your correspondent does. They put down all this commotion to Assafoo Aggay's account. The envoys desired the Governor to give him up to them or transport him, but were greatly pained by a denial. The fact is, the sympathy exhibited by the tribes who have revolted from the power of Ashanti for Assafoo Aggay is not altogether on account of love they have towards him, but, as I wrote you before, they cannot bear that prestige any more. I am glad to report that the Gyawoman envoys have this day arrived at Cape Coast. It is about three months ago since we heard of their being on the way. What a sharp cutting knife this news is to the Ashantees! But it is painfully to be regretted that the right view of these openings is not taken by the local Government in respect to the general civilization and trade of this country. I have not yet heard the errand of these envoys; you shall have it as soon as I hear.—Your obedient servant,', 'last_edit_date': '1877-03-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_03_1877#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.694, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE WOULD-BE ASHANTI ENVOYS', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The steamer Accra arrived at Grand Canary on April 16, _en route_ for Liverpool, having on board the _soi-disant_ Ashanti Ambassadors, who are visiting England in the hope of waiting upon the Queen to lay before her Majesty a full statement of their case. The mission of these Envoys marks a stage in a series of negotiations. They are six in number, the chief amongst them being Prince A. A. Ossoo-Ansah, a son of Prince Ansah, who, in 1874, after the Ashanti War and the deposition of King Coffee, visited England for the purpose of clearing himself of imputations as to disloyalty to England during that war, and of obtaining compensation for the destruction of his property by the enemy. Prince Ossoo Ansah is the only one of the six who can speak English, and is appointed to act as interpreter and spokesman. The purpose of the visit has been stated in telegraphic despatches, but some fuller information is now available. It seems that the relations of Great Britain towards Ashanti have, with the sanction of the French Government, assumed somewhat new features, as it has been recognised as falling within the British sphere of influence. With the increased assurance of protection thus afforded, British traders have extended their operations in the country, which is extremely fertile in general produce, and especially rich in gold. The Governor of Cape Coast Castle, Sir W. Brandford Griffith, has consequently been led to propose the extension of British authority in a more formal manner—the establishment of a British Resident at the capital, Coomassie (or Kumasi). This step having been taken, the next would naturally be the definite conversion of the country into a British Protectorate. But to this idea a considerable number of the Natives have expressed the most decided objection; and it is with the idea of expressing the popular feeling upon this point that these six "ambassadors" have been appointed with the intention that they should seek an interview with the Queen, and lay before her Majesty the reasons why such a course would be so unpopular among their people.', 'last_edit_date': '1895-05-04', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_05_1895#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.7, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Chiefs and Kings of the Gold Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sir,—The interest which your journal has always taken in the affairs of West Africa induces me to solicit a space for the insertion of this article, which I trust will not fail to lead to an amelioration of the state of things, by its being brought to the knowledge of those whom it concerns.

One of the results of the Ashanti Campaign was to bring the countries on the Gold Coast under the control or protection of the British Government. The countries on the sea-coast are divided into districts, to each of which a Commissioner is appointed by the Governor. The interior countries, however, are not thus provided for, but are left to be ruled by their chiefs and kings, as formerly. The authority of these kings and chiefs was not formally acknowledged, and any offence which, according to custom, is visited with severe punishment, is immediately reported to the Government authorities on the sea-coast; and the chieftain or king who ordered the punishment is brought before the Court and treated as the commonest fellow.

This action on the part of the Government terrifies and paralyzes a good many of these chiefs and kings, so that in a great many instances the wicked go unpunished. On the other hand, others use the name of the Government to acquire territories which they have not the least right to. Amongst these I may mention the name of one "Sakiaty," who is of great notoriety in Eastern Croboe, interior of Accra. This man was a chief of Odumase, a country of Eastern Croboe, before the Ashanti Campaign, but immediately after the war, he assumed the authority and title of king, which he said was vested in him by Sir John Glover for the valuable services he rendered in the war. Not contented with the throne which he has thus usurped, he is now intriguing to acquire Western Croboe also. The present king of Western Croboe, who is now being molested, forbears to say anything, lest his opposition may end in a contest, and he may be thereby brought to the sea-coast and treated with ignominy. But there is sure to come a successor who will dispute every inch of ground that "Sakiaty" has thus acquired. This will undoubtedly end in strife, when people will have the mortification again to see that their royalties are treated contemptuously by those who are their protectors. If the present system of government in the interior countries is to continue, I would, Sir, respectfully recommend that the following plans be carried out: (1) that every chieftain or king in the interior should prove his claim; (2) that the right of government by native chiefs and kings in the interior, so far as it is compatible with common sense and humanity, be proclaimed as supported by the British authorities on the sea-coast; and (3), that any unnecessary interference and aggression of one chief or king with another, be met with the highest displeasure of the Governor.', 'last_edit_date': '1880-06-11', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_08_1880#article-4', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.694, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Colonial Office and the Ashanti Envoys', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The Ashanti envoys who persisted in coming to England some months ago with the forlorn hope of being officially received as the accredited representatives of the Ashanti King, have now returned to their own country, without securing the object for which they had travelled so far. In a somewhat lengthy correspondence between the Secretary for the Colonies and Mr. T. Sutherst, who has constituted himself their advocate and champion—for which, we regret to say, we are unable to find room—we get a very clear statement of the objects which King Prempeh's messengers had in view in coming to England, and, on the other hand, of the reasons which induced the Colonial Office authorities to refuse to receive them.

In the first case we arrive at the foundation of the rumours which have been circulated in reference to the alleged relations established between her Majesty's Government and the Ashanti envoys. That the Secretary of State should have so far departed from official etiquette as to receive in person intermediaries from a deputation, which had been formally warned that no recognition could be extended to it, seemed highly improbable. This correspondence shows that Mr. Chamberlain caused the envoys to be once more informed in the plainest terms why it is impossible to recognise them as ambassadors, or to negotiate a treaty with them. They are told that if any arrangement with the King is made it must be effected at the Gold Coast by the Governor of the Colony. They are reminded they were informed of this fact before they left Africa, and the words of the prohibition by the Governor of the Gold Coast on Dec. 21, 1894, are repeated: "I hereby give you notice that I have to-day received instructions from the Government of her Majesty the Queen of Great Britain and Ireland and Empress of India to forbid you going on to England, and I forbid you accordingly."

If King Prempeh still adheres to his determination to communicate his acceptance of the British ultimatum through these messengers and through no other channel, his conduct is, to say the least of it, so remarkable that Mr. Chamberlain is', 'last_edit_date': '1895-12-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_12_1895#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.692, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Letter from Kpong', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Alas, dear Mr. Editor! I am afraid our local Government here are neglecting one of the most important measures in this affair of the Ashantee war. No blockade can be effectual till it is carried out fully. Although Government has blockaded our frontiers toward the Ashantee territory, yet this part of the country, on the river Volta, is totally neglected, and now open to the Ashantees, where they receive all the munitions of war. In consequence of this, a vigorous trade is going on from this and Adda and Quittah, in salt, tobacco, gin, arms, and gunpowder, in exchange for gold dust and slaves. This is a policy that we stupid people here don't understand. Through this neglect the Ashantees have lately committed some outrages here.

Some time last month the messengers of the King of Ashantee arrived here in the town of Assabi, in the district of Krepee, and under cover of night cut off the heads of two of Her Majesty's subjects, by names Quamlin Savili and Kuaku Dabonnie, natives of Assabi, in our Krepee jurisdiction.

It has since come out that this outrage was committed by sanction and connivance of the chief of Assabi, by name Quamlin Minta, who is supposed to be intriguing with the Ashantees. On investigating the case before the supreme chief, Nijarkon, it was further proved that Minta has had a criminal connexion with the wife of one of the unfortunate men. He is now bailed out before Chief Nijarkon till something is heard from proper authorities. I will write you something more about this affair, and about the change that has come over the people in other parts of our territories with regard to the Ashantee war. It seems to

me that the sufferings inflicted on the country last year in consequence of the shameful military mismanagement, which allowed the Ashantees to ravage in all directions, have not only put an end to the enthusiasm the people felt when the war began, but quite sickened them of it. The truth is, they do not believe in the English power as they did before the last campaign.", 'last_edit_date': '1863-12-08', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_01_1864#article-7', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.723, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'ASHANTEE SCHEMES.—TRIBES IN DANGER.—CRUEL GOVERNMENT MISTAKES.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'It will not, therefore, surprise you to hear of his having sent the greater part of his troops on expedition against the interior tribes, and thinking, as the general notion in Ashanti, that their treacherous policy is still unknown by other nations, especially the Europeans, see how he sends his concerted scheme. On the 30th ultimo, a messenger arrived from King Mainza, alias Ossay Bonzo, of Ashanti, to the Lieutenant-Governor; as he was absent, on the 31st the messenger went to the Acting Colonial Secretary and delivered the following message: "My King sends his compliments to Governor, his good friend; he says, one of his revolted chiefs, Essandawah, of Insutah district, wishing to return to his former allegiance, sent to ask him, King, for ammunition to chase his own sister, who is the Queen of that district, and two sons, or rather nephews, of his, who have left and gone to Kraki because they would not go to Kumasi with him. The King had refused him ammunition; but since he sent to ask him to send a captain to take him to Kumasi, he, the King, has sent one of his captains to bring him to Kumasi; and because he fears someone may come and report him as going to war, he sends me to apprise the Governor." We have, therefore, now to wait a short time to hear the result of this from the interior. Still, I venture to hint to you the secret of this sending for the Chief of Insutah, who has no enemies between him and Kumasi to have necessitated a captain being sent to bring him.

You know, Mr. Editor, that as soon as the neighbouring tribes of Ashanti who had suffered so much the prestige of that kingdom, knew of Kumasi being set on fire, and the King's running away before Sir Garnet's troops, they all exhibited their enmity, and revenged themselves by killing all Ashantees who had gone among them, and did not wish to have anything further to do with that dynasty. When they saw that the King of Juabin also had thrown off his allegiance to it, they all then directed their course to him to join him in placing themselves under the British Government. result: The observations from the "General History of Africa" textbook and The African Times news articles present a nuanced view of the claim regarding international skepticism and anti-French sentiment in Loango. The textbook does not directly address this claim, focusing instead on French colonial activities in regions like Madagascar and Dahomey, where anti-French sentiment and colonial rivalries with Britain are noted, but without specific reference to Loango or related interventions. This absence suggests that the textbook does not cover this particular aspect of French colonial history. In contrast, The African Times articles provide detailed support for the claim, describing the French occupation of Ponta Negra and the imposition of restrictive orders by a self-styled "Governor of Loango," which were perceived as vexatious by locals and traders. This led to calls for international intervention to counter what was seen as unjustifiable French meddling. The articles also highlight protests from the Dutch government against French claims on the Congo, underscoring concerns over the legitimacy of French actions. Additionally, the presence of French military authorities and their interactions with entities like the Belgian International African Association further fueled tensions and skepticism about French intentions and effectiveness in Loango. Together, these sources illustrate a complex picture of French colonial activities, with The African Times providing specific evidence of international discontent and calls for intervention in Loango, which the textbook does not address.

The Minister has not only married the Queen, but taken to himself all the Crown jewels. It is not impossible that this may lead to another of 'those distant expeditions' of which the Emperor spoke on the 5th of November, and which, if satisfactory, are certainly expensive."'}, {'id': 4687, 'article_title': 'RIVER CONGO.', 'full_section_title': 'RIVER CONGO.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1883#article-9', 'issue_date': '01_10_1883', 'content': 'PORTUGAL AND CONGO.**

_Lisbon._

It is reported that the Colonial Governor of Angola has sent a mission from Loanda to San Salvador, Congo, to salute the King, Don Pedro, who it is alleged, will send a special mission to Lisbon to present his respects to the King of Portugal. The sons of the King of Congo will form part of the mission, which will have for its object the strengthening of the friendly relations between Portugal and Congo, and the definitive establishment of the ancient protectorate exercised by Portugal over that kingdom.

_Congo River, August 4._

Since my last communication, I have received some strange information concerning the doings of the French in Loango. It will be remembered that a short time ago the French were stated to have taken possession of Ponta Negra, otherwise called Black Point, but the evidence was doubtful, as I pointed out, though I recommended vigilance in the matter. I now hear that the French have left Ponta Negra, and that military authorities have appeared in Loango, one official styling himself Governor of Loango, and issuing vexatious orders to the natives and traders. It is stated that amongst these orders of the "Governor" was one prohibiting the white traders from sending their servants for firewood and drinking water outside of their fences; another allowing wood and water to be fetched, but prohibiting the whites from leaving their own premises; another, prohibiting the natives from coming to the white establishments; and, lastly, one prohibiting the importation of trade guns and powder. However much these statements may be overdrawn, it surely seems that the time has arrived when other nations should take steps to prevent this unjustifiable meddling—let the French Government call it annexation, protection, or any other name they will.

_Munich, Sept. 7._

The Congress of International Law to-day decided to express the wish that the navigation of the Congo River should be declared free for all nations, and that the Powers should come to an understanding with regard to a course of action calculated to prevent conflicts between civilized countries in Equatorial Africa. The Bureau of the Congress was instructed to inform the Powers of this wish in the form of an addition to the memorandum of M. Moynier.

_Liverpool, Sept. 12._'}, {'id': 6604, 'article_title': 'INTERNATIONAL ARBITRATION.', 'full_section_title': 'INTERNATIONAL ARBITRATION.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1895#article-9', 'issue_date': '01_08_1895', 'content': 'The French Chamber of Deputies, on July 8, adopted the following resolution, moved by M. Barrodet, viz.: "That the Chamber invites the Government to negotiate, as soon as possible, a treaty of permanent arbitration between the French Republic and the Republic of the United States of America." M. Barrodet asked for "urgency" for this proposition, and this was granted. It was accordingly put as a formal resolution, and at once adopted unanimously.

The Paris Figaro, remarks upon this occurrence: "Hitherto, resolutions of this character have, for the most part, been introduced into Congresses attended by ladies and gentlemen, of no brilliant attainments in the knowledge of affairs of this world. They shout 'Hurrah for Universal Peace!' and drink toasts in honour of it, at the banquets which constitute a feature of gatherings of this class. But now the case is altogether different. Here we have the representatives of 36,000,000 Frenchmen declaring 'It is possible that we may one day have a difficulty with the American nation. Hence it is desirable to guarantee that international strife shall be prevented by a peaceful resort to Arbitration!'"

Many American organs have hailed this resolution as an auspicious event, which will tend to facilitate and resort to arbitration in future differences. The New York Herald declares the French proposal to be worthy of hearty approval.

In June 1893 the British House of Commons expressed its willingness to co-operate with the Government of the United States in settling disputes by means of arbitration. And, in January last, one of the members of the House of Representatives moved the following resolution in that assembly: Whereas the British House of Commons, on June 16, 1893, affirmed its willingness to co-operate with the Government of the United States in settling disputes between the two countries by means of arbitration; therefore—Resolved, that the President of the United States be requested to take such steps in the matter as may seem expedient; and to that end is authorised to appoint Commissioners to meet an equal number appointed by Great Britain to negotiate a treaty for the purposes of said resolutions.

Now that the two Legislatures of France and Great Britain have recorded their willingness to unite with America in further action for rendering a resort to Arbitration the permanent method of settling any disputes that may arise between them, it remains for the United States to take the next step, on the lines of the resolution above mentioned.'}]

Hamel was held prisoner in Gaboon when the despatch was sent off.", 'last_edit_date': '1885-01-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_01_1885#article-10', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.623, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE FRENCH IN WEST AFRICA', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'If the old "Quem vult perdere," which applied equally to nations as to individuals, had not been so hackneyed, we should undoubtedly have chosen it as a fitting introduction to what we feel bound to write as regards the late, and present external action of the French Government, which seems to us to have placed France upon the slippery plank at the bottom of which lies disaster, if not ruin. It would be impossible, we think, for even the most unreasoning admirer of France, its people, and its Government, to find cause for eulogy in the late external action of the Paris cabinet. With Annam and Tonquin we have nothing to do, though we may have formed our opinions on the subject. As regards Madagascar, we consider the French action, prompted by the Réunion planters, as so certain to lead, if successful, to a new revival of the African slave trade, either open or under the pretence of apprenticeship, or free labour contracts, that, as such, and as a wanton aggression on a community of the African race that has been for some time steadily progressing on the road to civilization, we do not hesitate to give it our most emphatic condemnation. The Government of Liberia, like that of Madagascar, refuses to allow white men to obtain a settlement on any portion of its land by purchase; and although this has greatly interfered with the development of the resources of the country, by shutting out European capital and energy, we can find quite enough in the history of past relations of Europeans with the people of Africa to excuse this policy of isolation. Behind every European acquiring, by purchase, landed possessions in such a country, there looms the national government of that European in the distance, as almost certain to become a factor in any dispute that might arise between him and the authorities. With equal justice, therefore, might France make demands upon Liberia, as upon Madagascar, on the ground of refusal to allow French subjects to become freeholders. What most concerns us, however, as regards the present external action of the French Government, is that portion of it which embraces west and south-west Africa in its disturbing course. We have before alluded to and condemned (and it will bear repetition) the most unfriendly action of France in taking the wretched King Tofa, of Porto Novo, under its protection. We repeat, situate as Porto Novo is with regard to Lagos, together with the non-existence of any real French interest there, the acceptance of a Protectorate by France was about as offensively unfriendly an action as can well be conceived. The French mercantile house that counselled it, has performed about as questionable service to France as was performed by the Portuguese slave trader who led the French Government into a similar measure some twenty years ago. No good can come of it to France, and much evil may. We and all other advocates of the rights of humanity, must now hold her responsible for all the horrors it may please her atrocious protege, King Tofa, to commit. We have a right to demand, in the interests of humanity and civilization, that the French Protectorate of Porto Novo shall be characterized and justified by the absolute repression of those fearful customs in which it has pleased King Tofa and his predecessors to indulge. Such repression has characterized the action of Great Britain in West Africa, and the way in which she has thus exercised her power for freeing the poor wretched victims of tyranny and superstition constitute, in our mind, her only just claim to rule there. Her keeping peace among the natives, and suppressing all slavery and slave trade, so far as within her power; affording protection to trade and commerce, and laying the foundation of civilization on which the natives may hereafter build—these, we say, and to afford protection for philanthropic and missionary enterprise, are her raison d'etre, on the West Coast. There is no doubt—there can be no doubt—that she might do this work better than she does, if more enlightened councils prevailed in Downing Street; still, what she has done, has been greatly instrumental for good. To feel this fully we have only to imagine what the West Coast of Africa would have been without persistent British interference and guardianship there. And it must always be borne in mind that the imperial exchequer does not receive one farthing from her settlements and possessions, and the protected trade there; while under her liberal free trade system, the ships, subjects, and goods of every other civilized power, European or American, have the same advantages as her own. In a word, she keeps the greater portion of West Africa open to trade and commerce for the benefit of the whole world. Now, the French Colonial system is the very reverse of this. Her protective and prohibitive regulations are in full force at Goree and Senegal; and, by intelligence lately received, we can have no doubt that France is anxious to confer similar benefits on other portions of the West Coast. The French admiral who took Porto Novo under French protection, looked in upon other places on his way down the coast. He made overtures to the King of Bonny, which the king and chief, who have received education in England, were too wise to listen to. And now we learn further that he has proposed to establish a French factory at Old Calabar, and that King Duke Ephraim IX., whose coronation under the auspices of the British consul and the Rev. W. Anderson, we some time since gave an account of, has held a grand council and petitioned the French Government to induce French traders to settle there. Those who do not know anything of the West Coast would suppose from this that French traders were hitherto denied trade with Old Calabar; which, under British consular auspices, has been open for trade to all the world from the period at which Great Britain put a final end to the slave trade there. The intended process is clear. A French factory under Government auspices, perhaps managed by Messrs. Regis, of Marseilles, Lagos, and Porto Novo, who have manipulated the Porto Novo protectorate—a dispute with the natives—French Government demands redress—protection—occupation—a French exclusive trading station, to the exclusion of our Liverpool and German merchants, who now do the great oil trade there.', 'last_edit_date': '1883-11-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1883#article-20', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.613, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'FRANCE AND MADAGASCAR.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The Malagasy Government has lately published the official correspondence between its Minister for Foreign Affairs and the Consuls of France. A more shameful story of arrogance and high-handed wrong-doing on the part of a first-rate European Power has been seldom given to the world. The first dispute, it seems, arose over the sale of land by the heirs of a former French Consul to a Roman Catholic priest. The Hova Government objected to the sale because the Consul in question, by Malagasy law, which prohibits the owning of land by foreigners, was only a life tenant. Moreover, the title-deeds which the Hova Government declare to have been forged, bore the signature of King Radama II., dated several months after that monarch's death. The French Consul attempted to explain this unpleasant fact away by different reckonings of the calendar, but the Hovas are able to prove that not a single document of Radama II.'s reign bears the date of 1864 except the particular one in dispute. The second dispute arose over the death of four French sailors on the coast. These men were, from the Malagasy standpoint, nothing more nor less than smugglers, who were landing weapons of war and ammunition, contrary to treaty. A Malagasy chief endeavoured to stop this traffic, and was fired upon by the French smugglers, whereupon the fire was returned, with the result that four of the French were killed and the goods in question seized. In the end the Hova Government paid an indemnity under protest. The trumped-up claim of the French to a Protectorate over the North-west Coast rests upon an alleged transfer of power by a certain chief to the French; but, apart from the fact that this man, as a vassal, had no right to alienate lands, the treaty which he did sign only allowed the French to settle for agricultural and commercial purposes, and to keep some armed men "for their own protection." We regret to find that the tone of the French officials throughout the controversy is to the last degree insolent and provocative. They appear to have acted upon the principle that weak nations have no rights which France is bound to respect; and that every Frenchman who finds himself in the territory of such a nation has a right to whatever he pleases, no matter what may be the law of the country. It is this kind of treatment of other nations which has more than once drawn down upon France evils and troubles which have shaken the whole commonwealth to its very centre. But we trust the French Ministry will not fail to put an explanation before the world which is worthy of the high position France holds in the front ranks of civilization.', 'last_edit_date': '1884-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1884#article-15', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.615, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE CONGO', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'International conferences seem to be in high favour, and now the proposal that one should be summoned on the Congo question is revived. A correspondent at Vienna states: "It does not suit everybody concerned that the Congo question should be settled between England and Portugal alone, and there are certain pigeon-holes at the London Foreign Office whence some curious documentary evidence of this might be obtained. On the other hand, it is by no means sure that the privileges conceded to France by the Association Internationale could be exercised without raising strong protest, and perhaps something more, on the part of other interested Powers. The convocation of a conference to settle the Congo question must in any case prove a matter of some little difficulty in the first place, owing to the altogether exceptional position of the Association Internationale. It is neither directly nor indirectly a Government institution. M. Frere-Orban, the late Belgian Premier, repudiated all official cognisance of it, and it never had the sympathy or approval of the present Belgian Ministers when they were in Opposition. Yet it is under the immediate patronage of King Leopold, who has already devoted considerable sums to further its aims, and is apparently disposed to make fresh sacrifices with the same object, as was proved by Gordon Pasha's intended mission. According to the Politische Correspondenz, the appeal of the native sovereigns to the Governor-General of Angola against the Association Internationale was immediately responded to by that official, who at once sent a corvette and gunboat to the Congo. The native kings will thus be supported in refusing to yield their sovereign rights to the Association Internationale, notwithstanding the treaties they recently signed.', 'last_edit_date': '1884-06-15', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1884#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.615, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'FRANCE AND THE ROYAL NIGER COMPANY.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sometime since the Niger Company protested against Lieut. Mizon's presence in the Muri, and denied the validity of his treaty with the Sultan of that region. M. Mizon was recalled for explanations, but the French Government continued to support the scientific portion of the expedition under M. Bretonnet, as also the commercial mission in charge of M. Wehrlin. M. Mizon was to await instructions through M. Hoelle, who left France to aid M. Wehrlin. But the Niger Company was no more willing to afford M. Hoelle facilities on the Niger and the Binue than M. Mizon, and so M. Hoelle was obliged to go to Kotonou. This has aroused the indignation of the French Central African Company.

"Our merchants," says the Temps, "are ignorant as to what has happened to their agents. Communication between the Upper Binue and the coast appears to be cut off. In spite of the rise of the waters which began in July, no mail has reached France. Has the Niger Company fulfilled its threat of sinking the French ships Mosca and Sergent Malamine? This uncertainty must not last. The French Government must know what is going on on the Binue. Perhaps an inquiry on the spot, to ascertain how the Royal Niger Company executes the engagements to which it is bound by the General Act of Berlin, may be necessary. Complaints are constantly being preferred against the Royal Niger Company. The English Government is apparently unable to exercise any serious influence on the chartered company, to which it has granted sovereign powers on the Lower Niger and the Lower Binue."

M. Hoelle, who was deputed by the French Government to carry fresh instructions to the Mizon mission, writes from Akassa, under date August 1:', 'last_edit_date': '1893-10-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_10_1893#article-1', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.63, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The French Movement in West Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The semi-official Note, says The Times, is happily an institution with which the Press of this country is acquainted only at second-hand. In consequence of our inexperience of this order of document we cannot always feel assured that we fully apprehend its meaning. This is occasionally not a little embarrassing. If, for example, the charges made against us in the Note published in Paris on Tuesday evening were embodied in a regular diplomatic instrument, we should be certain that they were intended to be a prelude to very serious events. The Niger Company is accused of sending officers to sow agitation and incite the people to "rebellion" in Borgu and in the Niki region. Presumably the "rebellion" is against France; but as we notoriously deny that France has any rights whatever in a great part of this country north of the ninth parallel and south of the Say-Barrua line, the accusation implies a right of sovereignty on the part of France in territory which, as she is well aware, we claim as British. That would be rather a serious matter in an official Note intended for publication. Still more grave is the assertion in the same document that "everything leads to the belief that the British Government is seeking to let things drag on, and has no intention of discussing them." That is a direct imputation of bad faith, made not against the Niger Company this time, but against the Government of the Queen. Most ominous of all in a diplomatic correspondence would be the words with which this Note concludes. "There is no doubt," they run, "that means will be found to foil these tactics." The natural construction to put upon them is that they are intended to convey a veiled but perfectly intelligible threat, and it need hardly be said that threats of any kind addressed to this country through the recognised diplomatic channels would meet with a very prompt and curt reply. But fortunately the Note belongs to the semi-official category, and accordingly we are free to put upon it a less unsatisfactory interpretation. We take it to mean that the French Government have realised the impossibility of pursuing any further on the West Coast of Africa the pleasant and profitable line of conduct which they have carried on with marked success for a great number of years. They were wholly unprepared for such a result; it has annoyed them and the colonial party very much, and the semi-official charges are the consequence of their disappointment.', 'last_edit_date': '1897-11-03', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/03_11_1897#article-10', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.621, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'FRANCE AND WEST AFRICA', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The Paris Débats of Dec. 16 contains a leading article entitled "France on the Niger," urging that the present moment marks a crisis in the position of France in the bend of the Niger. The idea conceived by the explorer Crampel of connecting the French colonies of the Congo, Senegal, and Algeria has been pursued by Maistre, Mizon, Monteil, Ménard, Marchand, Ballot, Decoeur, Alby, Toutée, and other valiant explorers until this grand dream of a French colonial empire, stretching from the Mediterranean to the Gulf of Benin, began to seem not so utopian after all. But with the expansion of the Royal Niger Company and the activity of German explorers, aided by the supineness of the French Foreign Office, France has seen, during the last three or four years, much of her explorers' work compromised. Only the other day during the hasty discussion of the Foreign Estimates, Prince d'Arenberg asked the Minister of the Colonies whether it was true that a post established by Capt. Toutée below the Boussa Rapids had been evacuated by order of the Government. The Minister did not reply, and thus the French Africa Company has put up with a snub the like of which would not have been meted out in any other country to a body deserving so much for its sacrifices in the interests of Colonial expansion.

Curiously enough, the article goes on to say, this indifference to the affairs in West Africa seems to coincide with the creation of a Colonial Ministry, and M. Delcassé, who might have played an active role in it, has been prevented by the accidents of political life from defending French interest in this region, where private enterprise has been left to its own devices. Since then colonial matters in West Africa have gone from bad to worse. The French Africa Company, however, certain indications prove, is about to begin the campaign afresh, and it must end by arousing the Ministry to greater activity.

At the meeting of the Budget Committee on Dec. 16, M. Guieysse, Minister of the Colonies, explained the reasons why he was about to ask for fresh credits of 725,000f. (£29,000) for the Ivory Coast and 975,000f. for the Upper Ubangi. But besides these credits he announced another of 100,000f. for the expense of the occupation of the Soudan, to be used mainly for the construction of the route from Konakry to the Niger. It is said, however, that this is not the whole story, that still another 100,000f. is to be asked for, and that its destination will be somewhat vaguer.', 'last_edit_date': '1896-01-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_01_1896#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.616, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Recent Explorations in the Cameroons Interior', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'In another column, our readers will find an account, given on the authority of the Paris correspondent of the *Times*, of the probable causes which led up to the late—or, shall we say present—difficulty between France and Dahomey. Though rather startling in its conclusions, it seems to bear the stamp of genuineness; and is interesting, as affording a possible explanation to other mysterious embroilments than this particular instance. The French nation has not shown much interest in this war: which has not even provoked enough criticism to be made a weapon of party controversy. They seem generally to have found no less difficulty in understanding its use or reason than the King of Dahomey himself whose request to President Carnot for enlightenment was published some weeks ago. And the French Ministry knows little more about it than the rest of the world. The popular belief has been that the Admiral on the West African station, and the military forces employed in garrison duty in the same district have tried to diversify their monotony by picking a quarrel. The account now published, if true, relieves them of the burden of such a reproach.', 'last_edit_date': '1890-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1890#article-7', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.628, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE ASHANTI WAR', 'section_title': '', 'content': '## THE ASHANTI WAR.

**PARIS, Sunday, March 26.**—The Bien Public states that M. Verdier, whom it describes as a French merchant at Assinie, on the coast of Guinea, has sent a formal complaint to the French Legislature on account of the blockade of Assinio during the Ashanti War, and demanding an indemnity. It is not necessary to add that the French Government has already rejected the claim of M. Verdier as utterly groundless.', 'last_edit_date': '1876-04-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1876#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.629, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'FRANCE AND ENGLAND ON THE NIGER.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Thus, indirectly, revived the popularity of colonial expansion. Less than thirty voices are now raised in the French Chamber against that occupation of Tonquin which not only wrecked M. Ferry but endangered for a time the stability of the Republic. The second cause has been the interest aroused throughout the country by the attractive colonial section of the Exhibition of 1889. Multitudes of all classes, who were drawn to Paris by M. Eiffel's masterpiece, remained to enjoy the realistic representations of their African possessions, and carried back their enthusiasm into every commune of France. There was a grain of truth in the view of a rhapsodical journalist that the light of the great tower would penetrate from the Champs de Mars to (among other places) the plains of Timbuctoo.

The dangers of prophesying are proverbial; but it appears almost certain that this new-born movement will before long be stifled, as has always previously happened, by newer and more pressing interests; so that unless the French Government seizes this golden opportunity of inducing the nation to delegate the work to Chartered Companies, which would have internal and perennial sources of energy and would be independent of Parliamentary crises and party necessities, the present agitation will lead to no practical benefit whatever to France. Until the African races reach a level at which they can dispense with minute and incessant control of Europeans, civilisation cannot cease to mount without falling back to its starting-point. The special difficulty of the Central African question lies in this early stage, during which spasmodic efforts are a sheer waste of lives, money and energy. I do not, for a moment, wish to imply that France is peculiar in the want of steady continuity on the one hand, and judicious moderation on the other, in her African policy. M. Ribot, indeed, tells his Chamber that they do these things better in England. But here, too, the ebb and flow of opinion on this question during the last three centuries remind one of those fevers which form the chief obstacle to its speedy solution. In the delirium of the hot fits, Central Africa has figured as "La Belle au bois dormant" ready to awake to full vitality at the first caress; while, in reality, it is a Pygmalion's statue, to which the gift of life will only be granted on the prayers of a fervent and constant wooer, after patient preliminary labours; "Interea niveum mira feliciter arte Sculpit ebur." For, I would point out in passing, although ivory and other existing products cannot make Central Africa worth holding, they form the temporary basis on which the subsequent creation of agricultural wealth must rest. But the hot fits of enthusiasm have always been succeeded by periods of chill, lassitude and nausea, during which public opinion has blindly accepted assertions that Europe can never make any lasting impression on those regions.', 'last_edit_date': '1891-02-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_02_1891#article-0', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.624, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE FRENCH IN AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The feverish restlessness of the Government of the French Republic as regards colonial extension and annexations, has naturally caused surprise and great misgivings in the minds of thinking men who have no feeling of hostility with the democratic institutions which France has given to herself, or which have been given to her by the force of circumstances. There had been for some time past a general impression that the great bulk of the French people had become so opposed to everything resembling a policy of adventure—so entirely determined in favour of home improvements, and the quiet pursuit of wealth,—that no exterior action likely in any way to compromise the nation could or would be entered upon. If we may judge by what has of late taken and is now taking place, the general conviction above expressed would seem to have been founded on error; the national abstention being only from what might by possibility lead to early complications with continental neighbours. We are led to these remarks by a series of events, some of which may have very serious results, and all of which indicate that not Monarchy or Empire were alone to blame for the perturbation France so often caused in the world at large. No one ought to desire that France should efface herself. She has a wide sphere of action open to her, which no other Power has sought to dispute with her, unless it be the feeble opposition of Italy to her late operations at Tunis. From the time when an insult by the Bey of Algiers afforded the then French Government an opportunity for putting an end to that old piratical Mahometan rule which had for ages been a standing outrage to Europe generally, and a great hindrance to commerce in the Mediterranean, Europe, by tacit general accord, regarded France as entitled to any and every extension of sway she might find necessary or desirable in that portion of the great African continent. It was felt in England that although France had not such redundancy of population, or such rapid increase of population, as could render it necessary to send out colonies, there must be a portion of her industrious and enterprising people who could be spared from home both to their own and the national advantage, if they might be located so near to her that their absence and the employment of a portion of her military force there should not diminish her power and influence in Europa in the event of any misunderstanding with neighbouring Powers. She has, therefore, had *carte blanche*—entire freedom of action as regards a large territory in North and North-east Africa; nor have we thought it at all unreasonable that she should seek to bring this territory into connection with that appertaining to the Senegal River possession. It was on this ground that when it was stated there was an absolute determination on the part of the British Government to give up the River Gambia to France, we insisted that this could never be done except on condition that France retired altogether from West Africa, south of the River Pongas, with a view of preventing future complications that might arise from French pretensions in the Melicourie and other rivers adjacent to Sierra Leone, at Grand Bassam and Assinee, at Porto Novo, and at the River Gaboon. It was, however, understood that, notwithstanding the anxiety of France to obtain possession of the River Gambia, the French mercantile interests connected with the above named places were too powerful *vis-a-vis* the French Government to allow of the latter ceding anything in return for what she coveted. From this period we have always been looking forward to French action of an embarrassing nature in West Africa; and we have it now in the neighbourhood of the River Congo, arising out of the French possession of the River Gaboon. We confess that we look with apprehension to what may take place in that quarter with the French, under the lead of so vainglorious a person as Mons. de Brazza. The French operations in that quarter would not, however, *alone* justify our charge of "feverish restlessness" with which we began this leader. The Réunion planters are obviously in the ascendant as regards Madagascar, which is clearly doomed, sooner or later, to become a French possession—not only because of the richness of its soil, &c., for sugar production, but because only by its becoming a French possession can the supply of labourers for Réunion from Madagascar itself be continuously assured, while it will be a stepping-stone for *African free labourers* from East Africa to hard labour and graves in Réunion. Then, again, she is pouting about Egypt, where she thinks she ought to have a preponderating influence; while she opposes the continuance in office of a tried good Governor of the Lebanon, because she has, forsooth, a greater interest in Syria and Palestine than all the other European Powers combined, and will have no one in power there unless he be devoted to French interests. It will be remembered that in a former leader, in which we stated our belief in a great future war of France and Russia against Britain, arising out of the return of the Jews to Palestine, we expressed our conviction that, notwithstanding the French Government was composed for the most part of professed freethinkers, the clerical influence was so powerful that the same counsels which led to the dispute with Russia about the keys of the Holy Sepulchre (the original cause of the Crimean War) would continue to prevail, and that French efforts would ally themselves with those of Russia in hostility to all who should aid the descendants of Jacob in becoming again a nation upon the mountains of Israel. It will thus be seen at a glance how wide-spread is the present sphere of French activity, and how possible it is that such activity will lead to deplorable results. She desires Madagascar, with, seemingly, the reopening of the African foreign slave-trade; she desires an exclusive possession up the River Congo; she will admit of no rival in N. and N.E., and indeed N.W. Africa; she has decided on possessing Tonquin; she claims preponderating influence in Egypt, Syria, and Palestine. Do these not justify our charge of "feverish activity"? It is with any feeling but that of pleasure we thus bring it. We would have France and England in the bonds of secure friendship—the world would gain by it—but we cannot shut our eyes to facts and cry "Peace," when there is no peace, but rather discord, in prospect.', 'last_edit_date': '1883-05-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1883#article-18', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.618, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}]

hh: Inconsistent and skeptical British policies and actions, including misrepresentation of conflicts and reluctance to engage diplomatically, prolonged and escalated tensions with the Ashanti Kingdom.
result: The observations from both the General History of Africa textbook and The African Times news articles provide a comprehensive view of the inconsistent and skeptical British policies and actions that prolonged and escalated tensions with the Ashanti Kingdom. The textbook details how the British initially offered protection to the Ashanti, which was rejected by Prempeh, yet they continued to pressure the Ashanti by demanding the acceptance of a British Resident and the payment of a war indemnity. Prempeh's refusal led to a British military expedition, resulting in the arrest and deportation of Ashanti leaders, despite their decision not to resist militarily, indicating a reluctance to engage diplomatically and a preference for military intervention. The demand for the Golden Stool, a sacred symbol for the Ashanti, further escalated tensions, leading to the Asante uprising of 1900. This pattern of misrepresentation and disregard for Ashanti sovereignty is echoed in The African Times articles, which highlight the British government's reluctance to engage diplomatically, as evidenced by their refusal to officially receive Ashanti envoys in London and the lack of frankness in dealings with the Ashanti King. The articles also criticize the British for dismissing Ashanti invasions as mere trading expeditions and failing to support local tribes against Ashanti aggression. Inconsistent policies, such as issuing proclamations while threatening allied tribes and failing to block Ashanti supply routes, further illustrate the skepticism in their approach. Attempts to negotiate peace through gifts and the release of prisoners, only to be met with Ashanti contempt, underscore the inconsistency and skepticism in British actions. Together, these sources support the claim that British policies and actions significantly contributed to the prolongation and escalation of tensions with the Ashanti Kingdom.

The articles highlight the British government's reluctance to engage diplomatically, as seen in the refusal to officially receive Ashanti envoys in London and the lack of frankness in dealings with the Ashanti King. There is also mention of misrepresentation of conflicts, such as the British authorities' initial dismissal of Ashanti invasions as mere trading expeditions and the failure to provide adequate support to local tribes against Ashanti aggression. The articles criticize the British for their inconsistent policies, such as issuing proclamations while simultaneously threatening allied tribes, and for their failure to effectively block Ashanti supply routes. Additionally, the British government's attempts to negotiate peace through gifts and the release of prisoners, only to be met with Ashanti contempt, further illustrate the skepticism and inconsistency in their approach. These details align with the claim that British actions contributed to the prolongation and escalation of tensions with the Ashanti Kingdom.

To beat back the Asante, the British government launched one of the best organized campaigns of the period under the command of one of the most famous British officers of the day, General Garnet Wolseley. This answer can be documented from the very words of the contemporary African leaders themselves. The British had clashed with King William Pepple of Bonny as early as 1854, when they exiled him to Fernando Po, Ascension, Sierra Leone and London. They used disturbances caused by local feuds as an excuse. In 1887 they could find no such excuse when they removed Jaja of Opobo for his opposition to direct British trade in the Imo river valley. Twice he attempted to come to terms with Lugard, but the latter would not countenance these gestures. 2 7 Mwanga, the Kabaka of Buganda, at times tried to intercede on behalf of the Bunyoro king but to no avail. Eventually, Kabarega resorted to guerrilla warfare, probably the first of its kind in East Africa. He with› drew from Bunyoro to the Lango country in the north from where he harassed British forces time and again. Kabarega caused poison to be given to a friendly chief and he died, but I have had the poisoner killed.'$^{28}$ Thurston's description is a perfect example of the guerrilla tactic of withdrawing to a neighbouring country in order to harass occupying forces in one's own country. Kabarega was later joined in Lango by Mwanga, but their hide-out was stormed in 1899 and both kings were captured and taken to Kisimayu where Mwanga died in 1903. In this episode, we have both military confrontation and diplomatic initiative by Kabarega and Mwanga as will be shown in the sequel.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.67, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The British, Boers and Africans in South Africa, 1850-80', 'section_title': 'British expansion in South Africa 1870-80', 'content': "It was quite clear to the British government, which was also impressed by the arguments of the Anglican Bishop, John William Colenso, the only stout defender of the Hlubi chief, that injustices done to the Hlubi were the result of the excessive dread of the blacks held by the whites. Actual contacts made by Langalibalele with the Sotho, Ndebele, and Zulu before the rising, or rumours of them, further raised the spectre of a general African uprising against the balkanized whites in South Africa. Advised by Shepstone and others, Lord Carnarvon saw federation as the only answer to the 'terrible labyrinth' of South Africa. 33 As a first step, Lord Carnarvon secured the appointment of Sir Garnet Wolseley, recently returned from Kumasi where he had defeated the Asante, to deal with the Natal difficulties. Wolseley was instructed to gain control of African affairs for the Crown and to delay responsible government for the whites in preparation for a South African federation.$^{34}$ Since peaceful approaches would be pursued, Carnarvon became conciliatory to the Boers by dangling a settlement of the diamond fields disputes. [{'id': 316, 'article_title': 'Gold Coast', 'full_section_title': 'Gold Coast', 'last_edit_date': '01-14-1864', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_02_1864#article-4', 'issue_date': '23_02_1864', 'content': 'Dear Sir,—I did not write by last mail, having nothing of very great importance to communicate. Nor is there much worthy of note this month. Preliminary movements are taking place among the troops, that is all. Preliminary to what? you will say. No one can tell. Several detachments of troops have left this at various times during the last month for Mansco and the River Prah, at the former of which the Government is forming a depôt and magazine, &c., for ammunition and stores. But I very much doubt whether he will give in even when they are at the gates of Comassie—if they ever get there—which, unless they be greatly reinforced, I do not believe they ever will do.

However we may regret such a barbarous execution, still it must be admitted that it was done for the good of the public; and if it was unlawfully carried out, it was only because the Government that ought to have done it had long ceased to do its duty in those parts, and had formally withdrawn its protection from them. During the last twelve months the King of Ashantee has expended in Aquamboe alone no less than 1,500 or 2,000 ounces of gold in the purchase of salt, gunpowder, and lead, only. Without these supplies he must have given in to the demands of the British Government. The trade is still going on, or rather was, up to the time of the execution of Darko Yaw.

If the Government had despatched a force to occupy Aquamboe twelve months ago, it would have done much more to put an end to this war than could possibly be done by sending some 600 troops to perish in a useless campaign on the Prah.

It is very difficult for thinking men to believe that the British Government is sincerely desirous of bringing this disastrous war to a termination, for while the regular troops are encamped on the Prah, and supposed to be only waiting for the junction of the allied native forces before marching on Coomassie, the Government is issuing proclamations declaring its own people enemies; and to crown the whole, at the same time the Accra tribes are ordered to take the field, the Government is threatening the Kroboes with an invasion. In reply, his grace stated that he had considered the plans submitted to him, but he declined to give his adherence to them, and he enjoined upon the Governor that the principle of all military proceedings on that coast should be that of defence, and not that of aggression, and that on that principle alone were governors entitled to make war; but ultimately Governor Pine was authorized to strike a blow against the Ashantees, if it could be done consistently with the safety of the troops. The Duke of Newcastle had shown the utmost desire that the troops should be cared for in every way—(hear, hear)—and to inveigh against the Government for culpable negligence was to make a charge which could not be sustained. Stores of various kinds calculated to serve for a long time were gathered together, and the disasters which had occurred might be attributed to the two facts that the Tamar, which conveyed the troops, had arrived a month later than was anticipated, and that the wet season set in a month earlier than usual. The delay of the vessel was not remarkable when it was remembered that the troops sent from the West Indies had to be collected from different islands, and that the ship had to make her way in the face of the trade winds. He did not think, therefore, that there was anything very unusual in arriving a month after the time expected. As to the troops being located near Cape Coast Castle, it seemed that was one of the healthiest stations on the Coast. The principal charge seemed to be that thirteen officers had died. This return of the deaths of officers, it must be borne in mind, extended over the whole year. He would also remind the House that officers in the line, who were anxious for rapid promotion, often exchanged into West India Regiments, and he had made the attempt himself; but if they did so they acted with the knowledge that they were exposing themselves to a climate most deleterious to health. Bibrassee, near Croboe, Accra District,  
November 10, 1864.

Sir,—I had intended to forward you a long account of the present state of affairs in these Eastern Districts by this mail, but am prevented doing so till next month. I may, however, inform you that, bad as things were twelve months ago, they are now infinitely worse, and it is difficult to describe, and impossible to imagine, the state of utter confusion in which the whole country is at present.

this moment the Government have not the slightest influence or authority out of James Town and Christiansborg.

It is true that constables are daily sent to other places with summonses or warrants, but not the least notice is taken of them; and not unfrequently parties summoned or to be arrested take it into their heads to cudgel the constables within an inch of their lives, and then kick them out of the place; yet even when such an incident occurs, no attempt is made on the part of the Government to vindicate their authority.

The consequence is, that travelling in the interior, or indeed in any place five miles from James Fort, is absolutely dangerous, from the almost certainty of being panyarred (seized) and sold, if a black, or if an European or Mulatto, detained for some fictitious claim of a party with whom the individual so detained has no connexion. What with the stoppage of trade on account of the Croboe fine, the insecurity of life and property, and the expected disturbances on account of the spirit tax, the whole country is in a nice state, and you may expect to hear of some fine goings on ere long.

No doubt the British public will be glad to learn that, through the vigilance of their cruisers on this coast, the slaves intended for shipment in the celebrated steam slaver have become so expensive to their owners at Whydah and other places, that they have been resold, in the neighbourhood of the Volta, to the Bush people for half price, some having even found their way up here, and also at Accra.—Yours, &c.,  
VOLTA.
