T.'}, {'id': 2593, 'article_title': 'ASHANTI WAR OPERATIONS.—SIR GARNET WOLSELEY AND THE FANTI KINGS.', 'full_section_title': 'ASHANTI WAR OPERATIONS.—SIR GARNET WOLSELEY AND THE FANTI KINGS.', 'last_edit_date': '10-30-1873', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/30_10_1873#article-8', 'issue_date': '30_10_1873', 'content': "Sir Garnet Wolseley, who arrived at Cape Coast on the 2nd of October, lost no time in assembling the kings and chiefs, explaining his views, and instructing them as to the course he intended to pursue. His speech is before us. We are rather disappointed with it. He seems to have spoken too much from the top of his dignity. There is a cold, hard tone in his words, not calculated, we think, to induce that hearty co-operation so desirable, and so essential to success. We do not believe in the plan by which the daily supplies of rice and meat for the native troops, wherever these may be, are to be issued to the natives at the gates of Cape Coast Castle, to be thence transported to the troops by unassisted native effort. It is a mere scheme to save money and trouble; and unless we greatly err, will prove fatal to efficient native co-operation. And Sir Garnet is wrong in his facts. He told them it was not the Queen's war; it was their war. Now this is a serious mistake, and one that must have grated harshly on their ears. The Governors and Administrators, from M'Lean's time until now, have taken upon them the sole charge of the external relations of the Protected Territories. The kings and chiefs have often protested against the policy pursued; and have for years past predicted this war as a result. When, in view of the coming danger, the Fanti Confederation wished to organize against it, they were snubbed, threatened, and some of them imprisoned by the British authorities on a charge of high treason. How then can it be their war? The King of Akim asked in December last for arms and ammunition, and leave that he might attack the invading Ashantis; he was threatened with the sore displeasure of Her Majesty's Government; and thus the Ashantis were allowed free entry into the Protectorate. How then can it be their war? Sir Garnet sought to prove that it was their war, by quoting the Ashanti declaration of 1863-4 that they had come to war with the Fantis, not with the English. Competent judges believe that the invasion of 1863 would not have taken place had we not allowed some human sacrifices to pass unpunished, from which the King of Ashanti inferred that the British Government no longer exercised authority throughout the territories. They therefore made a distinction between us and the Fantis, hoping they might be allowed to eat up the latter. In January, February, and March last they must have believed we had now decided to allow them to do so. No, no! Sir Garnet. [{'document_title': 'THE ASHANTI WAR.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sir,—The "Protectorate" is again invaded by the Ashantis; and they are now but some seven or eight hours' journey from this.

Their progress from the Prah to Odoomassie has been uncontested—our feeble forces having fallen back as the enemy advanced—without any attempt to impede their onward course, as they are but a handful of men in comparison with the enormous force that our foes have brought into the field. Farther than this, our forces are in no way organized; they are like a flock without a shepherd. At the present moment we have not more than 4,000 or 5,000 men in the field, whilst the enemy is ten times as numerous. This is the result of the stupid, senseless, idiotic, and suicidal policy that has been pursued by our Government since 1864, and of the non-recognition of the Fanti Confederation by Her Majesty's Government.

Our policy since that time has made us the laughing-stock of the Ashantis, and has given them such confidence in their superiority over us that they look down upon us and our Government with contempt—and rightly so, too.

From whom did overtures first come for peace but from Cape Coast? It was our Government who sent the Honourable George Blankson on a wild goose chase to the Prah to induce the King of Ashanti to reopen trade; and that mission ended in the peace hoax of Colonel Conran. It was our Government that renewed negotiations for peace (for they were neither more nor less than that) after it had been so fooled by the King of Ashanti. It was our Government who made use of Prince Ansah's services, on his repeated visits to Coomasie, to endeavour to induce the Ashantis to let "bygones be bygones." It was our Government that, in spite of, and in direct opposition to the feelings and wishes of our peoples, sent up from here, from time to time, all Ashantis who had been captured in the campaign of 1863, and compelled our kings, chiefs, and others to give up all Ashanti prisoners, so that his Majesty of Ashanti might be led to lend a willing ear to their solicitations. It was our Government who sent the King of Ashanti "douceurs" (they call them presents), so that his Majesty might the more readily listen to their prayers for peace, and his Majesty willingly accepted their "presents," and laughed at them in his sleeves. It was our Government who sent to inform his Majesty that they were ready to double the annual stipend that he was receiving from the Dutch, as sop, provided the King would reopen trade, and not continue to frighten us out of our wits by threatening war, when we were desirous of going on our knees and sueing for peace. It was our Government that has committed a thousand other acts as impolitic to soothe the feelings of the outraged monarch of Ashanti; that danced to any and all the tunes that his Majesty played on his royal diplomatic fiddle, and that will continue to hop, skip, and dance, after the present disturbance, to whatever tune, the royal fiddler may think fit to treat them to.', 'last_edit_date': '1873-02-28', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/29_03_1873#article-1', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.735, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE ASHANTI WAR.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'No one believed throughout the protectorate, not even the gentleman who pretends to be omnipotent with the King of Ashanti, that his Majesty ever intended delivering up his German prisoners just now; and if the 1,000l. he asked for them had been sent up—and we believe that it would have been if this same gentleman could have had his way—his Majesty would have coolly pocketed the money, retained the white prisoners, and still have come to war. Everyone knows the Ashantis to be a treacherous lot of people; that they do not rashly pledge themselves to anything, and when they do, they have ulterior designs; and how the Government could have been induced to place any confidence in his Majesty of Ashanti, so as to compel our people from time to time to give up their prisoners, and fine and disgrace our kings and chiefs, on representations coming from such a source, is more than any sane man out here can understand. For him, and to suit him, and to oblige and to calm him, our border kings and chiefs were almost invariably maltreated. One can hardly find fault with the Government for this, as there was someone who was perpetually pouring into their ears stories of outrages committed on peaceable Ashanti traders, insults offered to his Majesty, and anything that would lead the Government to believe that we are and were always the provoking and aggressing party in all disturbances with the Ashantis. We hope that for the future the Government will not accept all such stories as truth without making inquiries of their own; and not appoint people who are related to this same person, or who can be induced by him or anybody else to distort or conceal facts; and that in future communications or negotiations with his Majesty of Ashanti, other native gentlemen, and Europeans of some experience here will be invited to the Councils of the Government. There are many gentlemen who are as well acquainted with the Ashantis as the one who is desirous of making people believe that he has but to say to him of Ashanti, "Come, and he cometh; Go, and he goeth;" and who informs the Ashantis that he is paramount here, and the authorities listen but to obey when he speaks.', 'last_edit_date': '1873-02-28', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/29_03_1873#article-1', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.74, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Letter from Kpong', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Alas, dear Mr. Editor! I am afraid our local Government here are neglecting one of the most important measures in this affair of the Ashantee war. No blockade can be effectual till it is carried out fully. Although Government has blockaded our frontiers toward the Ashantee territory, yet this part of the country, on the river Volta, is totally neglected, and now open to the Ashantees, where they receive all the munitions of war. In consequence of this, a vigorous trade is going on from this and Adda and Quittah, in salt, tobacco, gin, arms, and gunpowder, in exchange for gold dust and slaves. This is a policy that we stupid people here don't understand. Through this neglect the Ashantees have lately committed some outrages here.

Some time last month the messengers of the King of Ashantee arrived here in the town of Assabi, in the district of Krepee, and under cover of night cut off the heads of two of Her Majesty's subjects, by names Quamlin Savili and Kuaku Dabonnie, natives of Assabi, in our Krepee jurisdiction.

It has since come out that this outrage was committed by sanction and connivance of the chief of Assabi, by name Quamlin Minta, who is supposed to be intriguing with the Ashantees. On investigating the case before the supreme chief, Nijarkon, it was further proved that Minta has had a criminal connexion with the wife of one of the unfortunate men. He is now bailed out before Chief Nijarkon till something is heard from proper authorities. I will write you something more about this affair, and about the change that has come over the people in other parts of our territories with regard to the Ashantee war. It seems to

me that the sufferings inflicted on the country last year in consequence of the shameful military mismanagement, which allowed the Ashantees to ravage in all directions, have not only put an end to the enthusiasm the people felt when the war began, but quite sickened them of it. The truth is, they do not believe in the English power as they did before the last campaign.", 'last_edit_date': '1863-12-08', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_01_1864#article-7', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.732, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE ASHANTI WAR.', 'section_title': '', 'content': '**WEST AFRICA** has once again seriously occupied the public press, and therefore, we may suppose, in some degree, the public mind of Great Britain. The preparations which have been, and still are, making by Her Majesty’s Government, are on a scale of sufficient magnitude to attract notice, and it is not surprising, therefore, that during a Parliamentary recess, all our daily contemporaries, who have been accustomed to turn their blind side upon West African matters, as too insignificant for serious regard, should have devoted a portion of their columns, morning after morning, to the news from the West Coast, to Government preparations, and supposed plans and objects. Nor is it strange that quite a number of persons, who have been or are more or less connected with the West Coast, officially or commercially, should have rushed in to the assistance of the editors, with statements, criticisms, plans, and objections, of very varied degrees of truth and importance. Leader after leader, letter after letter, have given to this embryo Ashanti war an importance greatly disproportioned to that of any operations that have hitherto marked its progress. When we called attention in January last to the well-authenticated fact of a large force of Ashantis having crossed the Prah and destroyed several villages, the Administrator at Cape Coast and the Government at home preferred to ignore the whole affair. If Col. Harley, instead of pooh-poohing the information furnished by the native kings on the frontier with that supercilious contempt which but too often characterizes military officials, had sent up the small supplies of ammunition requested, the invading forces might have received a check sufficient to have caused them to abandon their enterprise. Instead of this, the frontier kings were peremptorily ordered to abstain from all acts of hostility against the body of Ashanti traders, as it suited the then views and purposes of the Administrator to designate them. Unimpeded, therefore, in their early operations, and not meeting with resistance in any form, the advanced corps was followed by a main army, of sufficient magnitude to force the knowledge of the disagreeable fact of their presence in the country upon the reluctant mind of the Exeçutive. But even then that Executive confined itself to the issuing of proclamations and the dispatch of special commissioners, attended by a certain number of Houssa police, with instructions to observe and report, but not under any circumstances to come into collision with the invading forces. Nothing effectual was done to promote the cohesion of the native tribes, to organize them and lead them against the enemy. They were told that it was their duty to defend their country, but they were not furnished with adequate means for doing this. Ammunition, when granted, was doled out as if every pound of powder was more valuable than a native life; nor was any attempt made to assist them in obtaining such supplies of provisions as would enable them to keep the field. All this was exposed in our columns, wherein we also showed, by brief but graphic accounts of the actions fought, that if properly organized, officered, led, and supplied, the Fantis, whom it is so much the fashion to vilify as cowards, would have of themselves sufficed to turn back the destructive tide of invasion. There can be no doubt whatever that at that time it was the deliberate official intention to limit British protection and action to a mere meagre contribution of arms and ammunition, provided the Ashantis did not advance to a point which must be considered as endangering Cape Coast, Elmina, or other Coast settlements. Too much was said at that time about the advisability of giving the Ashantis a port on the Coast, and consequently a permanent footing there, to allow or to admit the possibility of such a compromise not having been seriously admitted into the Executive mind. But such a project was of too infamous a nature to allow of its even passing beyond the obscure stage. It would not bear the light. It would have been a surrender of the lives of every man, woman, and child in the protected territories to the knife of the Ashanti executioners, with no more noble aim than that of our being permitted to levy certain duties, producing a large revenue, to be eaten up by an official staff. But although this infamous idea could not pass beyond the realm of ideas, or even ripen into fact, it had done a mischief for which Great Britain will now have to atone, by the sacrifice of many valuable lives and the expenditure of no inconsiderable a sum of money. The Ashantis could not attach any other meaning to the abstention of the British authorities from all active participation in the Fanti resistance than that the British were now too weak to resist them, or intended to abandon the Coast should sufficient pressure be brought to bear upon them. They could not, naturally enough, comprehend a policy which should allow them to advance without serious resistance to within a few miles of the seat of Government, if there was any intention of a resolute defence of the Coast Settlements. And so they pressed on, until their interference with the British bombardment of Elmina opened their eyes to the error into which they had fallen. It had then become too late for them to retreat; they had settled down into occupation of large districts as conquerors, bringing down their wives and slaves, and otherwise manifesting a fixed determination to extend the frontiers of Ashanti from the Prah to the ocean. And there they still are; the loss they suffered before Elmina has induced a caution which keeps them at a respectful distance from that place and Cape Coast, although they have never ceased to threaten both, but which has not prevented their detaching sufficient forces to Ashanti and Appolonia to enable them so to dominate the public mind, as to detach kings, chiefs, and people from British allegiance, as evinced at the interview of Commodore Commerell with the King of Chamah, and the subsequent deplorable events at Chamah and Tacorady. What can an impartial chronicler or historian say to all this? What but that, if it has been the result of an honest British policy, that policy has been an exceedingly ignorant and contemptible one; and if the result of an incipient dishonest policy, it meets with the retribution it deserves, in being compelled to an expenditure of life and money the limits of which no one can at present foresee; and to a possibly total reversion of ideas and feelings with regard to settlements which have been looked upon as worthless and compromising—a legacy of national slave trade iniquity, involving constant loss and disaster, without any chance of compensation either in honour or profit—either pecuniary, moral, or national. For our own part, it is well known that we believe in a great future of those countries—a future which we believe will be importantly hastened by this war, which, however, we have done our best to avert, by persistently clamouring for measures which, if they had found favour in Colonial office eyes, and been adopted, would have made it for ever impossible.', 'last_edit_date': '1873-09-29', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/29_09_1873#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.728, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': "Mr. Gladstone's Declaration on the Ashanti War", 'section_title': '', 'content': 'we shall, I hope, seek to draw from what has happened a lesson on the duty of avoiding in future the first entrance into equivocal and entangling engagements. Meantime, we repose the utmost confidence in the British General, officers, and soldiers; and we cherish the hope that we are about to emerge at an early date, and on good terms, from the conflict." The address from which this extract is taken, is one of great power and intense interest, shadowing forth, as it does, changes of extreme importance to the whole British community, and which must influence materially the future destinies of the country. Nor have we any fault to find with the above observations relative to the Ashanti War, except in the paragraphs as to "the establishment of friendship with the Ashantees," and "the duty of avoiding in future the first entrance into equivocal and entangling engagements." The latter is a fine phrase, meaning nothing, and copied out of Mr. Bright's textbook—a bad volume for a Minister to study as regards foreign relations. Should equivocal and entangling engagements appear to be necessary in the future, for forwarding some great object of Imperial policy, they will be entered into then as they have been entered into in the past. One unacquainted with the history of our connection with the Gold Coast countries, would imagine that, by some act of official stupidity, we had recently entered into engagements which had led to this Ashanti War. Nothing can be farther from the truth. Our engagements with the Gold Coast at this time—those engagements which have forced us into the present Ashanti War—are the unavoidable legacy of the foreign slave trade we ruthlessly carried on there for more than a century, and the efforts since made by the conscience-stricken British nation to put a final end to that abominable traffic. We were thus naturally led to, and detained on, the Gold Coast. We could not remain there without being supreme, and asserting and exercising our supremacy. In the exercise of this supremacy, we became naturally the protectors of the Gold Coast against enemies by sea or land. We consequently took upon ourselves the direction of its external relations, among the chief of which were those with Ashanti; and if there is now a war between us and Ashanti, that war is not the result of Fantee action, nor of "our having entered into equivocal engagements," but of a culpable neglect and mismanagement on our part, the responsibility for which does not attach to the present Administration alone, but to many successive Administrations, which have chosen to shut their eyes to, and take no efficient measures to prevent, results which every unofficial person connected with those countries could foresee. Then, as regards friendship with Ashanti, as a result of the present advance on Kumasi. Should the Ashanti power survive the victory which we are bound to obtain over it at whatever cost, there could not be any friendship between it and us, except by a total change in its principles, customs, and character. Kumasi is a charnel-house, a slaughter-pen, where the blood of innocent human victims is incessantly flowing. Hitherto we have not been responsible for this, save that by a national effort, such as Ashanti has now forced upon us, we might have put an end to it. But if we entered into relations with it (after having conquered it) that would re-establish and perpetuate it, we should be responsible, and guilty as a nation, before God and man. Friendship between light and darkness is not less impossible than friendship, under such circumstances, between Christian Britain and the Ashanti which has been known of up to this present time. But our own opinion, expressed at the commencement of the present operations, and which we still retain, is that there will not be any danger of our falling into such a snare of guilty complicity with a murderous superstition, because the Ashanti power, losing all its prestige by our successful advance on Kumasi, will fall in pieces. It has only existed hitherto through the mutual jealousies of divers people, whom it has played one against another, while using them all for its aggressive operations. We may be mistaken; but this, we repeat, is our confirmed opinion; and it will be well for the Administration of which Mr. Gladstone is the head that this contingency should be maturely considered, in order that they may be able to deal in the most advantageous manner with the emergency should it arise.', 'last_edit_date': '1874-01-29', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/29_01_1874#article-14', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.755, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE ASHANTI ENVOYS IN ENGLAND.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sir,—The Ashanti Ambassador has consulted me in reference to the various articles appearing in the Press touching on this subject, and he has requested me in fairness to ask that you will permit me to make some comment thereon inasmuch as the English version of the matter has alone been presented to the public. There appears to be some foundation for believing that a military expedition has been sent to Coomassie, or is about to be, for the purposes of compelling the King of Ashanti to accept a British Resident at his capital, whether the same be just, expedient, or otherwise. It is but fair (and Englishmen always boast of their fairness) that our Government and the King of Ashanti should have the like opportunities of putting their case before the British public, although I am aware that the public Press is not exactly the constitutional medium generally appealed to. The Ambassadors, however, are in London, and having appealed to the Government for a hearing (which has been refused), they can but now appeal to the Press for the ventilation of their alleged grievances—the more especially as I understand that the British Government are not slow on occasions to recognise that as a correct medium. According to my instructions, it would appear that Prempeh was not elected to the stool of Ashanti by us, so much so that we refused to interfere with the Ashantees' selection at all, but fully recognised their action by having present our official representative at the coronation, and acknowledged him as King of Ashanti. There cannot be any manner of doubt about this, as it is borne out by the Blue records from 1888 to 1894. I am also told that when the British Government submitted the proposal that a British Resident should be received, the King was correctly designated by us as "King of Ashanti," although at that time we were aware of the fact now alleged that "the old Ashanti Confederation" has been broken up"—a confederation which, I am instructed, had never existed. My clients emphatically deny that the King has ever broken or violated any of his treaty engagements. They deny, too, that he has countenanced human sacrifice, a fact which I am told is negatived by our own records; nor has he, it is urged, hampered trade and attacked tribes under British protection. It is also denied that he has raided for slaves. On the contrary, my clients inform me that the King has cause to complain of want of frankness towards him, and that our representative in the Gold Coast, while professing friendship towards the King, has, as a fact, been acting contrary to his pledges. The King is prepared to open his country to British skill, and does not seek to hamper trade as is suggested. The Ambassadors submit that the fact of Ashanti being "within the sphere of British influence" does not carry away the King's independence as a sovereign, nor justify the hostile attitude our Government are assuming. That the King is an independent sovereign, there cannot be any question in the face of the reply of the Under-Secretary of State for the Colonies, given in February last, and if England claims the right to send a mission to the King whenever she feels inclined, my clients urge that the same privilege should be extended to their King when he is acting with bona fides and in the honest belief that he is acting within his rights. The mission have travelled some thousands of miles to discuss the position and treat with her Majesty's advisers, and if only on the grounds of fair play, and apart from any precedent, the Government could receive them, there certainly would not be any particle of reason why one ounce of blood should be shed. Of course, in expressing the foregoing views I am carrying out my instructions, not, however, with any doubts as to the justice of the King's claim, but with a keen sense of the Ambassador's sincerity.—I am, sir, yours, &c.,', 'last_edit_date': '1895-10-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1895#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.742, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Anticipated Trouble in Ashanti', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Just as we are going to press, we learn through Reuter's Agency that, in consequence of the hostile action of the King of Coomassie (the old Ashanti confederation having been broken up), the Government has instructed the Governor of the Gold Coast to send Colonel Sir Francis Scott home for the purpose of consulting with the authorities as to the force required to deal with the troubles, and whether it will be necessary to despatch additional troops from England. Of course, an Ashanti war would not be anything like as large an undertaking as the expedition of twenty years ago: many who then fought against the British are now living quietly under their protection.

It appears that the King of Coomassie is alleged to have violated treaty engagements with Great Britain by the continuation of the practice of human sacrifices, as well as by hampering trade and attacking neighbouring tribes which are under British protection. There are other causes of complaint, one of which is the difficulty he has placed in the way of the appointment of a British Resident at Coomassie. Communications on these subjects have for some time been taking place between the King of Coomassie and the Governor of the Gold Coast. The former has been temporising, but there is still hope that the differences now existing may be arranged without a resort to war. It is nevertheless felt necessary to be prepared for a less favourable contingency, and with this view, as mentioned above, Sir Francis Scott, Inspector of Constabulary of the Gold Coast, has been summoned home for the purpose of conferring with the War Office about the preparations for the military expedition to Ashanti, should war prove inevitable.

Several Native envoys from Ashanti recently arrived in London with a commission from their king to negotiate with the British Government on some of the questions now at issue. These envoys were not, however, officially received or recognised by the Government; and as Ashanti is within the British sphere of influence, they were advised to make their communications through the Governor of the Gold Coast, the authorised representative of the British Government in the district to which they belong.", 'last_edit_date': '1895-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1895#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.742, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Party Criticisms on Ashanti War Operations', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'but can scarcely fail to be regarded with a mixture of sorrow and disgust by all who are not blinded by ignorance or party feeling, which, like the snake, converts the most delicious things into poison. We have never, in African matters, been partizans of either Conservative or Liberal Administrations. Both, and equally, have, to our mind, dealt neglectfully and unwisely, and therefore unjustly and injuriously, with Western Africa. But when we see an attempt to overwhelm the late Administration with such questions as the following, we become for a moment partizans of the late Government, notwithstanding all its errors and shortcomings, of which we have felt personally the sad effects. "How did the quarrel with King Koffee Kalcalli arise? In obedience to what principle of national duty did we send an expedition beyond the Prah? What advantage have we secured by burning down Kumasi, and shattering the power of the only negro State which offered any semblance of a stable government? What do we hope to gain by peace and friendship with the Ashantees, supposing that we have inclined them thereto by the measures we have taken for their destruction? We have to satisfy our national conscience on all these points, or else we shall have won what is something less than even a barren triumph." This is meant, no doubt, to be a formidable indictment, yet the answer is simple enough. The quarrel with King Kalcalli dates from his predecessor's reign, in 1862, when the Gold Coast authorities refused to deliver up the refugee "Ganim." No peace has since been made. It was always understood that the Ashantees were busy accumulating ammunition, and the Dutch withdrawal and Elmina discontent, brought the slumbering hostilities to a head again. It is not difficult to prove that it was our duty to rid the Protectorate of them. The only error was, that that was not understood at the commencement, before they half-ruined the country and bearded us in our seacoast forts. It being our duty to get rid of them, it must have been equally our duty to get rid of them effectually. This could only be done by what has since been done—by following them into their own territory, destroying their military prestige, burning their capital, and shattering the power "of the only negro State which offered any semblance of a stable government." Detestable government, might well have been said. As to what we hope to gain by peace and friendship with them, after the measures we have taken for their destruction, the reply is not difficult. Having gained a full assurance of peace for the Protectorate, by destroying the military prestige and power of its only enemy, we give that humbled enemy liberty to carry on, as heretofore, that trade with the sea-coast without which he cannot live; and which he could not have ventured on without a treaty, because the Assins, Wassaws, Denkeras, &c., would have murdered and plundered the traders, on the ground of their being still enemies. The Ashantees, and the people of their formerly tributary states and others beyond, cannot exist without communication with the Coast, for that most indispensable article, salt, and many others. We wish them to have these; we have an advantage in their coming to buy them in our territory: we guarantee them, by treaty, peaceable access, on certain terms. This will give them again their old advantages as intermediate traders between the seacoast and the people beyond. In the supposition that there is an engagement on the part of the King of Ashanti that there shall be no more human sacrifices, this is sneered at as having "a shining moral appearance." When we reflect on the myriads of human beings that have been offered there in sacrifice, until the whole atmosphere of the capital was poisoned by the sickly exhalation from human gore and putrefying carcases, we feel ineffable disgust at this "shining moral appearance." If no other good end had been obtained by us, this one alone, if obtained, is worthy of a great Christian civilized nation; and, should be deemed, if power has duties as well as rights, a full and exceeding recompense for the effort we have made, even though the "sacrifice of other lives which it has entailed" should all be debited to this account, which we deny. As to the war "having been always unnecessary," we have not space to join issue on the point as it deserves. All we shall say is, it can only be deemed unnecessary, provided it could be established that, if earlier measures had been taken by the Cape Coast Government to aid the native tribes of the Protectorate, they alone would have sufficed for rolling back the invasion. We always believed this might have been effected. But even then the war could scarcely be deemed unnecessary, as the territories would have been continually threatened with invasion and devastation, murder, and all other enormities of barbarian inroads. There was no permanent remedy to be found, no permanent security to be obtained, save by the invasion of Ashanti. This has been, happily, accomplished, and however party feeling may suffer at the too speedy and economical success, we rejoice that there is no longer any probability of our ever having again to deplore an Ashanti invasion of the Gold Coast.', 'last_edit_date': '1874-03-28', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/28_03_1874#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.728, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Menace of War by Ashanti', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'circumstances, of appointing a mere military man. Sir Samuel Rowe having had experience in those countries, having been at Coomassie with Sir John Glover, and shared, no doubt, with Sir John the disgust of not being allowed to remain there awhile and place the affairs of the countries beyond the Prah on a permanent peace footing, he knows the people with whom he has to deal, and has no more fear of an Ashantee than of any other untutored savage. Such a man, we hope, will see the necessity of something more than to be content that no invasion has taken place, or that it has been repulsed. It is not compatible with the dignity of the British Government, or with the duty of the latter to the countries under its protection, that the latter should remain liable to a repetition of the “Golden Axe” insult whenever it may suit a vain and ignorant barbarian to inflict it. Sir Samuel Rowe will, we hope, recognize the necessity, and make that necessity to be fully comprehended in Downing-street, that a definite line of policy must be adopted, and certain efficient measures be taken and maintained, as regards Ashanti and the other native States beyond the River Prah such as shall put an end for ever to the possibility of the recurrence of insulting threats, with their disturbing influence on industrial pursuits in the countries of the protectorate, and needless expense both to the Imperial and Colonial Exchequer. To give security to a country as well as to preserve peace and order in it, is one of the first duties of a sovereign power. This security the British Government must now give to the Fantee countries. We have made them dependent on us for protection, and we must make that protection efficient—not spasmodic, according to the varying humour of an insolent neighbouring barbarian, but constant and assured beyond the possibility of doubt. If it be said that the British Parliament, uninstructed by the fate of Old Rome, would not consent to any charge on the British Exchequer for any requisite measurer, then we say that the revenues of the protected territories, now not less than 100,000l. a year, are adequate for securing the interest on a public loan for the small amount that would be required. We have before contended that this revenue should be made available for guaranteeing railroads, and for other works of public improvement, that may aid in the development of the natural resources, vegetable and mineral, of those territories; but though we have the construction of railways there deeply at heart, we would postpone these and all other aids to industry in favour of that one great first aid without which all others are liable to fail in their object—security, perfect security, for life and property against the threat of barbarian invasion. We venture to hope that Sir Samuel Rowe will be the instrument through whom this great aid will be obtained. For ages past Ashanti has been the curse of all neighbouring countries. It was delivered into our hands in 1873-4 for destruction, and we failed in our duty, allowed it to be revived, and again to become insolent, and are now suffering the temporary disturbance of important industries, and compelled to incur considerable expense, because of that insolence. The line must be drawn somewhere; let it be drawn at the late “Golden Axe” menace; and then, within a few years, our great expectations of national wealth to come from those territories will be realized.', 'last_edit_date': '1881-03-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_03_1881#article-16', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.727, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE END AND PURPOSE OF THE ASHANTI WAR.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Peace, to large and populous countries of the interior of Africa. We cannot conceive any reason why those countries should not contain some of those to-be blessed people, of whom we have thus made mention; and if they do so contain them, and these are to be reached only by the prostration and destruction of that most awfully blood-stained kingdom, this war will be made an instrument for opening the way to those who will willingly set forth with the glad tidings. Again, if they do so contain them, and they are only thus to be reached, the honour which God thus offers to our beloved country is in our eyes so great, as to outweigh a hundredfold any temporary pecuniary outlay, or any sacrifices far more painful, that the procuring of it may involve. And while we look at the progress of events during the last fifty years of our relations with the Gold Coast countries, we cannot avoid the conviction that there has been a gradual Divine preparation for Great Britain, of this honour which she has sought to repudiate and to avoid, even to the very verge of national dishonour. We believe that, however nations, and especially so-called Christian nations, may desire to live and act for their own ends, interests, and purposes alone, an overruling Divine Governor shapes that selfish life and purposes to the accomplishment of His own great supreme designs as regards the children of men. In the pursuit of that abominable object—the carrying on of a foreign slave trade, a cruel dealing in human flesh for gain—several European nations, and among them Great Britain, obtained sea-side settlements on the Gold Coast. We need not enter here upon any detail of the causes and events which led to the final extinction of that sinful trade there carried on. Suffice it to say, that by conquest and purchase, Great Britain became, with the Dutch, the only possessors of sea-coast dominions there; and that, finally, so late as 1872, the Dutch, compelled by native African pressure—which Great Britain not only did not aid or assist, but condemned and opposed—were glad to abandon all the posts they occupied, upon the mere payment to them by Great Britain of the money value of the stores they left behind them. A few words will suffice to show how important a difference was thus made in the position and responsibilities of Great Britain as regards the Protected Territories and Ashanti. The Ashantees are the hereditary and deadly enemies of the people of the Protectorate, whom they have long regarded as their rightful prey, and have sought to annihilate, that they might themselves enter into undisputed possession of these countries, and their coveted sea-coast. While the Dutch were joint possessors with the English of the sea-board of the Gold Coast, the latter were greatly restricted in their action. The Dutch were always friends and allies of the Ashantees. They had still a little slave trade of their own under another name, the victims of which were brought down from Ashanti. Whenever the Ashantees made an invasion of the Protected Territories, they received ammunition and arms, and all necessary supplies, through the Dutch towns. By the retirement of the Dutch last year, this was all changed, and we were brought face to face with Ashanti. In the furtherance of a most short-sighted and selfish policy, the British Government had of late years openly proclaimed that the people of the so-called Protectorate must in future depend upon themselves alone for their defence against their deadly enemy. This, too, while they still retained solely in their own hands the conduct of all relations with that enemy, which became thus British relations, and not theirs; while, too, they exacted obedience to all behests, so far as they chose, throughout the entire Protectorate; levied, collected, and retained for their own use the entire import duties, amounting, in 1872, to above 50,000l.; and not only refused to allow, but put down an effort at native union for defence against the Ashantees, for making roads and educating the people; and this, as it seemed to us, chiefly because it would necessarily involve their apportioning to the Fanti Confederation a share of the revenues they levied, and the formation of a native organized military force, not immediately under the command of the British Administrator. The Ashantees saw and knew of all this; they could not fail to do so, because the British administrative voice was continuously loud that all the people of the Protectorate could expect from them in any future invasion was a small supply of arms and ammunition. Was not this an encouragement by Great Britain to the Ashantees to invade the territories which she thus declared she would neither herself protect, nor allow the natives to organize efficiently to protect? It was such an encouragement, and was followed by just such results as might have been anticipated. We knew, of course, that, in the event of a formidable invasion, the British Government would be forced to take the field, sooner or later, against the aggressors, though the Ashantees believed that they would not; being encouraged therein by the British authorities treating for the ransom of the German missionaries whom they had kidnapped within the bounds of the Protectorate. And the British local authorities seem to have been of the same opinion; having, if we may judge by the course pursued, adopted Sir Charles Adderley's principles and ideas, that the British Government occupied their positions on the Gold Coast merely for purposes of trade; that it was quite indifferent to them whether the trade was with Fantees or Ashantees, and consequently that there was no reason why the Ashantees should not be allowed to annihilate the natives, and occupy their territories, provided always they respected those British positions, and would pay the Customs' duties levied there. The Ashanti monarch therefore sent the vanguard of his army across the River Prah early in December, 1872. They commenced by destroying the villages in their route. The King of Akim dispatched messengers in hot haste to Colonel Harley at Cape Coast, informing him of what had happened, of the imminent danger, and requesting a supply of arms and ammunition, that he might attack the invaders. Colonel Harley, however, was too fully imbued with Sir Charles Adderley's principles and ideas, to view these things in the same light as they appeared to the King of Akim. Instead of sending the prayed-for supplies, he ordered the King of Akim to abstain from all hostilities, unless he chose to incur the heavy displeasure of Her Majesty's Government. The result was what might have been expected. Encouraged by the absence of all opposition, fortified by Colonel Harley's pacific dispositions, in their belief that the Fantees were to be entirely given up to their tender mercies, the Ashantees flooded in. Time came, when their large army was within thirty or forty miles of Cape Coast (having destroyed some fifty or sixty villages), that Colonel Harley could not regard them any longer as ardent traders, coming down to fill the colonial chest with Customs' duties; but, still true to the Adderley principles and ideas, in sending up a couple of officers with some Houssas to inspect and report, he is understood to have ordered that under no circumstances should they fire a shot against the invaders. The Fantees had then advanced a large force against them. Those officers, with the Houssas, saw the Fantees overpowered in fight by them, yet abstained from giving any aid. Is it a matter of surprise that the Ashantees should at last have believed that not only had the British abandoned the Fantees to them, but that, with a little pressure, they would give up Elmina and Cape Coast Castle also, and leave the Gold Coast to their sole possession? We are merely showing how this Ashanti War has come about; that Great Britain has brought it entirely on herself, through the prevalence of dishonouring administrative principles and ideas, and the dignified incompetence of her local executive head; that she is forced into it against her will, through neglect of sacred and obvious duties; and that, as thus now acting in opposition to her own wishes and desires, she is—if she will now perform her duty adequately, persistently, and inflexibly—an instrument in the hands of an overruling Providence for working out a great intent. It is indeed lamentable to behold the lengths to which political party feeling will impel public writers, even in matters of national import. We are sorry to be compelled to say that, if we may judge by the tone of their public organs, the now dominant political party find the Ashanti success of Sir Garnet Wolseley, almost as palatable as gall and wormwood. hh: Diplomatic strategies employed by the Ashantee King, including the release of prisoners and efforts to settle debts, reflect attempts to navigate colonial pressures and improve relations with both African kingdoms and the British.
result: The diplomatic strategies employed by the Ashantee King, Prempeh I, in navigating colonial pressures are depicted with varying emphases in the General History of Africa textbook and The African Times news articles. The textbook highlights Prempeh's resistance to British colonial demands, such as rejecting offers of protection, refusing the stationing of a British Resident in Kumasi, and declining to pay a war indemnity, which ultimately led to a British expedition against Asante. It underscores Prempeh's broader strategy of defending sovereignty through diplomacy, yet it does not mention the release of prisoners or efforts to settle debts as part of these strategies. In contrast, The African Times articles provide details supporting the claim that the Ashantee King engaged in diplomatic efforts to improve relations with both African kingdoms and the British. The articles note the King's actions, such as releasing Ashantee refugees and potentially English prisoners, and his willingness to settle debts, as evidenced by communications with the Fantees regarding payment for goods and the release of detained individuals. These actions, along with sending ambassadors to Cape Coast and negotiating with British officials, illustrate a strategic approach to managing relations and addressing grievances. However, the articles also highlight challenges, including internal dissent and the complexities of maintaining alliances, adding nuance to the King's diplomatic efforts. Together, these sources present a multifaceted view of Prempeh I's strategies, reflecting both resistance and attempts to navigate colonial pressures through diplomacy.

This is a question that has so far not been seriously considered by historians, African or European, but it needs to be answered. The answer is quite clear and unequivocal: an overwhelming majority of African authorities and leaders were vehemently opposed to this change and expressed their determination to maintain the status quo and, above all, to retain their sovereignty and independence, an issue on which virtually all of them were not in any way prepared to compromise. [{'id': 317, 'article_title': 'ASHANTEE WAR.', 'full_section_title': 'ASHANTEE WAR.', 'last_edit_date': '01-13-1864', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_02_1864#article-5', 'issue_date': '23_02_1864', 'content': "Mansoo, of recent date, is remarkable for its being the croom where, a few months ago, a force of no less than 9,000 armed men assembled to watch the invading army of the King of Ashantee. It has a beautiful river, which swells considerably after a heavy fall of rain, and which alone gives life to the place. It is a most important and well-selected position for a depôt; it being on a hill, perfectly surrounded by lofty evergreen trees, as well as having an easy supply of good fresh water, at once gives to it that excellency which only a few places on the Gold Coast can boast of. The town being small, it is well adapted for building a stockade, in which a few rockets and field-pieces, with the rifles of the soldiers, will keep at bay any number of the Ashantees. But to prevent any further inroads of that powerful enemy on the protectorate territory, the occupation of Mansoo is insufficient. The aide-de-camp of his Excellency the Governor was, therefore, sent further on, to the Prah, to report on the adaptability of Prahsoo for the formation of a second and more advanced camp. His report is very favourable. The embankment at this side of the Prah is a great deal higher than at the Ashantee side; consequently, a few field pieces will be sufficient to prevent the crossing of any number of the Ashantees at that place, and well protect the advance of the army into the Ashantee frontier, should such an advance become necessary. Prahsoo, therefore, will be our next post, and I hope I shall hereafter be able to give you a full and perfect account of it, as I intend, please God, to go up there.

On the 1st January, the 1st Battalion of the 1st Division of the Army of Observation, commanded by Captain Mackay, arrived at Mansoo. On it devolves the arduous duty of clearing the bush and building up stockades. A better officer than Captain Mackay, I think, could not possibly be found to superintend such a work. He attends personally to it, and directs the performance of every work by the men, and, therefore, everything is properly done. The 2nd Battalion of the 1st Division will arrive at Mansoo in the course of a few days.

Before the commencement of the late campaign the King of Ashantee sent messengers to Attah, King of Eastern Akim, asking him not to molest his army whilst crossing the Prah, as he had sent it down to take Ajman's head. These men were sent as prisoners to the King of Accra. They were subsequently taken on board the Rattlesnake, about six months ago, on a cruise to different parts of the Coast, and were landed the other day at Cape Coast Castle. The Governor has given them leave to return to their country under an escort of three soldiers (and with an interpreter) to the Prah. This, I think, may facilitate a reconciliation between the two governments. But of one thing"}, {'id': 1244, 'article_title': 'Refugees Sent Back to Ashantee', 'full_section_title': 'Refugees Sent Back to Ashantee', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_12_1867#article-6', 'issue_date': '23_12_1867', 'content': "Sir,—As a supplement to what I wrote you last mail, I have now to report that, through the instrumentality of Mr. Thos. Hughes, of this town, a lot of Ashantee refugees have been given up (though very reluctantly) by the bush chiefs, and that the Administrator, Mr. Ussher, has returned them to Kumasi, in charge of Prince Ansah, who has gone on another visit to his royal relative there. It is hoped and believed that this very just and prudent measure of Mr. Ussher's will tend greatly to allay those old grievances which have been the source of those unfriendly relations between Cape Coast and Kumasi, that have been productive of so much harm to the protectorate and to the trade of this place with Ashantees.—Yours truly,"}, {'id': 1736, 'article_title': 'An Ashantee Message to the Fantee Confederation', 'full_section_title': 'An Ashantee Message to the Fantee Confederation', 'last_edit_date': '12-30-1869', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_02_1870#article-13', 'issue_date': '23_02_1870', 'content': "Sir,—We have great pleasure to enclose for your information the message from the King of Ashantee, and shall be glad if you will publish the same in your valuable columns:—

Markeessim, Dec. 8, 1869,

Statement of the message from the King of Ashantee, delivered before the Kings, President and Council of the Government of Fantee Confederation, on Tuesday, the 7th instant, by Acquabina Ornoomaful, the King's Court Crier.

1. The King of Ashantee sends his compliments to the Fantees, returns his best thanks to them, and is highly pleased with their allowing Captain Aggin the liberty of sending one of the detained Ashantee traders with a message to him.

2. By this messenger Captain Aggin states to him that he went to trade on the River Prah, and was there detained with a party of his traders; and, further, that he (Aggin) is given to understand by the Assins that the King of Ashantee had some time ago bought a number of pieces of silk velvet and damasks from them (the Assins) without paying for them, and they are detained for the settlement of the value of these goods, and also for some Fantees, Denkirahs, Assins, Warsaws, and Akims, &c., already detained in Ashantee, and he (Aggin) desires the King will see to it that these are sent back and restored.

3. In reply to the message of Captain Aggin, the King desires his compliments to the Fantees, and respectfully requests them to ascertain from the Assins, or the parties concerned, the amount of claim due to them by the King of Ashantee and his people, and send him a faithful and correct account of these transactions, and he will readily send payment, and will also set at liberty all the persons hitherto detained in his kingdom.

4. In reference to his people now encamping in Aquamboe, the King states that Aquetoe, King of that place, had been formerly his man-wife, or peculiar ally, and during the last wars he revolted; but he now sends a message to him, assuring him that he would wish to resume his former allegiance with him; and that the King would let bygones be bygones, and send him an assistance of troops to enable him to put down his Inquonah or Awoonah people, who had risen up against him in consequence of his going to renew his alliance with the King of Ashantee; and who had, moreover, refused to agree with him being under the King of Ashantee as his subjects.

5. With regard also to the Ashantees now in Aöwin, the King states that Andor, the Elmina chief, was sent up to Coomassie in attendance at the late King's funeral rites, and as he had since received information that the road to Elmina by Prahsue had been blockaded or stopped, he considered it safe and prudent to send him back to Elmina by the Aöwin direction, duly escorted by one of his captains, Ackampon Asantoo, with troops, who himself had been trained up at Elmina, with instructions to the King of Aöwin to have a passage procured for him for his conveyance by water down to Elmina."}, {'id': 1882, 'article_title': 'West African News', 'full_section_title': 'West African News', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1870#article-2', 'issue_date': '23_09_1870', 'content': 'By the Biafra, which arrived in the Mersey on the 28th August with the monthly mails, the following was reported:—

The health of the different rivers was good, and trade generally brisk, with the exception of Bonny, where it was at a complete standstill.

There were immense quantities of produce about the coast, waiting the arrival of ships to take it away. At Lagos there were plenty of cotton and palm oil awaiting the chances of shipment.

In consequence of the markets being reopened at Benin, oil was coming in freely to the different establishments.

From the Western Districts of the Gold Coast, it is stated that since the exchange of territories, notwithstanding the troubles connected with it, the palm-oil trade had increased, the increase in the exports being over 140,000l. Some important messages had been received from Ashantee, the King offering to surrender all the Fantees in his dominion, on condition that the English Administrator gave up all the Ashantees in the Protectorate. He also suggests that all property seized by either side should be exchanged. It was also stated that the famous Ashantee Chief, Quaguah (who negotiated the treaty with Governor Maclean for the surrender of all refugees) was about to be sent as ambassador. Governor Nagtglas was also sending back to Coomassie, through Assinnee, the Ashantees at Elmina. The missionaries belonging to the Basle Mission, who were captured by the Ashantees in Creepee several months ago, were likewise to be sent down. When the Ashantee trade sets in it is believed that a large business would commence.

Accounts from the Eastern Districts state that the Accras and their allies had had great success in the war against the combined Ashantees, Aquamoos, Awoonas, and the Volta forces. They had taken possession of the enemy's chief towns, burnt several "crooms," which were mere nests of robbers, murderers, and pirates, defeated and destroyed or dispersed every armed force opposed to them, and cleared the Eastern Districts of rebels and hostile troops. The losses on the Accra side were stated to be very severe. The action in which General Domphrey, the commander of the Accra army, was killed, was fought at the foot of Aquamoo Mountain on the 25th July. The allied forces of the Eastern Districts, numbering about 25,000 well-armed and disciplined men, under the kings, chiefs, and native gentlemen of the Protectorate, were expected to return to Accra in September, when the campaign will probably have terminated. Large supplies of ammunition and provisions had been recently forwarded to the allied camp from Accra by Captain Ross, the chief civil commandant of the Eastern Districts, and it is stated that the influence of the British Government in the protected territories adjacent to the forts and settlements had not been so strong since 1851 as it is at present. That portion of the Gold Coast settlements contains a population of 400,000 souls.'}, {'id': 2078, 'article_title': 'CAPE COAST AND ACCRA', 'full_section_title': 'CAPE COAST AND ACCRA', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1871#article-3', 'issue_date': '23_09_1871', 'content': 'The Western districts of the Gold Coast are tranquil, all the paths and roads are open, and trade and agriculture are being carried on in perfect safety. The native chiefs of the British Protectorate, who had assembled at Cape Coast to meet the Governor, for the purpose of assisting him to bring about peace with the Ashantees, have almost all returned to their own places, and it is considered that peace has actually been concluded between the Fantees and the Ashantees. Mr. Thomas Forson was commissioned by the Governor of Cape Coast to go up to Coomassie to negotiate with the King of Ashantee for the release of the four Europeans who are still held prisoners in the Ashantee capital. The captives are Mr. and Mrs. Ramsey, Mr. Kuhne, and Mr. Bonnart. Mr. Ramsey was a missionary at Anoom, and was captured two years ago by a detachment of the army of Oddoo Boffoe. It is stated that nothing could have been more wanton and cruel than the manner in which the captives were treated. All their property, together with that of the mission, &c., was destroyed or plundered, and they were compelled to travel all the way from Anoom to Coomassie on foot. The troops who escorted them used them very ill on the way, and in consequence of exhaustion and want of nourishment Mrs. Ramsey's baby died.

Mr. Forson returned to Cape Coast on the 23rd of June, accompanied by a special messenger from the King of Ashantee, and it was believed that his visit would not be altogether fruitless. The king was not unwilling to restore his English prisoners to freedom, but urged that, according to the custom of his nation, the commander whose troops seized the captives and ordered them to be sent up to Coomassie must first make his appearance at the capital and give his report of the proceedings, before the captives could be finally dealt with. In the meantime it was believed that there was no cause for any uneasiness on their account. The king told Mr. Forson that he wanted nothing in the shape of ransom for the captives, and he would freely give them up to the British Government.

A further account, under date of the 11th ult., from Coomassie, states that the remains of the hordes of Ashantees which had been invading the Eastern districts of the English Protectorate were returning, bringing with them thousands of captives, principally women, girls, and boys, from the neighbourhood of the Volta. When the remnant of the troops which comprised the first army of invasion of the Eastern Province entered Coomassie, there was public lamentation on account of the numbers that had fallen in the war, and, according to the fearful custom of the country, there were terrible human sacrifices; "in fact, hardly any description," according to an eye-witness, "could exaggerate the reality." At least half the Ashantees who went to battle are
**27**

reported to have died, and 200 human jawbones were carried in procession through the streets.'}]
