[{'document_title': 'RIVER NIGER.—THE SLAVE-TRADERS.—LATE GUNBOAT OPERATIONS.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Navigating the Niger. This does not much concern us; we are only sorry they have escaped punishment, and we give them warning that a similar or heavier one than that illegally decreed, and from which they have thus been freed, may yet overtake them; as the powers with which the late Consul Hopkins was to have been entrusted will certainly be conferred on his successor, from sentences passed by whom they will not so easily escape. What does concern us is the destruction of Onitsha, and its results. Onitsha seemed to be inseparably identified in our mind with the redemption of the Niger countries from barbarism, and the growth of a healthy commerce in them. Situate at the confluence of the Tchudda with the Niger, on ground ceded to the British at the time of Prince Albert's celebrated and unfortunate expedition, it has been the centre of missionary action, as well as of trading operations; and now, by its destruction the native catechists and missionaries must be scattered, and the work of twenty-two years, during which time the Church of England Mission had been established there, be brought to a deadlock. And it does cause us serious reflection that so important and extreme a decision as that of the destruction of that cradle of Niger civilization, should have been arrived at so soon after the death of the late lamented Consul Hopkins. If the iniquities of Onitsha had become so flagrant during Consul Hopkins' life as to have justified such severe punishment, we cannot believe that Consul Hopkins would have allowed them to go unpunished; while the time that has intervened since his lamented death is too short to have allowed an extraordinary new growth of iniquity. We cannot, therefore, believe that had Consul Hopkins been still exercising authority in those countries, he would have permitted the violence that has been employed; and we do think that where power has been so excessively, ruthlessly, and carelessly used, it is imperatively necessary that we should be made acquainted with the justifying cause of such an exercise of force. We hope at least to find this in the Blue-book of the present year; to find who were the complaining parties, what were the offences and iniquities denounced, and who decreed the extreme penalty that has been inflicted.", 'last_edit_date': '1880-02-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_02_1880#article-19', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.687, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Death of Mr. Consul Hopkins', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"With the death of Mr. Consul Hopkins, news of which arrived from the West Coast of Africa by the last mail steamer, we cease to have a most worthy and efficient representative at Fernando Po. Mr. Hopkins was Consul for the Bight of Biafra, and for a dozen years or more lived on the Coast, bearing almost a charmed life in the midst of jungle fevers and the other terrible ailments to which the white man is subject. By his unaided exertions he frequently restored and maintained peace among the disputing chiefs of the Coast. His last duty was a journey to New Calabar, where his presence, we are told, 'caused the conflict between the native chiefs and their followers to cease, and a palaver to take place to settle the existing differences.' Mr. Hopkins's influence with the natives was proverbial, and the name of 'King-maker' was not inaptly given him by traders in the district, for in the election of chiefs his voice was all-powerful. At the time of the Ashanti difficulty Mr. Hopkins offered to assist Sir Garnet Wolseley with a drilled body of five hundred men from Bonny, while both Commander Cameron and Mr. Stanley have to thank him for valuable assistance during their travels. Mr. Consul Hopkins owed his position, such as it was, entirely to himself, and his heart was so much in his work that he chose to brave the deadly climate year after year rather than relinquish his post. How he came to receive the appointment was never very clear, but as he was about the only British resident to be found on the spot, the choice was not difficult to make. Mr. Hopkins some years ago held a temporary appointment under the War Office, but, failing to pass the prescribed examination for a clerkship, was cut adrift from official employment. He was a crack shot with the rifle, and his name figures frequently as a prize-winner at the earlier Wimbledon meetings; he was indeed the first captain of the Irish team. Subsequently he entered into an engagement with a trading company to proceed to the West Coast, and here his skill as a marksman brought him the respect of the natives far and wide. Within a few years of his rejection by the Civil Service Commissioners as incompetent, as possibly he was, to perform the duties of a War Office clerk, we hear of him saluted by the guns of the squadron as British Consul, and proceeding in company with a gunboat to settle some dispute between quarrelsome chiefs on the subject of palm oil or ivory. The death of Mr. Consul Hopkins will be a sad loss both to the traders and the natives of the West Coast.', 'last_edit_date': '1879-10-16', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1879#article-14', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.703, 'probability_score': 0.069, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Trading Troubles in Western Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'For some years past there has been no king in Bonny, George Pepple, a youth who was educated in England, the last king, having been quietly deposed some time ago, owing to his not possessing the confidence of the various chiefs, and to his being too poor to maintain his position. Since then there has been no real king, but Oko Jumbo, the most powerful of the chiefs (who visited England last year, when he was erroneously styled "King of Bonny" by the London papers), has been endeavouring to exercise supreme power, and has been the cause of a vast amount of blood being shed. Some time back, by the advice of the Consul, Warraboo, who was the principal general in the war with Ja Ja a few years ago, was appointed Regent, pending the election of a king; but latterly he has had to seek protection in the residence of one of the European traders, owing to Oko Jumbo having made divers attempts to murder him. The country has now for a considerable period been split up into factions; there has been a general air of lawlessness, demoralization, and what might be termed an atmosphere of crime and outrage; trade has, consequently, been at a standstill, and civil war appeared to be the only possible outcome of it all.', 'last_edit_date': '1886-12-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1886#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.647, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'West Coast News', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Mr. William Robinson, writing from Whydah on October 27th, says: "Quittah has been in a state of siege. Business operations had been entirely suspended, and the factories were being turned into fortresses. Kroomen were armed and provided with ammunition, gangs told off nightly to patrol the streets, whilst the Government were preparing redoubts and taking every precautionary measure against an impending attack. The effects of the sad affair, in which Captain Ellis and his companion have plunged the town, cannot yet be realized. It will be, undoubtedly, a costly job for Government and an awkward matter to settle, for the same law as in olden times prevails, 'blood for blood.' Even if war is averted, which is very desirable, and an amicable settlement come to, it will take some time to efface it from the memories of the country people, and bring them round to the same state of tranquillity as heretofore. In fact, great dissatisfaction is everywhere expressed against the Government, and every market day there are complaints against Houssas stealing firewood, turkeys, etc. This all tends to affect the trade of the port. Merchants suffer and agents' lives are endangered by the foolhardiness of a young inexperienced Commandant. A very uneasy feeling prevails amongst Europeans at Whydah to know what steps the Government are likely to take in order to enforce the balance of the fine the King has not paid and still persists in not paying. The country is very tranquil and trade good, and we think if Consul Hopkins was sent up he would be able to persuade his Highness to pay without resorting to extreme measures, thereby endangering lives. Lagos trade was extremely dull, owing to the interior war. Merchants were loud in their protests against the Governor not taking any steps to put an immediate end to the war, nor using his influence to bring about a reconciliation between the two conflicting tribes. In order still to make matters worse, the King of Porto Novo has shut the roads against provisions and fresh meat going into Lagos. After the recent epidemic which the inhabitants have passed through, it is really too bad that they should be prohibited fresh provisions, so needful to the preservation of health."

We learn by the "Senegal" that Mr. Consul Hopkins has arranged temporarily certain difficulties which had arisen between King George of Bonny and his chiefs. King George had, we fear, been badly inspired by some of his new friends in England, who were totally ignorant of Bonny customs, prejudices, and powers; but we hope all will soon be satisfactorily arranged between him and his chiefs.', 'last_edit_date': '1879-01-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_01_1879#article-1', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.655, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Benin Disaster', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Fuller details of the terrible massacre in the Benin country were not received till the 22nd. They came simultaneously from Lagos and Brass, and agree in all essential points. It seems that the expedition started from Sapele on Jan. 2, and after proceeding up Gatto Creek the party landed, and continued their journey overland to Benin town. In every town through which they passed they received friendly greetings from the people, and peaceful messages were brought to them from the King. The expedition, which was wholly unarmed, was divided into two parties, the first being about four hours' march ahead of the second. The advance party was surprised by a great force of the Benin warriors, who were in ambush, and was cut to pieces, not a man escaping. This happened on the day after the landing, when they had covered about fourteen miles on the way to Benin city. The second company, suspecting nothing, marched in the tracks of its vanguard, and suddenly came upon the piled corpses of those who had already fallen victims to the treachery of the savages. While they were examining the scene of carnage, they also were attacked and shot down from the bush.

Consul Phillips, his private secretary, Dr. Elliott, and Mr. Powis fell dead on the spot, Major Crawford was wounded, and was picked up by Captain Boisragon and Mr. Locke; but he died almost immediately, and before he expired he implored them to leave him behind, declaring that it was all over with him and exhorting them to look after their own safety. Mr. Campbell was captured and taken to the town. The King refused to allow him to be brought in, and he was carried to an adjacent village, where he was put to death. There is no authentic information as to the fate of Mr. Gordon, but he is believed to be dead.

Capt. Boisragon and Mr. Locke escaped into the bush, where they wandered for five days before they were picked up. Mr. Locke was armed with a revolver and shot several of the Natives who attacked them during their wanderings. Capt. Boisragon was shot in the arm while beating a band of Natives back with a stick. They subsisted for five days on cassava leaves, and the only water which they had to drink was dew. Finally, they came across a Benin village, where they were kindly treated by the Natives, who took them across a creek and landed them at a town. After a time they were conveyed down the creek in a covered canoe. A launch with a relief party on board was met on its way up the creek, and to this the two officers were transferred. The Native servant of Mr. Powis escaped into the bush. All the other Europeans were killed and beheaded. The finger rings of the Consul have been sent back by the King; and the act is taken to indicate his intention to defy the British.

Consul-General Phillips was a son of the Archdeacon of Furness, and was well known and respected in the North of England.", 'last_edit_date': '1897-01-11', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_02_1897#article-6', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.639, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE WEST COAST OF AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The Royal Mail steamer Cameroon, belonging to the British and African Steam Navigation Company, reached the Mersey on Friday, July 25, with mails and passengers from the West Coast of Africa. News from the Coast was not very encouraging, as trade for the most part was anything but brisk. From New Calabar, the death of the King was reported. His Majesty, who was a very old man, had held the sovereignty for many years, and since his decease scenes of disorder and tumult have been frequently taking place in the district. There were many aspirants to the vacant throne, and with their followers they had on many occasions been engaged in combat with each other with the result that many persons on both sides were reported to be killed. Up to the latest advices no one had succeeded the deceased king, and the quarrels between the petty chiefs and their adherents were still going on. The throne of Old Calabar was also still vacant when the Cameroon left. Since the death of King Archibong, the ruling monarch in this district, trade has been adversely affected, and it was understood that Consul Hopkins intended to entrust the government of the place to an Assembly, as formerly, and not to have any recognised king. The Consul was also about to pay his annual visit up the River Niger.', 'last_edit_date': '1879-08-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1879#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.643, 'probability_score': 0.065, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Death of Mr. Consul Hopkins', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The steamer Ambriz, Captain Wilkins, of the African Steamship Company, which arrived at Liverpool on the 16th October, brought particulars of the death of Consul David Hopkins. Mr. Hopkins died on board the hulk Benledi, in the Bonny River, on the 13th of September, from affection of the kidneys and other complaints. Great regret was manifested on the Coast immediately the event occurred, and the sympathy was genuine and universal, trade suffering a temporary suspension out of respect to the deceased. When Captain Wilkins was at Bonny, just after the death of the Consul, a deputation waited upon him, composed of traders, chiefs, and others, to express their unqualified sorrow at the occurrence. In speaking of Mr. Hopkins, the whole population of the Coast bear testimony to his skill and ability in the treatment of some of the most delicate matters, which his influence, more than anything else, brought to a successful issue.

We extract the following from the Daily News of Monday, Oct. 20. We use it because we have pleasure in honouring the memory of the late Consul. The writer says, "How he came to receive the appointment was never very clear." This is an error. Consul Hopkins was very wisely appointed by the Government at the recommendation of the principal commercial houses at Liverpool, and because they had also full knowledge of his fitness for the post through services he had previously rendered. We can only hope the Government will act with equal wisdom in their choice of a successor to the deceased Consul:', 'last_edit_date': '1879-10-16', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1879#article-14', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.697, 'probability_score': 0.069, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'WEST COAST NEWS', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The Africa carried a man named Gonzo from Quittah to Accra to take his trial on a charge of murder. It appears that the prisoner had been engaged smuggling for some time, and, being detected by an officer named Cerlear, the latter attempted to arrest him, when Gonzo stabbed him to death. The prisoner admitted having murdered the man, but declined to say what he did with the body, but it is supposed that he threw it into the river.

By the Gaboon, arrived September 16, we learned that Consul Hopkins had gone from Bonny to Opobo, with the hope of inducing King Ja Ja to act as arbitrator in the New Calabar dispute. She brought the further news from Lagos that trade was still dull there, and shipments small; also that a Government mission to the Niger had left a few days before, with the intention, it was supposed, of recruiting the Houssa force, and inducing more friendly relations with the warlike tribes along the river.

At Little and Grand Popo (August 17) an ingenious method had been adopted to communicate with vessels by lashing forty palm oil puncheons in a row and dragging them through the surf. By good pay and "plenty rum" some natives had been induced to adopt this plan, but the majority had not yet recovered from the shark panic.

At Axim it was stated that the Wassaw gold mines (French Company) were in active operation, but the results were kept secret.

By the steamship Bonny (arrived Sept. 23) we learned that Consul Hopkins had failed to persuade King Ja Ja to interfere in the New Calabar dispute, and that he thought it necessary for the protection of British interests that a gunboat should be stationed in Bonny. The Commander of H.M.S. Decoy was written to for that purpose, and was to arrive there in a few days.

By her we also learned that the steamer Albion, with Mr. Stanley and his Zanzibar followers on board, sailed from Sierra Leone on September 3, for the River Congo. His expedition seemed at Sierra Leone to be invested with much mystery, Mr. Stanley voyaging under the assumed name of "Swinburne;" so that the steamer was in danger of being detained by the authorities until Mr. Stanley declared his real name and the object of his voyage.

The textbook primarily focuses on British interactions with other African polities, such as the Dahomey and Yoruba, and discusses broader themes of British colonial diplomacy and intervention, without specific mention of the Egbas. Despite these challenges, efforts to mend relations are noted, such as Governor Carter's successful visit to Abeokuta and the establishment of a new treaty for peace and trade. Overall, The African Times illustrates the complex and strained relationship between the Egbas and the British, shaped by historical grievances and political strategies, while the General History of Africa does not provide direct evidence on this specific relationship.

[{'document_title': 'Dahomey, Yorubaland, Borgu and Benin in the nineteenth century', 'section_title': 'The growth of European interest', 'content': "Because the lands and peoples were so interwoven, developments in one part always had effects and implications in other parts. The appointment in 1849 of John Beecroft as British Consul for the Bights of Benin and Bonny (formerly Biafra) signalled the dawn of a new era. British interests came to be specifically protected visà-vis the interest of other European nationals; British interests were also advanced against those of Africans. We have already drawn attention to the penetration of the Benin kingdom from the Niger delta and the resultant whittling down of Benin's trading hinterland to the extent of the eventual abandonment of Ughoton, Benin's traditional port. The inter-state wars did not weaken the resolve of each of the states to keep European traders from encroaching on their spheres of trade or in the maintenance of their sovereignty. The British had clashed with King William Pepple of Bonny as early as 1854, when they exiled him to Fernando Po, Ascension, Sierra Leone and London. [{'id': 340, 'article_title': 'CAPE COAST.', 'full_section_title': 'CAPE COAST.', 'last_edit_date': '04-11-1864', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1864#article-5', 'issue_date': '23_05_1864', 'content': "The Oyimbos* are now in great favour at Abeokuta, in consequence of their conduct during the attack, and great hopes are entertained of a speedy re-establishment of friendly relations between the Egbas and this colony. His Excellency Governor Freeman is about to visit Abeokuta. This visit has been contemplated some time, but has been retarded by the Governor's illness and the hesitation of the Bashorun and elders to receive him. A person of colour who conceives himself to have been injured by some former acts of the Governor has for months past been staying in Abeokuta, exerting all his influence to prevent a rapprochement between the authorities of the two places, whose interests are so closely united. The Bashorun has, however, responded favourably to his Excellency's intimation that he was desirous of going to Abeokuta, with a view to an amelioration of the existing state of things, and little doubt is entertained that much good will result from an interview and direct communication with the Bashorun and elders. My own impression is that the Egbas will be only too glad to listen to the Governor's overtures, and that, being tired of the long stoppage of trade, they will avail themselves of any good excuse to open the roads and let our produce come down. Bad counsels may, however, prevail over their own better intentions, or their easy victory over Dahomey may have further inflated them. The Governor's mission may fail, and then I think that, repugnant though it may be to the ideas of many, the authorities here must adopt some very coercive measures, as the only means of rescuing Lagos from ruin. War feelings against Abeokuta were strong here lately, when they hesitated to receive the Governor, and will be fanned into a flame should his overtures be rejected, as we all believe that the fault will not be his.

Governor Freeman has been much abused, but he had an invidious task before him, as the first Governor of this colony; and though few here care to admit that he executed his work in the least obnoxious manner, it may be doubted if any one in his place would have incurred less obloquy than he has done. It is, however, true that our late most worthily popular Lieutenant-Governor was more the man of our choice; and all the European population at least would most heartily welcome his return, even though only as Colonial Secretary.

A good measure has just been adopted. The foreign merchants trading both here and at Porto Novo have been landing their goods for Porto Novo on the beach there, the duties here, especially on rum and tobacco, being too oppressive. An ordinance has just issued that goods passing through Lagos to Porto

* White, or Sierra Leone men.—Ed. A. T."}, {'id': 602, 'article_title': 'LAGOS.', 'full_section_title': 'LAGOS.', 'last_edit_date': '04-10-1865', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1865#article-10', 'issue_date': '23_05_1865', 'content': 'If, however, there be one thing that we especially detest, it is a policy of temporary, shifting expedients. Ikorodu was under British protection. When the Egbas came down to lay siege to it, the Governor of Lagos gratified them by withdrawing British protection, and blockading the coast. The Egbas then allowed all the cotton stored in Abeokuta to come down to Lagos. Now the Ikorodu market seems of more importance than anything in Abeokuta, and British protection is again accorded to Ikorodu, and British forces are employed to drive the Egbas from before the place. We have no doubt this is all susceptible of consistent explanation—at least, we hope it is. The Egbas have shown anything but a friendly disposition towards us since Lagos became a British colony; but we cannot help, nevertheless, deploring that we should be in active and deadly hostility with a town to which we have been sending Christian and civilizing agencies for so many years, and which was, right or wrong, regarded as one of the brightest spots in native Africa.

In order the more effectually to cut off all supplies from Abeokuta, Cotenoo Creek is closed from the 14th April, which it is supposed will prevent the passage of goods by Porto Novo. Cotenoo Creek is also a landing place for Whydah.'}, {'id': 2448, 'article_title': 'TRUE STATEMENTS OF THE CAUSE OF LAGOS DISASTERS.—No. II.', 'full_section_title': 'TRUE STATEMENTS OF THE CAUSE OF LAGOS DISASTERS.—No. II.', 'last_edit_date': '03-11-1873', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/29_04_1873#article-18', 'issue_date': '29_04_1873', 'content': "Dear Sir,—After perusing the several articles in the English papers (especially the _Manchester Courier_) on the affairs of Lagos, I feel that it is only fair and just to Governor Pope Hennessy that I should relate in your valuable columns a brief history of the cause of differences between the Lagos Government and the Egbas and Ijebus which have caused them to close their trade against Lagos up to this time; and being an African and knowing my countrymen, I think you will agree with me that my statements claim more credence than any which Mr. Charles Leigh Clare (who only wrote from hearsay, and has never been in Lagos) has or can make. Nothing can be more untrue than Mr. Clare's assertion in the _Manchester Courier_ that the roads for trade were closed in consequence of the policy of Governor Hennessy, and I am glad to find that it has been contradicted in the same paper as well as in the _African Times_.

Now, Mr. Editor, it seems that Captain Glover and his friends are trying to make the British public believe that the Egbas and Ijebus are antagonistic to British presence in Lagos on account of the Slave question, and they go on to argue that if Governor Hennessy's policy was good, why have not the roads been open to trade since June, 1872, to the present time? They forget the fact that a wound which can be inflicted in a moment cannot be healed for a long time. I state it as an indisputable fact which can bear any test of investigation, that Captain Glover, during the period of his administration of the government of this settlement (from 1863 to 1872), managed to inflict such serious political wounds on the minds of the Egbas and Ijebus, that it is surprising he and his friends should expect those wounds to be healed in the very short time in which Governor Hennessy tried to heal them. Happily for Lagos Lord Kimberley sent out Governor Hennessy at the time he did; otherwise I cannot say how serious the state of things in Lagos would have become. Party spirit and tribal feelings were running so high at the time, that it is questionable whether the authorities would have been able to prevent one of the most bitter and destructive civil wars from breaking out within this settlement, beginning in the town of Lagos itself."}, {'id': 2902, 'article_title': 'The Dahoman Raid on Abeokuta', 'full_section_title': 'The Dahoman Raid on Abeokuta', 'last_edit_date': '07-01-1875', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_07_1875#article-16', 'issue_date': '01_07_1875', 'content': 'The constantly recurring raids of the Dahomans in Egba territory, even so far as to the vicinity of the town of Abeokuta, call on us for something more than the mere cursory notice accorded to them in our June number. We then expressed a hope that ere this we should hear of another Dahoman defeat by the Egbas. This hope has not been realized; but we have news of the retirement of the Dahomans, without their having ventured any attack on the town. We presume, therefore, that they have returned to their own blood-stained land with fresh hordes of victims for those cruel annual customs in which both King and people take a childish and savage delight. This confirms our impression that, notwithstanding the vain glorious boasting, and annual threats and promises made during the progress of those customs, they have arrived at a full consciousness of their inability ever to force an entry into the town which they have so often during their orgies devoted to slaughter and destruction. The Dahomans cannot take Abeokuta; that is clear. But, unhappily, another thing is equally clear, and that is, the Egbas have not sufficient dependence on themselves, in conflict with the Dahomans in open country, to induce them to take the offensive against the invaders, in the hope that by inflicting a severe chastisement they might destroy their power and appetite for further devastating and panyaring inroads. This is greatly to be deplored. Many years ago we expressed our sorrow at so unsatisfactory a state of things. When Great Britain annexed Lagos, we entertained the hope that, among the advantages which the Egbas would derive from that annexation, the putting an end to those Dahoman raids within their territory would be one. It ought to have been one. The powerful and the wise ought to have so conciliated the ignorant and the weak, as to bring about such friendly relations that in attacking the one, the Dahomans should have known they were incurring the displeasure of the other. This was one of the results of annexation that we desired and expected. When we saw, at a later period, that not only had this not been effected, but that a disastrous bitterness and distrust marked all their relations, we strongly insisted, with those whom we then believed to have influence in Abeokuta, that the Egbas should steadily and diligently strive, by adopting, to a certain extent, an armament superior to that of the Dahomans, and becoming proficient in their use of the weapons, to raise themselves to a military condition that should enable them, in the event of further Dahoman inroads, to effect the destruction of their bitter and relentless foes. We did not think it at all necessary that the great bulk of the people should have arms of precision, and know how to use them; but only that some two or three thousand of them should be armed with Sniders; and be made so fully to understand and to command the capabilities of the weapon, that it could not fail to beget in them a feeling of invincibility as regards the brave but undisciplined and ill-armed Dahomans. We fully believe that had the advice been followed, the end we had in view would have been attained. The effects produced by the employment of similar arms, even in the hands of native Africans, against the Ashantees during the late war fully confirm us in the belief that we were correct in that view. We repeat the advice we before gave. We feel a great interest in the Egbas. Although there has not been any such spread of Christianity among them as we had once hoped for—although education even has made little or no progress, and although we have been heavy sufferers by that disturbance of relations between them and the British authorities at Lagos which has led to so much loss of British
**[JULY 1, 1875.]**'}, {'id': 3467, 'article_title': 'The Truth as to the Dispute between the Egbas and Ibadans', 'full_section_title': 'The Truth as to the Dispute between the Egbas and Ibadans', 'last_edit_date': '10-08-1877', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1877#article-15', 'issue_date': '01_12_1877', 'content': '

The Ibadans long since have been anxious to get their communications with Lagos, or with any seaport, that they may carry their trade independent of other countries, as Egbas and Ijebus; but those two nations try to monopolise the trade between themselves, and buy from the Ibadans and the interior, and take it straight to Lagos, even to England. The Ibadans tried to buy grog instead of rum or gin, as the Ijebus and Egbas water it so much that the purchaser scarcely gets 12 degrees spirit, and selling pieces of cloth 25 yards instead of 30, and so on. But, above all, some time ago they refused to sell them salt, powder, guns, &c., which is a sign of hostility; so much so, that Mr. Editor will remember that that was the quarrel of the Egbas with Captain Glover, when he stopped powder and guns against them in 1871-72. All this is almost nothing in comparison to others. In 1872-73, I was in Abbeokuta, when Chief Warrior Akodu sent to Kobits (Abbeokuta is a big market in the middle town) to take and plunder Ibadan people several times; once it met me in the very Kobite; and these Ibadans he used to chain and sell with their goods plundered. Once Oguée, another war chief (for there are thousands of them in Abb) plundered and caught several Ibadans, in the midst of whom was a woman with child. As Oguée knew that this trick would be discovered, and that he shared with nobody the plundered goods, consequently had no backstay as Akodu, he took these poor people and killed them all. The Egbas used to pass through Ibadan to Ilorin with thousands of pounds worth of goods, but the Ibadans never troubled them; the poor Ibadan people come to Abbeokuta with a single bag of kernal or bag of seed cotton to buy a bag of salt, are captured, and sold at once by the peaceable Egba. Can a gentleman like Mr. H. Robbin, though of Egba pure blood, as I am, deny this? As a gentleman, I trust he will speak the truth. Every day, similar plunders of the Ibadans by the peaceable Egba occurred, till lately one War chief, called Ajagunjungun, plundered some Ibadans' property; they begged and begged, but with no result. Chief Ogundipe interceded and opposed, though himself an Egba and heathen; never joining them nor approving their doings, as Mr. "Native" and others do. Tired of their going and coming, the Ibadans sent to their King Alafin (King of all the Yorubas) to intercede for them. The King of Oyo (Alafin), knowing how stubborn are the Egbas, sent Sango-fetish (Thunder-god), with his messenger, to the Egbas, begging them, through Sango, which, according to heathenism, is the most solemn request; but the Egbas refused (or Ajagaujeuru), for any single Egba is a king, a chief, an all in all. The Ibadans then determined not to go to Abbeokuta again for commerce, as they say in their own language, "they want no neighbourhood war in future after the Ijaye war"; so they sent to the King of Porto Novo to tell him (with Alafin messenger) that they would pass through Imeko to his country, to buy their necessaries. In this message there were Royal gifts on both sides, and rejoicings by the King of Porto Novo, who wants to be freed from the Egbas, for all the neighbourhood is against the Egbas. Perhaps Mr. "Native" will point out to me who are the Egbas' friends in this part of Africa but England; and they have well paid them (five days from date will make ten years since). On the return of the Ibadans, the Egbas sent a chief warrior, called Ogundeyi, to plunder them, but Ogundeyi being a coward, as all the Egba war-chiefs are, hid himself in the bush till the Ibadans went away, and then told the Egbas that he did not find them. Of course they all knew it well, but dare not say it, as none are able to do more. So the Egbas blockaded their roads against Ogundeyi's wish, and sent to the King of Ijebu (with flattering words, such as "you are our father," of our all and all") to do the like as they have done in 1872 against Lagos. All the Ibadans then could not help but to show the Egbas that they are men, and even not so coward as the Egbas, declared war against them, not against the Ijebus, until the Ijebus provoke them; '}]

[{'document_title': 'Address of the Egbas at Bathurst to their Friends in Abeokuta', 'section_title': '', 'content': "We, the undersigned Egbas by descent, now located at Bathurst Town, St. Mary's River, Gambia, to the Chiefs, our brethren, countrymen, &c., bearing rule at Abeokuta, greeting:—

We cordially and sincerely wish you all grace and peace from God our Father, and his Son Jesus Christ.

Whereas we have been informed, from undoubted and good authorities, that you, our beloved countrymen at Abeokuta, have recently been involved in quarrels with the British Government, and are ready to take up arms against them.

We, therefore, anticipating the dismal calamities, misfortunes, and distress that will inevitably result upon our nation from this quarrel, deem it an indispensable duty of sincere and affectionate brethren seasonably to interfere; and hope, by God's grace, to prevail on you with wholesome advice, in order that a stop might speedily be put to these impending and approaching evils. Which, we earnestly pray and hope, by God's providence, will be dispersed by our advice being taken and acted upon.

We heard that you rose up against the Crodco people, and the white men interfered, and asked you to give up the matter, and be at peace with them, allowing you ten days for meditation on the subject; and that at the expiration of these ten days you still continued obstinate, in consequence of which the white men get very much angry against you. Whether the fact be true as represented to us or not, we cannot tell, as we had no written, but mere verbal information; or whether these ten days allowed you for consideration were permitted to elapse before the white men took the offence, we cannot tell; but if it be so or not, we send this note to inquire of you, expecting to receive an early answer from you. If, unfortunately, it be true, we beg most humbly to interfere; and in the name of God, invoke, supplicate, and beseech you to give up the matter, and make peace with the white men the English people, because they have all this while been protecting you from enemies from every quarter.

We were very glad, indeed, to hear of your welfare and good behaviour in times past; but to hear this last sad news troubles our heart very much, because we are here under the immediate control and government of the English people.

We expect, therefore, to hear from you nothing but peace, ure and lasting. Fare-you-well.

We subscribe ourselves, with all good wishes, ever to be your sincere, affectionate countrymen and brethren in the Gambia.", 'last_edit_date': '1865-05-10', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_06_1865#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.694, 'probability_score': 0.07, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Quarrel of the Ibadans and the Egbas', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'A new correspondent, "Eni Olorunfe," writes to correct the statements of our various correspondents which have appeared from month to month in the African Times, relative to the unhappy dispute and hostilities between Ibadan and Abeokuta. His letter is too long for insertion, but it gives so copious an account of the origin of the differences, and is so consistent throughout, that we regard it as having the stamp of truth. We regret to believe that matters are as E.O. states; because, under such circumstances, it would appear difficult for the two peoples of themselves to arrive at such permanent settlement, as the material and social interests of both Egbas and Yorubas require.

Commencing with the history of the drawing together of the 145 counties of the Egba into one township at Abeokuta, for mutual protection against the Yorubas, the Ife, and the Jjebus, who were perpetually warring against them, he traces the subsequent proceedings of the people of Ibadan up to the present time; endeavouring to prove, and we think proving, that there is a settled purpose in Ibadan to destroy Abeokuta and enslave the Egbas, if possible. He points to the complicity between Ibadan and Dahomey, the objects of which were happily defeated by the overwhelming repulse of the latter before Abeokuta; and regards the late efforts of Ibadan to form a road to Port Novo through the Egba farms, as evidence of persistence in the same policy. As regards fighting power we think he gives abundant evidence that the Egbas are quite equal to the Ibadans. What then? Is it to be a combat à la mort between the two peoples? Is not some mediatory action—neutral and friendly to both Egbas and Yorubas—possible, on the part of the British authorities at Lagos? The prosperity of this Settlement depends on an uninterrupted security to be enjoyed for trading operations among and with both peoples.', 'last_edit_date': '1878-09-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_09_1878#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.656, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Quarrel of the Ibadans and the Egbas', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'and we hope and believe that some enlightened Administrator at Lagos will succeed in arranging a basis of reconciliation and enduring friendship between antagonists, whose only rivalry ought now to be which shall make the most rapid progress in industrial development and civilization. If, as stated, the only desire of the Ibadans is to procure constant and abundant supplies of arms and ammunition, not for self-defence, but for wars of aggression and conquest, and with the fixed intention and hope of ultimately destroying Abeokuta; we think it should be a matter for serious consideration by the British authorities at Lagos, whether in the interests, not only of Lagos as the great seaport of those countries, but in the also of the whole population of the Egba and Yoruba territories, they should not adopt a decided policy for the maintenance of peace, and make that policy known to all the parties interested. Lagos cannot be advantaged in any way by the destruction of the Egbas by the Ibadans. Every attack by the Ibadans on the Egba farms is an attack on the prosperity of Lagos. It seems to us, therefore, that the time has come when the Government at Lagos should notify to the chiefs and people at Ibadan that all unprovoked attacks by the latter on the Egba farms; and all attempts against the territorial integrity of Abeokuta, will be not only displeasing to the government at Lagos, but will, if persisted in, be at length regarded as acts of hostility against Lagos itself; that in an unprovoked war of aggression by Ibadan upon Abeokuta, the latter would, in case of necessity, be assisted by Her Majesty's Government at Lagos. It is surely time that the Queen's Government at Lagos should exercise its just influence in interior disputes that so gravely compromise those commercial interests on the prosperity of which that of Lagos itself depends. The key-note of civilization, peace, and prosperity in those countries must be sounded from Lagos; and it is not worthy in a Government carried on there in the name of the Queen of Great Britain and Ireland, that this key-note should be only so faintly struck as to be, as it has hitherto been, scarcely audible. That Government must adopt a policy distinct, stable, enlightened, and understood by the interior peoples. We do not see any secure basis on which such a policy can be founded and built up, but that of peace, friendship, and goodwill with and towards Abeokuta, and the promise of efficient aid to the latter, if necessary, in the event of unprovoked attack from Ibadan. Her Majesty's Government has remonstrated with the King of Dahomey as regards his oft-repeated attacks upon Abeokuta, one at least of which would seem to have been made by direct invitation of Ibadan; and it will only be a carrying out of the same policy to make similar remonstrances with the latter. If there be a perfectly friendly understanding with Abeokuta on the part of the Lagos government, with a frank declaration of such a policy as we have pointed to, we cannot believe that there would be any difficulty in arranging the question of transit dues between Abeokuta and Ibadan. If, as asserted, the objection on the part of the Egbas to force intercourse on the part of the Yorubas with Lagos, is one derived from the natural instinct of self-preservation, that objection will disappear when once Abeokuta becomes assured that, let Ibadan import whatever quantity of arms and ammunition she may, she will not be permitted to use them for despoiling and destroying Abeokuta. We should then also hope to see a perfect and entire accord between the Lagos Government and the Egba authorities for improving the land communications of Abeokuta with Lagos. The distance between the two places ought to be accomplished within the short space of a few hours, both for passengers and goods. Then, and never until then, will the Egba countries make that progress which such fertile countries, inhabited by so industrial a population, ought to make. All our views, aims, and desires concerning them, since Lagos became a possession of the British Crown, have been in this direction; and we yet hope to see them realized. It will appear at once, to all who are interested in the discussion and settlement of matters so vital as regards the commercial prosperity of Lagos, that the Porto Novo Question cannot be overlooked. It is time it was settled in the way desired by the enlightened portion of the Lagos community, native and European. The supplies of ammunition which enabled the Ibadans to commence their late raids in Abeokuta territory—raids, which we rejoice to hear, have, in many instances, been vigorously repulsed—were obtained from Porto Novo by a large armed body of Ibadans, who, either with the connivance, or because of the small power of resistance of the king of that place, plundered the stores of English and other merchants of all that they chose to require. The present efforts of the Ibadans to make a road of their own through Egba territory to Porto Novo, are efforts to enable them to repeat that plundering operation whenever their marauding necessities may require fresh supplies. We showed, some months ago, in a leading article in our journal, how indispensable it had now become that Porto Novo should be united with Lagos under British government; and the conviction then expressed could only be confirmed by the fact of the persistent attacks of the Ibadans on Egba farms lying on the line of their coveted road to Porto Novo. They would no longer have the same object in making, or desiring to make this road if Porto Novo and Lagos were under the same rule—a rule which has both the will and the power to prevent such depredations as those committed by the Ibadans in Porto Novo. We cannot doubt that the annexation of Porto Novo by amicable contract and arrangement with the Native authority of that place is under the consideration of Her Majesty's Government, who must feel the same desire that we do, that the enormities there practised should be put an end to, as well as that British property there should be freed from its present proved liability to plunder. Having "put their hand to the plough" in the annexation of Lagos, which, notwithstanding the occasional errors of its local government, has put an end to very great evils, and brought in a very great amount of good, they ought not now to draw back or hesitate when, as in the matter of Porto Novo, the need is so pressing, and the interests of humanity and civilizing commerce alike demand their immediate action.', 'last_edit_date': '1878-09-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_09_1878#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.634, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Affairs on the West Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Just before leaving England last year you asked me for some information in reference to some reports regarding Abeokuta. I have recently returned from another visit to West Africa, during which I have again been to Abeokuta. At present the authorities there have no intention to grant any favour to the prejudice of British interests; but I think something more should be done to attach the natives of the interior to our Government. Whether deserved or not we have a reputation of being slow and supine. The Egbas (the people of Abeokuta) are sometimes tempted to act unpleasantly towards us. There is a disaffected section in the community, by whom the loyal chiefs are occasionally harassed. On the occasion of my last visit to Abeokuta, last April, intelligence had arrived respecting the Dahomian attack on Porto Novo. It was currently reported that the English had secretly connived with the Dahomians, and an attempt was made to raise an ante-English demonstration. On April 7 important deliberations were conducted by the authorities. Ebullitions of anger were here and there displayed, and an attack was expected. However, the cloud passed off, and the ground of this suspicion appeared to be that an influential Dahomian prince had been for some weeks residing in Lagos. On this occasion I was returning from a tour through the Yaruba country. The region through which I travelled was in a state of great unrest. At Jubu Ode the King and chiefs expressed their vexation over the interminable Ibadan and Ilorin, which are sadly interfering with trade. The Ibadans, while prolonging their strife with Ilorin, are also troubled with the Egbas raiding their farms. The relations between Ibadan and Oyo are in a condition of extreme tension. At Ogbomosho complaints were loud on account of the spoliation of their farms by the Ilorians, with kidnapping and occasional slaughter. Within the last few years thirteen Yaruba towns have been destroyed by the Dahomians, and seven towns were destroyed last year. From what I can gather these towns have about 4,000 inhabitants, while several were much larger. In my journey I passed through the ruins of some of the towns which, a few years ago, were large and influential centres of population and commerce, notably Ijayi and Biolorun Pellu. It would be an unspeakable mercy if some benevolent civilised Power could interfere to cause the chronic strife to cease, and develop the riches of the country. After getting some fifty or sixty miles from the coast the country is comparatively healthy and fertile, as the plantations of cotton, indigo, &c., show, and in some parts rich in mineral treasure. I saw several iron pits and smelting furnaces, and have specimens of iron ore by me. I availed myself of the opportunities afforded me in interviews with kings and chiefs to urge on them the necessity of peace and industry, and was received with welcome wherever I went in the Yaruba country. The reply of one chief was remarkable. He said, “You tell us how much we should be advantaged if we would abandon our quarrels and unite for strength and prosperity. Your words are true; but we are like children fighting. Each is ashamed to be the first to stop, but both wish for nothing better than for some strong man to step between us and send us away to do something wiser.”', 'last_edit_date': '1889-09-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_09_1889#article-6', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.637, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Egbas and Ibadans', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We are informed that the interior tribes have sent to both the Egbas and Ibadans to make known their desire that the matter between them shall be amicably settled without fighting. Messengers from Ibadan and Abeokuta are stated to have arrived in Jebu about the middle of September, and it is hoped this will lead to peace. The Ibadans had determined to fight, and said that even if the Jebus attacked them they would not fight with them, because their properties and persons have always been safe with the Jebus; while on the contrary, the Egbas have laid wait for and kidnapped their people, robbed them of their goods, and sold them into slavery, for which they have never been able to obtain redress. They demand that the Egbas should either accept a consul from Ibadan to reside at Abeokuta, and watch over the Ibadan interests, in the same way that a consul of Jebu has resided for many years past in Ibadan; or receive a British consul in Abeokuta, who would watch over the interests of both Egbas and Ibadans, and settle all disputes between them. If not, they say they will fight the matter out. The King of Jebu, as mediator, is said to have remonstrated with both parties.

recommending the Egbas to appoint some permanent authority, King or other, whom all the Egba people should obey—and reminding the Ibadans that a people must have neighbours; and that in all disputes a third power should be applied to as arbitrator. There seems to be ground for hope that a pacific settlement will be arrived at.', 'last_edit_date': '1877-11-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1877#article-7', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.648, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African Times.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'At the present time, from all parts of the West African coast, we have reports of troubles and disturbances, which must hamper trade and retard the commercial and civilising development of that part of the Dark Continent. For some months now the trade of Lagos has been blocked by the closing of the roads which, running through the district inhabited by the Jebu and Egba tribes, connect that port with the interior; but we are pleased to learn, from the latest telegrams received, that the careful and earnest steps that are being taken by the authorities to secure the opening of these trade routes, have not been without their moral effect upon the tribes implicated, for they are already making overtures of peace and reconciliation. It is much to be hoped that this is the case, for at the present time trade needs fostering on the West Coast more than perhaps ever before, and this object can only be attained by the cheerful co-operation of all interested in its maintenance. The British administration in West Africa has been by no means free from faults in the past; and these faults have born their natural fruit. The secret of good Colonial government would seem to consist in interfering as little as possible with Native customs and prejudices, but at the same time making it thoroughly understood that laws and ordinances must be respected. Now that the dispute with the Jebus and Egbas would seem to be in a fair way of settlement, it affords an opportunity to the Governor of Lagos to insure that, though these tribes are to be treated fairly and with patience, they must quite understand that any infraction of the engagements now or subsequently undertaken by them, will be visited most severely upon the offenders.

But the troubles in this part of the world are by no means confined to the British. It appears that the French have been forced into a war with Dahomey, the only...

[MAY 2, 1892.', 'last_edit_date': '1892-05-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_05_1892#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.663, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Truth as to the Dispute between the Egbas and Ibadans', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The Ibadans long since have been anxious to get their communications with Lagos, or with any seaport, that they may carry their trade independent of other countries, as Egbas and Ijebus; but those two nations try to monopolise the trade between themselves, and buy from the Ibadans and the interior, and take it straight to Lagos, even to England. The Ibadans tried to buy grog instead of rum or gin, as the Ijebus and Egbas water it so much that the purchaser scarcely gets 12 degrees spirit, and selling pieces of cloth 25 yards instead of 30, and so on. But, above all, some time ago they refused to sell them salt, powder, guns, &c., which is a sign of hostility; so much so, that Mr. Editor will remember that that was the quarrel of the Egbas with Captain Glover, when he stopped powder and guns against them in 1871-72. All this is almost nothing in comparison to others. In 1872-73, I was in Abbeokuta, when Chief Warrior Akodu sent to Kobits (Abbeokuta is a big market in the middle town) to take and plunder Ibadan people several times; once it met me in the very Kobite; and these Ibadans he used to chain and sell with their goods plundered. Once Oguée, another war chief (for there are thousands of them in Abb) plundered and caught several Ibadans, in the midst of whom was a woman with child. As Oguée knew that this trick would be discovered, and that he shared with nobody the plundered goods, consequently had no backstay as Akodu, he took these poor people and killed them all. The Egbas used to pass through Ibadan to Ilorin with thousands of pounds worth of goods, but the Ibadans never troubled them; the poor Ibadan people come to Abbeokuta with a single bag of kernal or bag of seed cotton to buy a bag of salt, are captured, and sold at once by the peaceable Egba. Can a gentleman like Mr. H. Robbin, though of Egba pure blood, as I am, deny this? As a gentleman, I trust he will speak the truth. Every day, similar plunders of the Ibadans by the peaceable Egba occurred, till lately one War chief, called Ajagunjungun, plundered some Ibadans' property; they begged and begged, but with no result. Chief Ogundipe interceded and opposed, though himself an Egba and heathen; never joining them nor approving their doings, as Mr. "Native" and others do. Tired of their going and coming, the Ibadans sent to their King Alafin (King of all the Yorubas) to intercede for them. The King of Oyo (Alafin), knowing how stubborn are the Egbas, sent Sango-fetish (Thunder-god), with his messenger, to the Egbas, begging them, through Sango, which, according to heathenism, is the most solemn request; but the Egbas refused (or Ajagaujeuru), for any single Egba is a king, a chief, an all in all. The Ibadans then determined not to go to Abbeokuta again for commerce, as they say in their own language, "they want no neighbourhood war in future after the Ijaye war"; so they sent to the King of Porto Novo to tell him (with Alafin messenger) that they would pass through Imeko to his country, to buy their necessaries. In this message there were Royal gifts on both sides, and rejoicings by the King of Porto Novo, who wants to be freed from the Egbas, for all the neighbourhood is against the Egbas. Perhaps Mr. "Native" will point out to me who are the Egbas' friends in this part of Africa but England; and they have well paid them (five days from date will make ten years since). On the return of the Ibadans, the Egbas sent a chief warrior, called Ogundeyi, to plunder them, but Ogundeyi being a coward, as all the Egba war-chiefs are, hid himself in the bush till the Ibadans went away, and then told the Egbas that he did not find them. Of course they all knew it well, but dare not say it, as none are able to do more. So the Egbas blockaded their roads against Ogundeyi's wish, and sent to the King of Ijebu (with flattering words, such as "you are our father," of our all and all") to do the like as they have done in 1872 against Lagos. All the Ibadans then could not help but to show the Egbas that they are men, and even not so coward as the Egbas, declared war against them, not against the Ijebus, until the Ijebus provoke them;', 'last_edit_date': '1877-10-08', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1877#article-15', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.635, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Banquet to Governor Carter at Liverpool', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Sir Gilbert T. Carter, K.C.M.G., in responding, said that on his arrival in Lagos he was called upon to deal with an interior complication in connexion with the Jebus. The Jebus had acted as middlemen to the Yorubas, and barred them from access to Lagos, and hampering trade by tolls against the Yorubas bringing down their produce. This system had been the great bugbear of Lagos, and the attention of every administrator had been directed towards some means of abolishing it. The Jebus were a most intractable race, who would not alter their methods of government or system of trade. He found on arrival at Lagos, that this people had offered a gross insult to the acting governor while on a visit to Jebu Ode, endeavouring to settle a dispute, and to make some settlement in regard to freeing the roads from the interior to the Jebu country. Her Majesty’s Government, therefore, decided to insist upon an apology from the Jebus, and also upon a permanent settlement of the road question. A treaty was made but was kept but a very short time, and when an officer was sent to ask for an explanation his life was threatened; under such circumstances he felt further forbearance should not be exercised, and had no hesitation in recommending that they should be compelled to fulfil their treaty obligations. The result was the Jebu expedition, which had done more for the Colony of Lagos than any event since the cession to the British crown. The Egbas had closed their roads in sympathy with their neighbours; but the friendly intercourse was shortly resumed. The main incidents of the last expedition were known, so there was no necessity to dilate upon them. A treaty was concluded with the Egbas and the long-standing war between the Ibadans and the Ilorins was brought to a close. Apart from these points, a mass of information had been acquired in regard to interior affairs which could scarcely have been obtained in any other fashion. The recent events in Lagos had brought to the front the question of railways, and he had not been unmindful of this important factor in the development of new countries. Hitherto he had not been sanguine as to the prospect of West African railways, but his acquaintance with the Yoruba country had entirely changed his opinion. It has long been considered in Lagos that a railway in Abeokuta would offer the best chances of financial success, as it would traverse a fertile country, and its terminus would be close to Lagos. There was one important point in discussing the question of an interior railway. At present the Egbas withheld their consent to such a project, though he did not despair of removing their objection. In such matters progress must be slow, and it must not be forgotten that until his own visit no governor of Lagos had ever been permitted to enter Abeokuta. He did not anticipate any serious difficulty with the Yorubas, but they had not formally consented to the project. In the event of the construction of a railway to Ibadan, it would soon be necessary to extend it to the eastward, possibly as far as Ikirun.', 'last_edit_date': '1893-06-16', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/03_07_1893#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.642, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Leader', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'WE ARE MOST PLEASED to be able to record that the difficulties between the British Government and the Egbas, which, during the past year or so have been the fruitful source of all manner of trouble to the commercial prosperity of Lagos, seem at last to have received a satisfactory solution. His Excellency Governor Carter early in January arrived at Abeokuta, the Egba capital, and was received with all fitting honour at the entrance to the town by delegates from the principal chiefs. On the 10th there was a grand assembly of chiefs and people to welcome the Governor of Lagos. In the course of the palaver, Governor Carter expressed the pleasure he felt at seeing the chiefs, and declared that the occasion was an important one for Abeokuta and Lagos, and marked a new era in the history of the country. His welcome was a sign of the removal of the former suspicion and distrust of the Government of Lagos, and must be regarded as substituting for them confidence and goodwill. The reply on behalf of the Egba chiefs was characteristic and to the point: "The whole Egba nation welcomes you. We thank you for your truthfulness and justice, and manifest our joy and appreciation by having this large assembly to greet you. Welcome to Abeokuta!" Things having been arranged satisfactorily so far, the conclusion of a new Treaty between the British authorities

and the Egba chiefs followed as a matter of course. This Treaty was agreed to on the 18th, though up to the time of our going to press a complete official copy was not obtainable. But, doubtless, it follows the lines usual in such cases with such modifications as the circumstances of the case necessitate. It, of course, declares that peace and friendship exist between the subjects of Queen Victoria and the Egbas. Any difference which may arise is to be referred to the Governor of Lagos for settlement. Complete freedom of trade is established between the Egba country and Lagos. In view of the injury to commerce resulting from the closing of roads, the King and his authorities declare that no roads shall in future be closed without the consent of the Governor. The King and his authorities pledged themselves to use every means to foster and promote trade in the Egba country and Lagos, and to afford complete protection and assistance to traders. They also promise to abolish the practice of human sacrifice existing in Ijone township.', 'last_edit_date': '1893-02-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1893#article-6', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.638, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Anticipated Native Troubles in the Bight District', 'section_title': '', 'content': "The steamer Sherbro' arrived in the Mersey on Sept. 9th with mails and passengers from the West Coast of Africa. The Sherbro' brings news from the rivers to the 3rd August. Considerable anxiety was felt in Bonny and New Calabar lest the absence of all consular officials from the Bights should lead to a recurrence of the recent disturbances between the chiefs of those places in connexion with the Endelle markets and the Chief Will Braid's opposition to the Consular decision. The dispute was referred to Consul Hewitt when he was last out on the coast, and an award was given which should have been carried into effect last December, under a threat of fine and the presence of an armed vessel to enforce it. In consequence of the absence of Consul Hewitt and the sickness or death of the Vice-Consuls, nothing has been done in the matter. It is reported that the natives of New Calabar are now menacing the Bonny men on their way to and from the Endelle markets, and in such a way as will certainly lead to another of those native wars which are so ruinous to British interests. The treaties recently entered into between these people and Her Majesty's Government expressly forbid their entering upon war without first appealing to the Consular Court for redress of any wrongs; but the consular officials being now in England, this cannot be done, and much harm may occur unless they soon return to their posts.", 'last_edit_date': '1885-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1885#article-18', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.635, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Recent Troubles with the Jebus', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'From Lagos, under date June 20, we are told that the markets in the Jebu country have re-opened, and the natives have resumed trading. The roads leading through the territory of the Egbas are, however, still closed.', 'last_edit_date': '1892-07-04', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_07_1892#article-12', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.634, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Political Troubles on the West Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The British and African steamer Opobo, with mails and passengers from the West Coast of Africa, arrived at Liverpool a short time since. Health on the coast was still unsatisfactory, and trade dull. At Bonny and Opobo there had been no further hostility since the British Consul had held a "palaver," and both peoples were settling down to trade. At Salt Pond trade was at a standstill, owing to fighting going on a few miles from the coast. The trouble was between the tribes in the interior, those on the sea-coast, and the natives known as the "middlemen." Both parties were desirous of direct intercourse, which the "middlemen" natives were doing all they could to prevent. The effect was that business was stopped, and several encounters had taken place. The war in the Ashantee country showed no signs of abatement.

Affairs in the Cameroons are in a very unsatisfactory state. It is said that the natives have boycotted all the whites, and refused to trade with them or supply them with food. No white man can buy a fowl or a bullock, and the natives have barred the way to the fresh water, so that the whites have to depend upon rain for all the water they require. Large numbers of the factories up the river are closed, and the traders are sending their working staffs home. The natives are determined that the German Government shall derive no advantages from the port. They are paying up all the debts they owe to the white traders, but are doing no fresh business. The people on both sides of the river have joined together, and made common cause against the Government. They do not threaten, nor will they fight, but they will not work. hh: The detention and subsequent release of European captives in Abyssinia during the 19th century underscore the intricate diplomatic relations and power dynamics between Abyssinia and European powers.
result: The detention and subsequent release of European captives in Abyssinia during the 19th century underscore the intricate diplomatic relations and power dynamics between Abyssinia and European powers, as detailed in both the General History of Africa textbook and The African Times news articles. The textbook describes how Emperor Tewodros II of Ethiopia detained British consul Hormuzd Rassam and other foreigners to compel the British government to respond to his requests for foreign workers and military equipment. Initially, this strategy seemed effective, as the British government agreed to Tewodros's demands. However, relations deteriorated when Tewodros re-imprisoned the captives, partly due to reports of British activities perceived as threats to Ethiopian sovereignty. This incident illustrates the intricate diplomatic maneuvers and the leverage Tewodros attempted to exert over European powers, reflecting the broader context of European imperial interests in Africa. Similarly, The African Times articles highlight the detention of European captives, including Consul Cameron and missionaries, by the King of Abyssinia, and the diplomatic efforts made by the British government to secure their release. The involvement of Mr. Rassam, who was sent as an envoy to negotiate with the Emperor, and the subsequent release of the captives after diplomatic exchanges, underscore the complex diplomatic maneuvers involved. The articles also mention the influence of European powers, such as the British government's instructions and the involvement of the Foreign Office, which reflect the power dynamics at play. Additionally, the articles highlight the challenges faced in communication and negotiation, such as the King's initial refusal to release the captives and the need for assurances of goodwill before their departure. Together, these accounts illustrate the diplomatic complexities and power relations between Abyssinia and European nations during this period.
